Now this death, when we say death, this is apparent death,
and this is uh, clinical death, there are various names for it,


It means, that the heart has stopped beating, say, and
there is no respiration the person is not breathing,


So that is but, the brain is still functioning,


So till the brain is functioning, the man is not dead,

It is a very very simple technique, and anybody can learn it
<,,> 

<$B> 

So friends,  just learn the technique of
cardio pulmonary resuscitation,


By cardio I mean heart, pulmonary means lungs, and
resuscitation means revival,


Learning the technique, of reviving heart and lungs when it
fails, is what we call as cardio pulmonary resuscitation,


Before we actually learn, what is C P R or cardio pulmonary
resuscitation is,  uh imperative that we should know, as
to where the heart is situated, and what exactly is its function,


That heart, is just like a size of the fist, and is situated
in the centre of the, chest, with the strenum or the breast bone in
front, and the spine, or the backbone behind,


And uh, it pumps the blood to all the tissues of the body,
almost trillions of cells of the body, and the main target organs like
brain, which is the master controlling function of the body, the
kidneys liver and heart itself,


If the heart fails, that is the pumping action fails, the
death ensues,


And this death, is of two types, a clinical death, or what
we call a temporary death, and, a biological death, or a permanent
death,


The time interval, between this temporary death, and the
permanent death, is just four to five minutes,


It is this time interval which is crucial, and we have to take
all the measures, of C P R, at this junture,


Now, before we learn the technique of C P R, it is very very
essential for us to know, is the individual alive or dead,


If alive, is he sleeping, or he is unconscious, and there
are certain parameters by which we can easily determine, whether the
individual is dead or alive,


Like for example, we must try, to say ask some question to
the patient, are you okay, ?


If he is not, if it there is no response, then we can just
pinch the skin, or we can press over the, upper portion of the eyes we
can just have a deep pressure,


If there is no response, that means the individual is not,
uh not in a sleeping state, but he is unconscious or he may be dead,


Now how to distinguish whether he is dead, or, he is
unconscious,


We can easily see, the chest movements, or the breathing
movements,


If a person is unconscious we can see there is a breathing movement
or you can bring the palm of your, hand and put it just in front of the
nostrills or over the, uh mouth, and we can  
 feel   some warmth of the air,


Or, we can just bring the cheek, in front of the mouth and
the nose

And the third thing commonly which we should feel is, we can see
the carotids, the one of the arteries, which is very close to the adams
apple or what we call as the voice box or a sound box, there is a groove
on the side of this apple,


Uh this uh, uh, adams apple, we can just feel the
pulsation,


If we can feel the pulsation, we can say that the individual is

If you are not able to perceive the pulsation, and we say there

And then we have to keep certain " do's " and
" don'ts " in mind,


For example, we should never try to keep a pillow under the
head,


Now why it is so, ?


The principle is,  just explain you,


Whenever a individual breathes he breathes either from the nostrils
or from the mouth, and whatever air he inhales, it goes through the
windpipe and goes into the lungs, and the air which is inhaled, goes
into the windpipe and the lungs expand, and the chest moves,


If, for example we just keep for example we are keeping a
pillow under the head, this windpipe is obstructed, and there is a
narrowing of the windpipe


You can see here, this red one this is windpipe it gets choked
<,> and there is no, free passage of air into the windpipe, and an

So we must make an effort never to put any pillow under the head

The second thing which we must keep in mind, we can put any

Just by a simple technique, of raising the legs, or raising

The third thing, we must never put in, any water, or any
<,,>  any solid, in the individuals mouth,


There is a risk, as the individual is either in a temporory

The next thing which we must keep in mind is, we must assure

 such a simple technique,

Growth and characterization of lead telluride crystals
   


Ashok Kumar Department of physics and Astrophysics, University of
Delhi, Delhi - 110 007, India 

 

  Abstract  : 


Ferroelectric semiconducting crystals of lead telluride were grown by
fusing lead and tellurium in vacuum.


Optical as well as electrical properties were studied to characterize
the grown polycrystalline samples.


For the purpose of comparison experiments were also performed with the
single crystal of the material also.


The typical C.V characteristics obtained from the fabricated
Al-BaTiO3- PbTe( MIS ) structures were also investigated.


From XRD data, the lattice constant comes out to be 3.34A.


An overall decrease in mobility and resistivity with increasing
temperature ( from 77K to 300K ) is observed while the carrier concentration
shows a reverse behaviour.


Results with MOS capacitor are found to be in good agreement with the
earlier reported works. 

 

 Keywords  :


" Ferroelectric " " semiconductors
" , " electrical transport properties " , "
MIS capacitor " , " lead telluride crystals " .


 

  PACS Nos.  : 


72.20, Fr. 73.40. Qv, 77.80. - e 


  1. Introduction  

 

The existence of a series of IV-VI compounds is one of the most
exciting recent discoveries in the field of ferroelectric semiconductors.


PbTe, a polar semiconductor of this class with cubic NaCl structure
is a non-stoichiometric solid.


Several studies are reported relating various aspects of PbTe [ 1-4 ] .


Hall effect measurements were studied by many workers [ 5-7 ] .


Rogers [ 8 ] and others have reported the results of mobility and
carrier concentration between room temperature and liquid nitrogen
temperature.


But sufficient data have not been reported regarding the growth and
electrical properties of PbTe bulk samples. 

 

The metal-insulator-semiconductor ( MIS ) diodes, which are the
most useful devices in the study of semiconductor surfaces, have been studied
by several workers [ 9, 10 ] .


Lily  et al  [ 11 ] reported some experimental results on
MIS structures fabricated from ( 100 ) PbTe bulk single crystals at 77K.


However, studies on MIS diodes made of PbTe bulk sample at room
temperature were not given much attention so far. 

 

In the present investigation, an attempt has been made to study
the carrier transport properties in p-PbTe single crystal and laboratory
grown polycrystalline samples of n-type PbTe by the experimental measurements
and theoretical analysis.


Technical details for fabricating Al-BaTiO3-PbTe( MIS )
structures and the first results of C-V characteristics at a fixed high
frequency of 1 MHz at room temperature are also reported.  


  2. Experimental  


  2.1 Charge growth and sample preparation :  

 

For charge growth, according to molecular weight composition of
PbTe, the required quantities of elemental Pb and Te ( each of 5N purity )
were taken in a specially shaped clean quartz tube and the tube was vacum
sealed.


Vacuum of the order of 10<*>minus</*>6 torr was produced by
a vacuum pumping system ( Hindhivac, model V.S.- 65 ) .


The ampoule containing the materials was heated in an electric
furnace at a temperature of 1000 <*> degrees</*>C for about 28 hours
continuously.


The furnace temperature could be determined using a pt-pt / Rb
thermocouple and a digital milivoltmeter ( AGRONIC 34A-4 model ) .


The furnace was cooled slowly.


The formed material was then cut into almost rectangular shape of
dimensions 4.5 x 2.2 x 1.0 mm3 from the bowl with a microslicer - 2
using a very fine blade.


The samples were then ground with coarse and fine carborundum powder
of grades 600, 800 and 1200 consecutively to obtain flat and parallel slides.


These were then first roughly polished on a polishing paper and then
using diamond compound ( Hifin fluid  ` OS'  ) on a smooth
polishing cloth fixed to a rotating disc.


The  <- > smples   samples   were cleaned first
with 4 % hydrofluoric acid and then with acetone. 


2.2.   Optical and electrical properties :  

 

Philips diffractometer ( PW 1130 / 00 model ) with Bragg-Brentano
arrangement was used for XRD studies.


For conductivity and mobility measurements, Vander Pauw technique [
12 ] was employed.


Pure Indium was used to make ohmic contacts on the samples.


The cryostat was of conventional design.


A liquid nitrogen tall dewar was used to provide the desired
temperature to the specimen chamber.


The specimen temperature was varied from 77K to 300K by means of an
electronic temperature controller.


The thermometer used was a chromel-constantan thermocouple.


A magnetic field of 5K Gauss was applied by a varian electromagnet (
Varian, Fieldial Mark-II model ) .


The " d.c. " conductivity and Hall mobility were
measured for both single crystal and polycrstalline samples at different
temperatures. 


2.3.   MOS capacitor :  


2.3.1.   Fabrication :  

 

A well polished slice of PbTe was cleaned by treating it first
with a solution of KOH, ethylene glycol and H2O2 ( 10 : 10
: 1 ) and then by methanol.


A layer of pure Indium provided the back ohmic contact.


The thin insulating oxide layer of BaTiO3 was deposited on
the semiconducting surface by RF sputtering using NM Nordiko 1500 RF
sputtering system.


The top contact electrodes over the oxide layer were made by
evaporating 99.99 % pure aluminium in circular shapes ( diameter <*>
approximate- sign</*> 400 <*> mu</*>m ) using a copper mesh.


A Hindhivac vacuum coating unit model No. 12A4 was employed for this
purpose.


About 8 electrodes were formed on the oxide layer.  


2.3.2.   C-V measurements :  

 

A three terminal measuring cell and an automatic C-V plotter (
princeton Applied Research model - 410 were used for measuring the
capacitance-voltage characteristics of Al-BaTiO3<*>minus</*><&> PbTe
MOS device at room temperature.


The MOS behaviour was investigated by taking the retrace; of the
steady state high frequency C-V characteristics at a fixed frequency of 1
MHz. 


  3. Results and discussions  

 

The XRD patterns of laboratory grown pellets are shown in Figure
1.


The XRD pattern of a typical ( 002)- cut single crystal is also shown
in the figure.


In figures, it can be noted that  
the peak at 2<*>theta</*> = 27.5<*>degrees</*> for single crystal is almost
reproduced in the present grown sample at 2<*>theta</*> = 27<*>degrees</*>.


The slight difference in the value of 2<*>theta</*> reflactions for (
002 ) may be attributed to the difference of stoichiometry in the two
materials and the method of preparation.


The lattice constant calculated from the XRD data using the relations
for cubic crystals comes out to be <*> approximate-sign</*> 3.34A.    

 

The variation of mobility with temperature for PbTe single
crystal and laboratory grown crystal are shown in Figure 2.


The mobility decreases with increasing temperature for both the
samples.


However, it can be noted that the curves in the figure exhibit two
distinct regions of low ( 77K-150K ) and high ( 150K-300K ) temperatures.


The rate of decrease of mobility is slower in lower temperature
region than that in higher temperature region.


In the low temperature region, the observed lincarity of curves
clearly suggest that only one type of carriers contribute to the conduction
process and the mobility corresponds to the light holes.


The steep fall of the mobility in the high temperature region in
general is attributed  to an increased contribution of heavy
holes.


Also the overall nature of the curves for both the samples is similar
except in the magnitude thereby, supporting the XRD data.


The calculated values of a are given in Table 1.


The results of single crystal sample is in close agreement with the
reported values for the p-PbTe single crystal [ 13 ] , the observed
variations of resistivity with temperature are shown in Figure 3.


The values of carrier concentration   ` n'  
using the mobility and resistivity data are depicted in Figure 4.


The variation in   ` n'   clearly indicates a
monotonous decrease with decreasing temperature.


The corresponding calculated conductivities have been shown in Figure
5.  

 

In order to investigate the temperature dependence of the
depletion capacitance in the inversion region for verifying whether it
follows any Curie law dependence, a series of MIS were fabricated.


However, except for BaTiO3 which was RF sputtered on PbTe
substrate at  room temperature, all other insulators
investigated revealed very poor surface conductivity modulation property of
the base PbTe semiconductor due to their low resistivity and   probably presence of pin-holes.


One other major factor affecting these devices was the poor surface
finish of the PbTe sample.


Efforts to decrease roughness of the sample have been   seriously limited by the technical limitation of our
lab.


The conventional high frequency C-V behaviour for a capacitor with
BaTiO3 layer is shown in Figure 6.


The measured    accumulation capacitance of 48.8 pF corresponds to the insulator
BaTiO3 according to the conventional MOS theories [ 14 ] .


The calculated value of the dielectric constant for BaTiO3
film <*> approximate-sign</*> 15 is in good agreement with reported values
for amorphous BaTiO3 films [ 11 ] . 

 

The observed shift in the flat band voltage towards the negative
voltage region is commonly attributed towards a high percentage of interface
state density at the BaTiO3- PbTe junction and the increase of
capacitance beyond <*> plus</*>4 volts is probably due to sudden increase in
the conductance value of the film.


The results thus suggest that although the capacitance varies with
applied voltage, the dielectric strength of BaTiO3 film is not
enough to induce inversion in the underlying PbTe layer. 

 

Reports of Lilly  et al  [ 11 ] and Moulin  et al
 [ 15 ] also reveal that MIS properties are strongly determined by
preparation and fabrication techniques.


They also report that small capacitance changes are to be expected
experimentally and that insulator dielectric strength in excess of
106 V cm-1 are required in order to obtain surface
potential control.


The observed small change of capacitance is thus well supported and
in agreement with the theoretical prediction. 


  4. Conclusion  

 

PbTe polycrystalline samples were prepared by fusing Pb and Te in
vacuum at 1000<*>degrees</*>C.


The XRD patterns of these samples though indicate a preferred
orientation along the ( 002 ) axis, these samples cannot be strictly
categorised as single crystals due to the obvious nature of the simple
techniques employed in growing them.


However, the relative slow cooling ( <*> approximate-sign</*>
10<*>degrees</*>C / hr ) employed in this case may have resulted in large
degree of reduction of its polycrystalline nature.


Almost similar behaviour of mobility and resistivity curves for both
the samples also suggests a near single crystal nature of the laboratory
growth crystals. 

 

For MIS studies, the present work reveals that probably higher
thickness of the insulating film and better surface finish of PbTe may help
in realizing these MOS capacitors and efforts are now being made in these
lines to achieve better device quality.

SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY    


  The many uses of a laser beam      

 

Ability to retrieve enormous amounts of information,
shoot down hostile missiles and aircraft, propel satellites and spaceships,
cut and heat-treat materials, or kill cancerous cells in the human body with
pinpoint accuracy, is the magic of laser technology that was once regarded as
 " an invention in search of an application"  .


It has now become an indispensable tool for science, technology,
medicine and defence. 

 

In 1916, Albert Einstein predicted that electrons could be made to
emit a special kind of light, but it was not until 1960 that Theodore Maiman,
an engineer at Hughes Research Laboratories in the United States, made this
vision come true.


A flash tube was used to pump energy into a ruby rod to make it emit a
brilliant beam of red light of a kind never seen before. 

 

A conventional light bulb emits light consisting of a number of
different wavelengths, which stream out randomly.


In scientific terms it is incoherent.


A laser emits coherent light of one wavelength, with the light waves
surging out in a tightly ordered array.


Laser light can pack immense power and can travel long distances.


 

The term  " laser"  is an acronym for light
amplification by stimulated emission of radiation.


The  first practical impact was in the realm of
experimental scientific investigation, where it provided researchers a source
of light that could not only identify types of atoms and molecules and
initiate chemical reactions but, in general, probe, measure, and modify the
fundamental properties of matter.


Thereafter, the  remarkable properties were put to
use in industrial applications.


The first, and in some sense still the largest, application is
cutting and heat-treating of materials whether the need is for large cuts
in armour plate, using an extremely powerful carbon dioxide laser, or the
precise trim of an expensive piece of synthetic fibre cloth using a small,
hand-held laser.


The cuts are made without damaging any nearby material. 

 

What is that makes laser light so exceptional?


Although most people believe that laser light is more powerful than
light from other sources, this is decidedly not the case.


With the exception of very specialised industrial or military lasers,
the total light output power of virtually any laser is less than one-fifth
that of a 60-watt bulb, and the lasers used in communication, computers, and
the recording industry all emit less light energy than a small ornamental
bulb. 

 

If it is not total power of emission, what special properties of
laser light make it different from the light emitted from incandescent or
fluorescent lights,  arcs, the sun, or even from fire?


There are a dozen or so highly technical differences, but most
commercial and industrial applications rely on the four fundamentally unique
properties of laser light: colour purity ( monochromaticity ) ,
directionality, tightness of focus, and coherence. 

 

  Colour purity :  


White light, for example light from the sun, is really a mixture of
light of different colours, each with a different wavelength.


In the portion of the light spectrum that we can see, the shortest
wave-lengths appear blue; somewhat longer wavelengths appear green; and
those longer still yield yellow, orange, red, and deep red.


Sir Issac Newton demonstrated over 300 years ago that white light is
easily broken up into its constituents by passing it through some device that
bends the light proportional to its wavelength.


Mother Nature provides such a device in raindrops; sunlight passing
through the drops is refracted into colours, yielding spectacular rainbows.


Similarly, when light  from a flashlight or
light bulb passes through a prism, it will split into colours, even if a
piece of red glass is placed over the light source. 

 

In contrast, light from a laser operating in the red spectrum
would pass through the prism without being split.


This is because the range of red colours in the laser is extremely
narrow; the output is highly colour pure.


So even though the total light energy from the flashlight may be
larger than from the laser, all of the  light power goes into
one extremely pure colour, while the power from the other sources is spread
over a vast number of colours.


Many industrial and research laser applications depend on colour
purity. 

 

  Directionality :  


When light is emitted from a light bulb, it has no preferred
direction; the radiation goes uniformly in all directions unless something
special is done to capture and steer it along a specific path.


Steering devices such as mirrors and lenses are common and form an
integral part of many of our everyday light sources.


However, if the application calls for a beam of light going in one
precise direction, with little or no spread in angle, something quite
different is required. 

 

  Tightness of focus :  


When focused down to a small spot by a lens,  spread
increases.


Since laser light possesses the smallest product of angular spread
and spot size of all light ( diffraction limited), it will have the least
possible angular spread when focused to a tiny spot.


This property provides the laser with very precise focusing, allowing
all of the laser power to be concentrated on only one spot on the material.


In general, light from visible lasers can be routinely focused to
spot sizes on the order of .000127 centimetre, far smaller than light from
any other source. 

 

  Coherence :  


Light, regardless of its wavelength or colour, can be usefully
imagined as a wave travelling through space, or any transparent medium like
air or glass.


This wave has crests and valleys, much like ocean waves; two such
waves are said to be correlated if their respective crests and valleys bear
some relationship to each other, either in space of time. 

 

When a light source produces radiation that is not correlated in
space or time, it is said to be  " incoherent"  .


The best example of an incoherent radiator is the sun.


This is because the light coming from the sun at one instant is
uncorrelated with the light emitted later, and the light at the top of the
sun is uncorrelated with the light from the bottom of the sun.


In fact, unless great pains are taken, light from virtually all
non-laser sources is nearly totally incoherent. 

 

Laser light, however, can be easily made coherent in space and
time.


This property allows lasers to operate in a special mode in which the
output is no longer a steady beam of light, but rather a precise string of
extremely short-duration pulses. 

 

Lasers have revolutionised communications, computers, and
entertainment.


The development of solid-state lasers capable of emitting light with
long wavelengths far into the red end of the spectrum ( so-called infrared )
has prompted parallel engineering efforts on glass fibre cables for
transmitting this light. 

 

The benefits of  ability to retrieve enormous
amounts of information stored in a tiny silver platter called CD-ROM (
Compact Disk - - Read Only Memory ) are many.


What is more, the laser has the ability to record, with amazing speed
and flawless accuracy, vast amounts of information onto discs within
computers, or onto paper.


Magazines and newspapers are now printed from computers using laser
printers.


Laser printers use plain paper, eliminating expensive photographic
paper, processing machines, chemicals, maintenance and labour.


They cost less than other technologies. 

 

As important as they are, these applications pale in significance
when compared to  potential medical uses.


Lasers were first used in eye surgery, the 
transparency making it a logical first subject.


Even now, most innovations in the use of lasers occur in
opthalmology.


The blue light from an argon light is being used to seal a hole in
the retina, to treat glaucoma - - potentially a blinding condition - - by
cutting a hole to let excess fluid escape and to preserve sight in persons
with diabetic retinopathy by destroying the abnormal blood vessels caused by
the disease. 

 

The eye laser developed in the US was first used in India where
millions of people suffer from cataract.


The instrument detects whether a  retina is
obstructed by a cataract or is no longer functioning.


Lasers also see through cataracts to a determine whether surgery can
restore a  eyesight. 

 

Lasers are also being used successfully to remove kidney stones
from the lower ureter, the tube leading from the kidney to the bladder.


Traditionally, this operation involves a large incision in the  side and hospitalisation of upto two weeks.


Now with the use of a laser the stones are literally chipped to
pieces and patients are benefiting from shorter hospital stays. 

 

Similarly, gallstones are exposed to lasers through an optical
fibre passed through one channel of rigid endoscope.


A second channel contains a relay lens system for viewing and a third
channel transports a saline    
solution purge that crushes the stones in the gall-bladder. 

 

The high-energy beam of light can be used for cutting, sealing
and closing blood vessels.


Lasers can be used to replace stitches in many kinds of surgery.


The beams can fuse the protein of the tissues and, when the wound
heals, the body can absorb the coagulated tissue replacing a new protein and
preventing scars on the body. 

 

Laser techniques can work much faster than tranditional suturing,
thereby reducing the risk of infection while healing.


It achieves its cutting power by focusing light.


A beam of only a new watts can be made to cut an enormous amount by
focusing on a spot smaller than the diameter of a human hair. 

 

Laser technology has not only made surgery a gentler process, it
also costs less and saves time.


It has succeeded in its goal of cutting down hospitalisation and has,
in fact, entirely taken some procedures out of the hospital.


Laser technology lessens the trauma of traditional surgery and is
good because it is gentle, precise and can work into a deep hole without
having to disrupt a lot of overlying tissues.


Unlike in conventional surgery, the surgeon can sight along the beam
of light at the target tissue and does not have to struggle to look around
for the instrument. 

 

The laser has also demonstrated itself as an awesomely potent
weapon of destruction recently during the Gulf War.


Missiles were tracked, identified and ultimately destroyed with the
coherence of laser light.


It is the source of a vast number of new technologies as well.


This technology has been thoroughly integrated into everyday life and
it has developed into a tool so ubiquitous it would be hard to imagine life
in the high-tech world without it.  <*> filled square </*>

In the kingdom of shadows     

 

 THE beginnings of painting
are lost to us in the dark caves where the pierced bisons and magical hand
prints guard the secret of their genesis.


Speculations about the birth of tragedy do not transport us directly
to the source of a shattering experience conveying the tragic sense of
life.


Even the  ` Ode to a Grecian Urn'  does not have the
magic power to make the urn yield the enigma of its birth. 

 

The birth of all arts, except cinema, is shrouded in mystery and
is far removed from us in time and perhaps in spirit.


The belief in the magical powers of  art, in its
capacity to control the forces of the cosmos and the minds of men, does
not come easily to a modern artist who feels his importance against even the
market forces to which he must submit his art. 

 

Cinema was born just a century ago and has mingled so intimately
with our lives as no other art form has done in our age.


As Arnold Hauser says, our age can be justly described as the Film
Age. 

 

Yet, in one hundred years of its existence, it has equalled and
sometimes surpassed the highest achievements of the other arts.


Having been madly in love with it for the best part of my life, I
would like to celebrate its 100th birthday by feasting on the glimpses of
the everchanging contours of its enigmatic, dear face.


For a brief instant, I would like to freeze on frames that catch
something of its aerial spirit.


At the gate of this theatre, where we watch these short clips in
accelerated motion, we must have the face of Janus, looking at flashbacks and
flashforwards. 

 

 " Last night I was in the Kingdom of Shadows. 

 

 If you only knew how strange it is to be there.


It is a world without sound, without colour.


Everything there <*> dotted line</*> is dipped in monotonous grey
<*> dotted line</*>


It is not life but its shadow, it is not motion but its soundless
specter <*> dotted line</*>


Suddenly something clicks, everything vanishes and a train
appears on the screen.


It speeds straight at you - - watch out!


It seems as though it will plunge into the darkness in which you sit,
turning you into a ripped sack full of lacerated flesh and splinetered bones,
and crushing into the dust and into broken fragments this hall and this
building, so full of women, wine, music and vice."  

 

Maxim  review of the Lumiere programme at the
Nizny-Novgorod fair was published on the fourth of July, 1896.


In him, we have one of the earliest witnesses to the capacity of
verisimilitude that cinema has. 

 

Cinema changed the art of narration.


Tolstoy had anticipated the tremendous and far reaching impact
that cinema was going to make on the art of writing.


He said this on his 80th birthday.


August 1908;  " You will see that this little clicking
contraption with the revolving handle will make a revolution in our life - -
in the life of writers.


It is a direct attack on the old methods of literary art.


We shall have to adapt ourselves to the shadowy screen and to the
cold machine.


A new form of writing will be necessary <*> dotted line</*>


But I rather like it.


This swift change of scene, this blending of emotion and
experience - - it is closer to life.


In life, too, changes and transitions flash by before our eyes,
and emotions of the soul are like a hurricane.


The cinema has divined the mystery of motion.


And that is greatness <*> dotted line</*>


In the reeds of film art sits the toadthe businessman.


Above him hovers the insect - - the artist.


A glance, and the jaws of businessman devour the artist.


But that does not mean destruction <*> dotted line</*> in the belly
of the businessman is carried on the process of impregnation and the
development."  

 

Great writers from all over the world have been fascinated by
cinema.


From Tolstoy to Kundera, we have a long line which includes
Sartre, Malraux, Beckett, Joyce and a galaxy of names.


Poetry has been affected by the concept of montage, which in turn has
learnt a lot from poetry.


Classics of literature have not only found a new life in the
country of their origin, but have undergone a complete metamorphosis like in
 Throne of Blood, an adaptation of  Macbeth. 

 

Important artistic movements in our century, from surrealism,
expressionism and futurism, to abstract art, have felt the need to have a
dialogue with cinema.


Politicians from Lenin to Hitler and Mussolini have realised its
power.


( In India in a state like Tamil Nadu, you do not know what came
first - - life or cinema!) 

 

From political philosophy to transcendental metaphysics, cinema
has expressed it all.


Its ability to syncretise would have been tested by  unrealised project to make a film on   Capital  .


Eisenstein wanted to make use of James  inner
monologue to compress material across centuries and civilisations, in one
day in the life of a worker.


This Griffin on a film was to have a tongue-in-cheek credit line:
 "  " Capital "  , a film by Sergei
Eisenstein, based on the text of Karl Marx with a scenario by James
Joyce."  

 

Cinema, from its birth has shown its capability to express with
equal ease the waking and dream states of human existence.


In fact, its greatest achievements have come precisely from its
dual nature.


Its ability to record has enabled it to be a witness to our times
( to borrow a phrase of  ) as no other art form has done.


From two world wars to atomic explosions, famines, earthquakes, it
has recorded all that is terrible and that will be indissolubly associated
with our century.


It has also recorded with loving care our achievements in the
material world, when man broke his bondage to the earth and set foot on the
moon.


It is a curious irony of history that one of the earliest films by
George Melies was an imaginary voyage to the moon and within a few decades,
cameras were recording the real voyage to the moon. 

 

Not only has it recorded our reality, our history as we made it
with heroism and cowardice, with imagination and stupidity, with our heroes
and villains - - which other century has been its Grandhi and Hitler
recorded? - - but it has done much more. 

 

It has been a witness to our cherished dreams as well as to our
perversions and nightmares.


The collective being watching the moving images in the realm of
shadows, lost to its own materiality as well as to that of the world around,
has seen its own unconscious projected on screens all over the weorld.


The film form has assumed the shape of the concrete-sensuous world as
well as the nebulous, ever changing aspects of our wishes, fears, passions
traumas and visions.


From intensely personal expression to shameless spectacle, from
spiritual quest to sheer pornography, cinema has been it all. 

 

Just as a human being, in the period that it spends in the womb,
experiences the entire history of evolution in a capsule form, cinema in its
100 years of non-solitude, has assumed all forms of life.


Through the powers of animators, it has freed us from the tyranny
of the laws of gravity, relativity and causality.


It has in its dark halls, given us the power over objects and
events that alchemists, shamans and magicians have craved for centuries.


 

And yet, of all the art forms it seems to be the one most
threatened with extinction. 

 

Will there be cinema in the 21st century? 

 

This is the question everyone who has been in love with cinema
is afraid to ask and yet must ask. 

 

With the advances in technology, the spectacle is brought to
the viewer and there is no need for him to leave his home.


Theoretically, the entire population of the world can watch the
same event, just as it happens.


But with the  ` one world'  there is the media
control, the monopolies, the vast amounts and, to quote Tolstoy again,
 " the toad - - the businessman"  in whose belly goes on the
process of the impregnation and development of the seeds of the future.


Can we be as sure as he was at the turn of the century that these
seeds  " will come out on  earth and <*> dotted line</*>
begin their beautiful, brilliant lives all over again "  ? 

 

With access to a database of stored images, with possibilities of
all kinds of manipulation of these images through distortion, alteration,
combination of generated images with captured images, with simulation of the
sensuous world by computers, with the possibilities of holographs and
other types of 3-D imagery, it is difficult and hazardous to do any
crystal gazing. 

 

Practitioners of every art form, when challenged by some other
form with overlapping characteristics, have lended to be doomsday
prophets.


But just as painting, threatened by still photography, freed itself
of certain tasks like creation of verisimilitude, cinema might find its
own solutions. 

 

If I have to write the scenario for the future of cinema, I would
rather either trust the miraculous powers of my hero or just write an open
ending.  <*> two red and black diamonds</*>

<*> dotted line</*> AND  DHARMA  SHALL COME
      

 

 WHEN Patrica Gonzales, 36,
writes her address in a  diary, she uses one more line than
she strictly needs to.


Below her zip-code number, she invariably adds the words: 
  " Om Mani Padma Hum   ." 


For Gonzales, a resident of Mexico City, is a  " Boodist"
 who has been reciting this  mantra  for the past five
years. 

 

Indeed,   " Om Mani Padma Hum "
  is no longer the preserve of mist-clad monasteries and
generation-old Buddhists.


For, in these days of try-and-buy religion, this sonorous chant wafts
out of California condos and Bombay buildings.


It graces business cards in Seattle and provides an inexhaustible
topic for religious discussion in Syndey. 

 

For slowly, almost imperceptibly, in the last few decades,
Buddhism, once a strictly oriental religion, has captured hearts and minds in
distant lands.


And it is not  clouds of incense, flickering
butter lamps and gorgeous red-and-gold images that entrance this new breed of
followers, but the 2,500-year-old philosophy of a man who, followers believe,
peered into the heart of the universe. 

 

Siddhartha was born around 563 BC.


His father was a monarch who went to enormous lengths to shield his
sensitive son from the unpleasant aspects of life.


But when Siddhartha was 29, during his first few ventures outside the
palace grounds, he encountered suffering, sickness and death. 

 

After days of turmoil, Siddhartha left the palace in search of
answers to the questions that haunted him.


Years of wandering and introspection led him to Gaya, where he sat
under a   peepal   tree and went into a trance.


He emerged from his meditation a Buddha, or an Awakened One. 

 

During his moment of realisation, Siddhartha understood that
the self is an illusion and that all is impermanent.


He outlined the Four Truths; that misery exists, that misery
originates from within us, that this can be eliminated, and that this
elimination is the result of a methodical path that must be followed. 

 

The Buddha prescribed the Eightfold Path, consisting of basic
rules like right thinking, right speech and right living, which would help
the individual to escape from the cycle of life and death and to attain
nirvana. 

 

While about 200 million people in Asia, mainly Thailand, Japan,
Sri Lanka, Tibet, Burma and Vietnam, are Buddhist by tradition, a large
number of people from other religious backgrounds are becoming Buddhist,
or at least adopting some aspects of the religion. 

 

In Hollywood, Buddhism has displaced environmental
consciousness as the fad of the moment and the Dalai Lama has been elevated
to the status of a pop icon.


While actor Richard Gere has reportedly donated over a million
dollars to the exiled Tibetan leader, other big names like Harrison Ford,
Shirley MacLaine, Jane Fonda and Meg Ryan are also among the famous and the
faithful Bernardo Bertolucci, whose film,  The Little Buddha  ,
was released last month, says that his foray into the religion has changed
him.


 " I have come to realise what a great religion Buddhism is,"
 says the maker of the film, which interweaves the story of
Siddhartha with the search of  lamas  from Bhutan for a
reincarnation of a great teacher. 

 

While American interest in Buddhism is relatively new, 19th
century British scholars like Christmas Humphreys and I B Horner started
societies like the Pali Text Society and the Buddhist Society about 70
years ago.


 " These groups were purely academic in nature,"  says
R Sirkar, chairman of the United Lodge of Theosophists.


 " But gradually the interest became more religious and
other groups began to appear which accepted Buddhism as a way of life.


This is probably related to the crisis in Christianity in the
West." 


The 26-year-old Western Buddhist Order started by Sangarakshita, a
British monk, is a perfect example.


The organisation, one among about 30 similar groups in the UK, has
600 members, many of whom live in single-sex communities.


Regular classes are conducted both on the teachings of Buddhism and
on meditation.


The  magazine,  " The Golden Drum
"  , keeps members up to date about monasteries being
constructed in Queensland and retreats being built on Scottish islands.


 

Most members wandered into the order for a dollop of yoga and
meditation and stayed for spirItual seconds.


And while many of the  early members were long-haired
hippies who might just as easily have drifted into the portals of a
Scientology church or a Moonies temple, the newer followers are clean-cut
professionals with an educated interest in Buddhism. 

 

The growing awareness of Buddhism has, to a great extent, been
created by the sudden presence of Tibetan monks in diverse parts of the
world.


In 1959, over 1,00,000 Tibetans fled their homeland, which had
been annexed by the Chinese.


While most Tibetans settled in India, some went to parts of Europe
and America.


Concerned about the survival of their culture, they began to build
monasteries and libraries.


And in order to fund themselves, they began to conduct meditation
and yoga classes. 

 

Indeed, Tibetan and other Buddhist groups are mushrooming around
the world.


And even if their teachings contradict each  ,
their followers don't really care.


 " There are thousands of paths to the truth,"  says
Rev Prof Kohilavatta Anandathera of the Bahujan Vihar Trust in Bombay.


 " Each must find his own."  

 

It is this acceptance of individual beliefs and tolerance towards
different, even contradictory, opinions that seems to attract the rational
seekers of religion.


 " I was born a Christian but when I read about Buddhism, I
found it very appealing,"  says Dhammachari Lokamitra, a
Pune-based member of the Western Buddhist Order.


 " I liked tolerance and the fact that there is no greater
God in Buddhism.


Buddha is not God, but an enlightened man.


He only shows us the way.


We too can attain  nirvana  if we follow his path.


Buddhism does not demand blind belief.


It encourages you to question and investigate.


More than any other religion, I feel it meets the needs of the modern
man."  

 

 " I feel Buddhism has the most practical approach to
life,"  agrees Babloo Sen, the director of a Bombay school, who
meditates regularly with a group of friends.


 " In a way Buddhism is similar to courses like EST and Silva
Mind Control which believe that you have the power to make anything
happen.


These courses, however, try to change attitudes without
spirituality and so their impact is limited.


By following the techniques of Buddhism, you can control your
mind, transform your thoughts, change your attitude, and so improve your
  karma   .


There is no mumbo jumbo about sin and superstition.


Just straight psychological facts.


Undoubtedly this is the religion of today."  

 

While Sen still calls herself a Hindu, her friend and
meditation-mate Behroze Khajotia, who was born a Zoroastrian, admits that she
considers herself a Buddhist. 

 

 " When I started reading about Buddhlism and doing
yoga in 1991, I didn't know what I was in for,"  says Khajotia, a
researcher at TOMCO, who became interested in the religion when her
cousin, who has studied under many of the great Buddhist teachers, started
conducting meditation classes in Bombay.


 " I was a practising Parsi.


I said my prayers and did everything a good Parsi girl should.


But the more I read about Buddhism, the more involved I became.


I was very drawn by the openness and tolerance of the religion.


Buddhism challenges us to question the validity of our beliefs and
assumptions.


It has certainly made a huge difference in my life."  

 

While Khajotia says that her new-found beliefs have helped
her to snap out of her habitual depression.


Sen says that Buddhism has made her more humble and considerate.


 " It has turned my life upside down."  she says.


 " For example, I used to be an avid TV and movie watcher.


I couldn't sleep unless I watched a movie every night.


And then suddenly, one day, I was not interested in movies
anymore.


I felt I had many more important things to do - - books to read,
people to talk to.


Really, it was most peculiar."  

 

Sen and Khajotia are part of a group of middle-class Bombayites
who have consciously adopted a Buddhist teacher and a philosophy.


And like them numerous groups of middle-class Indians,
especially in Bangalore and Delhi, are rediscovering the religion that was
born here so long ago. 

 

Indeed, while the West is still flirting with Buddhism, in India
the religion has seen violent fluctuations.


While practically the state religion of the Mauryan and Kushan
dynasties, Buddhism vanished from India by the 12th century.


This was probably a consequence of the destruction of the great
universities, like Nalanda and Takshashila, and the massacre of monks by
invaders. 

 

There were few Buddhists in the country till Dr Babasaheb
Ambedkar, disillusioned by the Hindu caste system, called on the
oppressed lower castes to unite under the rather more egalitarian Buddhism.


Ambedkar, along with 2,00,000 followers, converted in 1956.


And although many view this as a social rather than a religious
statement.


Anandathera, who works with  Ambedkarites, is
optimistic. 

 

 " It is difficult to change your spiritual outlook
suddenly,"  says the monk who left his home in Sri Lanka 33 years
ago.


 " But in many ways they are better Budhists than we are.


They are not so caught up in rituals and ceremonies."  

 

Indeed, for believers, this sudden movement towards Buddhism, in
India and around the world, is no fad but the realisation of the long
foretold prophecy of  Shri  Padmasambhava, who introduced
Buddhism to Tibet.


 " When iron birds fly and horses run on wheel,"  the
eighth century saint said,  " the Tibetan people will be scattered
like ants across the face of the earth and  dharma  shall come
to the land of the red man."   <*> two red & black diomonds</*>

Celebrating the Essay  


by DARSHAN SINGH MAINI  

 

 Though  the essay as a distinct literary genre has
been courted and coveted by some of the greatest writers of the English
language, it has never quite attained its rightful place in the community of
letters.


While the poem, the novel, and the play walk into the parlor, or mount
the podium, as if it is their privilege, the essay is often treated as a poor
relation come in from the cold.


No wonder, it has  en route  sought hospitality
within the folds of the novel, the memoir, or the autobiography, and led a
fairly nomadic, shy, furtive, or vicarious existence. 

 

Of course, ever since Frenchman Michel Eyquem de Montaigne, who
is still regarded as the  putative father, the pure essayists
have struggled to keep its special credentials in order, wedded as they are
to a vision of the  freedom.


But for most novelists and poets, the essay has been a by-blow of
sorts.


Ironically, for that very reason, it has attained a raffish charm.


Either way, it has managed to survive despite frequent notices
about its impending demise.


For, if the essay is  " an enactment of the creation of the
self,"  as O.B. Hardison argues in a recent defense of the embattled
genre, then it has a constitutive franchise, or an existential lease. 

 

 Major Modern Essayists   *  presents some of
the most impressive and eloquent essays of our times.


Although meant chiefly for the American college student,  the  appeal extends to the essay addict
and the cognoscente alike.


It is truly a beaufiful house of words, assembled block by block,
and furnished with delicate care, taste, and understanding. 

 

In his preface Professor Gilbert H. Muller, the 
editor, has set down the parameters of the exercise.


The collection reveals a distinctive aesthetic at work in relation
to the format and the economy of the enterprise.


It confines itself to 20th-century writers - - from Virginia Woolf
to Annie Dillard - - and offers a rich, varied, and generous fare - -  "
a variety of voices, rhetorical modes, and prose forms."  

 

The essays included in this volume come from such diverse areas
of study as history, art, literature, ecology, science, medicine, philosophy,
linguistics, and sports, thus encompassing almost the entire spectrum of
modern life, thought, and aesthetic.


The 20 essayists - - ten men and ten women - - are drawn from Great
Britain, the United States, Canada, and Africa, and represent white,
black, Hispanic, and American-Chinese cultures.


Each is fielded with three to five pieces of prose to bring out the
aroma and ambience of his or her work.


A very thoughtful and efficient presentation but I was disappointed
to find no Indian writer here despite the fact that India produces the third
largest volume of literature in English in the world.


Even more mystifying is the omission of other Commonwealth writers
such as V.S. Naipaul and George Lamming.


The kind of colonial experience they represent, and the kind of
English they have evolved to render the agony and irony of their
situation, cannot simply be found in other texts and contexts. 

 

In a critique of this size and nature, it is not possible to take
up each individual essayist, and bring out the virtues of his or her prose in
terms of thought, signature, and style.


Nor is there any room for adequate illustrations.


The difficulty is compounded where some pieces and passages, like
period wines, yield their taste and flavor in slow, measured sips, and one
has to savor long periods of prose to register their presence.


I propose, therefore, to touch on some known classics, and on a
couple of new American voices that have lifted prose to a level where it
pleases and charms, compels and holds. 

 

To set Virginia Woolf at the head of the table is to recall
appropriately her celebrated ( and much misunderstood) statement:
 " Human nature changed in or about December 1910,"  which,
though formulated in the context of the Parisian Cubists and Surrealists,
defined strikingly a certain shift in modern sensibility, and in the ways of
appropriating experience for art.


The volume under review purports, above all, to show this aspect
through some of the profoundest moments of modern prose.


 essays included here-  " Professions for
Women,"   " The Death of the Moth,"  and  "
Middlebrow"  - - illustrate the resilience of the domesticated gypsy
genre, for the essays in question are in the form of a public address, a
series of  " dispersed meditations"  ( 
definition of the essay), and a public letter in that order. 


Her style accordingly is, in turn, chatty, witty, and conversational;
graphic, vivid, and figurative; puckish, fey, and mocking. 

 

Our next port of call is E.B. White, who almost created the
modern American essay out of the proven energies and felicities of the
American tongue.


 " The New Yorker "  style, which he
fashioned and honed into an instrument of precision, control, and dry wit,
subsuming conversational latencies, has become a modish American model for
high-profile magazine writing in English everywhere.


As an essayist, White truly divined the purpose of the light essay as
an evocation of  " the small things of the day, the trivial matters of
the heart." 


 where the essay and the short story come closest to
each other, for each deals, in essence, with  " significant
insignificances,"  and each makes a song out of marginalities and
memorabilia, even as each seeks to convey some profound truths.


In his long and delightful essay.


 " The Ring of Time,"  in which White describes the
sheer magic of the circus, and the nostalgia of those visits, the reader is,
along with the writer, rolling, cavorting, freewheeling, and trapezing over
the artifacts of language:  

 

The  gaze, as she peered straight ahead, seemed
to be circular <*> dotted line</*> then time itself began running in circles,
and so the beginning was where the end was, and the two were the same <*>
dotted line</*>.


Everything in her movements, her expression, told you that for her
the ring of time was perfectly formed, changeless, predictable, without
beginning or end, like the ring in which she was traveling at this moment
with the horse that wallowed under her.


And then I slipped back into my trance, and time was circular again-
time, pausing quietly with the rest of us, so as not to disturb the balance
of a performer.  

 

For those who can overhear the echoes from T.S. Eliot and recall
the metaphor of the ring from 17th-century metaphysical poets, an essay of
this kind becomes a treat for the mind. 

 

George Orwell, who was something of a secular visionary and the
conscience of a troubled race, is represented here by his much anthologized
essays such as  " A Hanging,"   " Shooting an
Elephant,"   " Politics and the English Language," 
 " The Moon under Water,"  and  " Why I Write."



These and several similar pieces have come to stay as classic
examples of plate glass and reflexive prose.


The main features of this prose are a controlled, nervious, and
efficient style, a freshness of idiom and metaphor, an organic development
of thought, a concreteness of detail, a precision of statement, and a strong
moral, Protestant vein.


And over the whole exercise presides a fine, subtle, and noble
imagination - - the imagination of  " sincerity and authenticity."



In employing Lionel  terms 
reminded of the fact that the American  great admiration for
Orwell rested, among other things, upon the Orwellian  " No, in
Thunder"  to all shams and hypocrisies, and all cant and casuistry.


No wonder, in  own words,  " the imagination,
like certain wild animals, will not breed in captivity."  

 

From Orwell to James Baldwin is only a leap from color and
continent to a similar sensibility, for despite their different
backgrounds, and situations and their worldview, each of them was
passionately and vigilantly devoted to the idea of truth as he saw it, and
to the search for a corresponding rhetoric and style.


And this is why each voice, in its own context, rings so truly, so
resonantly, and so movingly.


 prose is today widely recognized as a glorious
example of American writing marked by a sense of classical dignity and
vitality, and by a rhetoric of thunder, dream, and prophecy.


The underlying grid of this rhetoric is fed continually by four
distinct, though converging, lines of energy - - Shakespeare, the 
King James Bible  , Negro spirituals, and Harlem slang.


The themes of his essays include abused childhood and street terrors,
racial destiny and existential suffering, problems of identity and
alienation, and moral and linguistic imperialism.


These themes, to be sure, are  common to nearly
all writers of the Harlem Renaissance, but in Baldwin the issues become
invested with a strange visionary force.


Baldwin, the novelist, is often a conscious  " Jamesian"
 in his prose, but Baldwin, the essayist, is more Orwellian in the
final analysis. 

 

From James Baldwin to Martin Luther King, Jr., black American
prose follows a path of spiritual and moral polemic which, in some hands,
rises to a great song of sorrow in clear Biblical accents.


But before I come to King I wish to salute some other talents that
make up the matrix of this insightful anthology: Barbara Tuchman, for whom
history was a creative art, and the historian an artist in his own domain
( see page 39), Lewis Thomas, who writes on American science with such
precision, wit, and eloquence; Doris Lessing, whose African-colonial
background makes her a white crusader committed to human dignity and
heroism; Russell Baker, an American humorist of pure vintage whose
essay  " The Flag"  is a deliciious and delicate satire
reminiscent of Mark Twain; Richard Selzer, who in  " The Pen and the
Scalpel"  ( published in " SPAN " , July 1989)
brings a  experience to bear upon the craft of writing;
Edward Hoagland, who talks of the essay as a wild thing out of the jungle
whose surface  " generates sparks, like a cat of fur"  ; Joan
Didion, who in the opinion of James Dickey is  " the finest woman
prose stylist writing in the English language today"  ; Joyce Carol
Oates, who is emerging as  voice of culture and keeper of
conscience; Alice Walker, who at her best represents black feminine aesthetic
in America in an idiom of great power; and Annie Dillard, whose essays rise
above the din and dust of the native scene to claim her American heritage of
respect for life, and for its evocation of the beautiful, the sacred, and the
heroic. 

 

And, so finally, I come to King-  " every inch a king"
 of poetry and pathos.


His living classic,  " I Have a Dream,"  is
presented as an example of American prose on the peaks.


A most moving and powerful piece, it was written as much out of
the solar plexus as out of a politico-religious vision of austere beauty and
elegance.


Its  repetitive spoken pattern, its
haunting, evangelical rhythm, its urgency and eloquence, its visionary and
striking new phrases, among many of its other virtues, help make a prose
style that comes closest to being a   stilus   .


The Greek word indicates the lapidary aspect of such a prose, for
King uses his rhetoric as an instrument to cut the stones of experience to
proper proportions.


Even more powerful in some ways is his long and great  "
Letter from Birmingham City Jail"  to the ever-pliable elders and
betters of his church. 

 

To conclude, the  natural gaiety and inner
economy account for its undiminished vitality.


As the French word,   essai   , the Latin
  exagium   , and the English  essay 
suggest, it is a genre that continually solicits effort and exertions and
strivings.


To try, to test, to dart forth, to light out - - that, in sum,
constitutes its being and becoming.


The essay, then, is linked to the imagination on the prowl, turning
over any small object, place, or person that may, with luck, yield a
measure of music.  <*> small square</*>

Mullet, Prentice Hall, Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey, 1991, pp. 476,
paperback,
