Questions before us are baffling, and issues around us are  
overwhelming, 


When I start thinking about them, I get taken over by their  
variety and volume, 


And these different strands are woven together, and the emerging  
picture becomes clear and grim, 


And I start wondering, what is happening to us, as individual  
<,> as society, as a nation, 


Crisis seems to have penetrated everywhere, 


Is it political, economic, cultural or the crisis of life  
itself, ? 


We see many young children, begging on streets, and working  
in dangerous conditions, 


We hear many incidents, about young women, being burnt for  
dowry, 


Innocent persons, getting imprisoned in the trap of bonded  
labour, 


And the youth going astray, due to lack of direction, 


We read about many massacres, in cities and villages, 


We know many persons, who exchange their ethics and ideals for  
money, 


We are aware of many cases of bribery and forgery, 


Our attention is often drawn, to scandal in educational  
institutions, the citadels of learning, 


And nothing happens to us, 


Have we lost our sensitivity, the very core of human life, ? 


We preach morality to children, and we talk of values to all,  
but we do not hesitate in compromising, when it comes to personal gain, 


We see nothing wrong in seeking personal, favours, for  
gratification, 


Is this in accordance, with what we say, ? 


And what impact is it going to have on the young generation, who  
get bewildered and confused, by this discrepancy between action and  
preaching, 


Corruption seems to have penetrated, in all spheres of life,  
and worse then that, it seems that we have accepted, that it has come  
to stay, 


Work culture gets adversely affected by this, 


Demands for rights are put forward, without due consideration to  
duties, 


Previleges are sought without fulfilling obligations, 


Consumerism and hedonism dominate our time, 


Pursuit of comfort, mixes get oblivious of the means adopted for  
the same, 


The importance of money, is accepted unchallenged, 


Everything starts getting measured in terms of money, and then  
<,> values are turned in prices, 


People get, to use Henry  expression,  
 Protected by money, learnt by money, dulled by money   
<,,> 


New inventions, advance in technology, and wonders of  
computers have certainly opened new vistas for human beings, 


But  not go in ahead without values and ideals,  
pushes into an age of despair and destruction, 


Emerson had said that  The true test of civilization is,  
not the census, not the size of cities, nor the crops, 


No, but the kind of man, the country turns out , 


Unfortunately today we see, men surrendering their ideals to  
expediency, and yielding their sensitivity to the pressure of power, 


Respect for human value, and constraints on, human greed,  
and lust were never more important, than they are today, 


Gandhi had pointed out, that hankering after riches, forces  
one, to exploitation in some form or other, 


The modern civilization, with its emphasis on materialism,  
and its basis of exploitation of the weak, is equivalent to darkness and  
disease, 


True civilization consists, not in accumulation of commodity,  
but, in a deliberate and voluntary reduction of one, 


Politics, bereft of religion, is a death trap because, it  
kills the soul, 


Unfortunately today we are at such junction in history, where  
the line between good and evil, often gets blurred, and consequently  
the distinction between heroes and villains also often gets blurred, 


The practice of putting, profits before prudence, and the  
instinct of putting " I " before " we ",  
have eroded the foundation of human values, 


If humanity itself is lost, would a human being be a human,  
or a mere robot, ? 


In that case, what about future, ? 


One undoubtedly is in agreement, which the Russian poet Andrei  
Muroyiv when he said, that  I am not interested in the twenty-first  
century, if it will be only robots, 


It can happen but it will be death, 


We will be alive, but dead , 


We start enumerating, the advantages and gains, profits and  
pay-offs, and neglect, human values and human emotions, 


We ignore the highways, and start getting lost, in lanes and  
by-lanes where paths become narrower and narrower, 


As a nation, we are going through rough times, 


Nationalism often becomes synonym, with  factitious   
politics, and this gives boost, to destabilizing and destructive forces  
<,> 


Ugly forces of communalism, fundamentalism, regionalism,  
and terrorism rock the tranquility of the country, 


Instances, of communal riots and political violence provide  
material, for headlines to media, 


Events and happening, in the field of politics, indicate  
clearly that politics, is the game of power, 


The game of ruthless strategies, the game of selfish interest  
<,> where moral norms, and high ideals are pushed aside, and where  
credibility and accountability, become meaningless words, 


Problem of poverty has assumed grave dimension due to illiteracy  
<,> 


Basic needs of food, shelter, and clothing of the people have  
yet to be fulfilled, 


Rising prices, inflation, and unemployment, bring  
unprecedented pressures on the common man, 


Today problems are many and solutions are not simple, 


We have to accept the fact, that ours is a plural society,  
where diversity in religion, caste, community, and language is  
overwhelming, 


This plurality, cannot be hidden under the clock of concensus  
<,> nor can they be    branded   as  
confrontation, 


Aspirations and grievances of various ethnic, religious,  
linguistic, and minority groups demand special attention, to cultural  
ethos and recognition to diversity, 


As the noise over, " Masjid-Mandir ",  
employment and social justice, ethnic diversity and minority rights, is  
getting louder, law and order situation, is worsening, 


The weak and the underprevileged sections of the society still  
suffer from discrimination, 


Here I would like to focus on the status of women, 


Even now, after so many years of Independence, women suffer  
problems, of inequality and discrimination, dependant and domination  
<,> 


Some individual women have achieved, stupendous success in some  
fields such as education and politics, 


The Constitution has granted equality, and some progressive laws  
are enacted, 


But the majority of women are lost in the darkness of ignorance, 


The literacy rate among women, is only thirty-nine point  
forty-two percent, 


The fact to remind, that India is a nation, where people  
belonging to different, religions live and practice, their own way of  
life, 


The Constitution did not establish a common civil code, and the  
personal laws of different communities, remain operative, 


It is unfortunate, that in a democratic and secular state like  
ours, all the women are not on equal footing, 


Women of different, religions and communities suffer under  
oppressive personal laws, 


Traditional norms of behaviour and inequality have taken deep roots  
in our social system, 


Revival of religious fundamentalism, intensifies the threat to  
 equality, 


It is sad to note that social evils like " dedication of  
girls to temple, polygamy ", and " seclusion of women  
", have thrived, in the name of religion, 


There are some laws, which provide protection to women, but  
the cunning and conniving, do not take long to find the loop holes, 


Moreover, the process is long, painful and expensive, 


The question remains, how many women would muster courage and  
resources, to fight discrimination, ? 


Bigamy is still not extinct, 


The provision regarding the age of marriage gets frequently  
violated, 


 access, to rights, of property,  
maintenance, inheritance, divorce, alimony and custody of children  
<,> get limited, 


Many laws, lose their meaning in the absence of proper  
implementation, 


Though it is one of the duties, of an Indian citizen, to  
renounce all practices, derogatory to the dignity of women, women are  
often subjected to atrocity, like grave or physical assault, 


Trade in human flesh is still prevalent, 


Rape victims suffer from tremendous trauma, and damage to their  
personality, 


Crimes against women, continue to rise, 


There were more than six thousand reported, victims of rape in  
nineteen eighty-seven, and more than fifteen hundred dowry deaths,  
including burning, 


The declining sex ratio, is an issue causing grave concern, 


The nineteen ninetey-one census, shows only nine hundred and  
twenty-nine women against, thousand man, 


This is an issue, not just of number but a pointer at our social  
reality, 


Neglect at every stage, is the fate of the women, 


Survival itself becomes difficult, as is evident from the misuse  
of the sex determination test, 


Age specific death rate indicate, higher rates for female  
children, and women upto thirty-five years of age, 


The discrimination against the women in economic arena still exist  
<,,> 


The provisions of labour laws and equal pay for equal work, do  
not reach all women and, provisions are not properly implemented, 


Almost, ninety percent of women workers, are engaged in  
unorganized sector, 


Studies clearly show, that modernisation and mechanisation tend  
to marginalise women in many sectors, 


The fact remains, that there cannot be division of women into  
groups of working women and non-working women, 


Women work, but their work goes unnoticed, 


Invisible hands of women are always at work, but the data  
system with respect to  work is imperfect, 


Estimates of the average hours of unpaid work, done by women  
<,> outside their homes vary from six to seven hours per day, with some  
women working upto ten hours or more, 


Apart from the domestic duty, women are engaged in agricultural  
operation, for an average of twelve hours a day, 


They have to keep themselves and their families alive, 


In rural areas, thirty to thirty-five percent of household,  
are headed by women, still there access to ownership of land, and  
property is negligible, 


Women find it extremely difficult, to enter the male dominated  
field of politics, 


The crucial fact is, that women find themselves being judged  
<,> and often judging themselves by two different standards, 


One standard is of traditional role of the private world, which  
regards her as homebound, nurturing, submissive and emotional, 


The other standard is, of her changed role in the public world  
<,> which expects her to be ambitious, rational, progressive and  
competetive, 


This private public divide bring severe pressures on her, 


Other deterrants in her way are, approach of political parties  
<,> prohibitive election expenses, demands of home, and family, and  
fear of character assassination, 


Still we have a long way to go, 


Democratic notions of equality and liberty, have to percolate  
in her day-to-day life, 


Journey of democracy, is never static or uneventful, 


Today realities are hard and challenges are tough, but we the  
people of India have to give a positive response,

Rs. 40  cr.  for Holiday Inn hotel in Delhi
 


 Need to review bonanza for Lalit Suri 


 By <@AS> MANECK DAVAR {#} 

 

In the capital, there is one identifiable monument to the
rapine of financial institutions and banks.


This edifice was initially the product of illegal largesse, and then
has been constructed brick by brick by public funds wantonly granted - - an
example of how the heads of financial institutions and one bank have
flouted banking norms and pumped in good money after bad to shore up the
financially diseased structure.


This monolith is Lalit  'Sumitomo'  Suri's Holiday Inn
hotel. 

 

Mr. Suri, when he decided to go into the hotel business, roped in
three financial institutions and one bank to help finance his fantasy.


They were S.S. Nadkarni's Industrial Development Bank of India (
IFBI), N. Vaghul's Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation of India (
ICICI) and D.N. Davar's Industrial Finance Corporation of India ( IPCI) and
Premjit Singh's Bank of Baroda ( BoB).


Together, these institutions have advanced over Rs. 40  crores
 worth of finances, on flimsy and doubtful security and even after
the borrower's inability or intransigency in   
repaying   earlier instalments. 

 

This huge sum has been advanced in a period of little more than
three years to Suri's Bharat Hotels which has built the Holiday Inn.


Today, there is a real apprehension, with losses accumulating to Rs.
11.09  crore     up to   March 31,
1989, that the loans advanced are in jeopardy.


There has been an official recommendation by the Public Accounts
Committee ( PAC) of Parliament that the hotel be taken over and publicly
auctioned for breach of contract.


If that happens, all that the institutions will be left with, will be
forks and spoons, pots and pans, cots and mattresses and airconditioners and
lifts.


For all these loans have been advanced, for the most part, against
the movable property of the hotel. 

 

The break-up of the financing provided by the institutions and
Bank of Baroda is as follows:- 

 

- - On November 1, 1985, Rs. 8  crores  is handed
over to Bharat Hotels by a consortium of the three institutions.


Of this, the share of IDBI is Rs. 4  crore  , ICPI Rs.
2  crore  , and ICICI Rs. 2  crore  .


Simultaneously, the agreement provides for a Euro-Dollar loan of
US

$7,630,742 ( Rs. 11.93  crores  as per the balance sheet)
advanced by four banks: Bank of Baroda, Syndicate Bank, Central Bank of
India, and Indian Overseas Bank.


The sums advanced are: Bank of Baroda US

$3,582,215.22, Syndicate US

$2,352,805.04, Central US

$847,859.37, Indian Overseas, US

$847,859.37. 

 

The mortgage is, in this instance, in respect of all movable
immovable properties.


This is the only time that immovable property has been charged.


Why this was not included in subsequent mortgages is explained later.


 

The latest balance sheet shows only Bank of Baroda's
outstandings.


Obviously, the bank has transferred the amounts advanced by the
consortium to itself. 

 

- - On May 15, 1986, within six months of Rs. 21  crore
 being handed over, IFCI sanctioned a term loan of Rs. 3.5 
crore  .


This is under the Project Finance Participation Scheme ( PFPS).


The mortgage is now only on movable property and the short
particulars of this head are repeated verbatim in all subsequent agreements.


 

- - On March 3, 1987, IFCI and IDBI provide for another Rs. one
 crore  in equal proportions.


The mortgage comprises only movable property. 

 

- - On June 8, 1988, the three financial institutions again
seek to bail out Suri.


This time they rush with Rs. 10.38  crore  approx. as
term loans.


The break-up this time is, IDBI Rs. 5,28,35,000, ICICI Rs.
2,44,00,000 and IFCI Rs. 2,65,06,000.


The mortgage, needless to add, is pots and pans, cots and carpets.


 

- - On March 3, 1989, responding to a further SOS from Suri, as
in their own words the borrower is in need of further funds: the trio of
financial institutions provide succour to the tune of another Rs. 4 
crore  .


The lenders themselves have divided this in the ratio of IDBI Rs. 2
 crores  and the other two Rs. one  crore 
each.


The mortgaged items are the same. 

 

In addition to these amounts, the balance sheet of the company
shows a Rs. one  crore  rupee term loan extended by Bank of
Baroda and a cash credit facility of Rs. 1.15  crore  with
Canara Bank    against   hypothecation of
stocks, stores, supplies and book debts. 

 

The items offered as security, reproduced with almost
cyclostyled monotony in all the agreements, read thus:- 

 

  " The whole of the movable properties of the
Borrower, ( Bharat Hotels) including its movable plant and machinery,
machinery spares, tools and accessories, fixtures and fittings, electrical
installations, furnitures, cutleries, crockeries, utensils, vessels,
mattresses, carpets, cots, tables, cars, trucks, jeeps, buses, vehicles,
trollies, calculating machines, refrigerators, air-conditioners, coolers,
modern electrical/ electronic and other appliances, computers, etc. and other
movables, both present and future ( save and except book debts) whether
installed or not and whether now lying loose or in cases or which are now
lying or stores in or about or shall hereafter from time to time during the
continuance of the security of these presents be brought into or upon or
be stored or be in or about all the Borrower's hotel, premises and godowns
wherever the same may be or be held by any part to the order or disposition
of the borrower, or in the course of transit or on high seas or on order, or
delivery howsoever and wheresoever in the possession of the borrower and
either by way of addition or substitution."   


 Continued on page 7 


 Need to review bonanza for Lalit Suri 


 Continued from page 1 

 

This outflow of public finance into the apparently bottomless pit
of Bharat Hotels would never have been sanctioned on an independent appraisal
of merit for the following reasons. 

 

The hotel itself was conceived of an illegality.


The land on which the Holiday Inn was built was leased by the Finance
Ministry to the New Delhi    Municipal  
Corporation ( NDMC) with the specific condition that no sub-lease be created
or the land handed over to any private party for development.


This was, of course, abrogated. 

 

The agreement with NDMC, however, stipulated that the land and
any structure on it could not be sold, disposed of or even mortgaged.


As Suri could not pledge immovable property, the NDMC agreement was
supplemented with two memoranda which allowed the hotel to mortgage
structures on it but not the land.


This was all unearthed by the outgoing PAC chaired by Amal Datta.


 

However, it is a clear legal postulate that no structure can
be mortgaged in isolation of the land it is situated on.


The PAC's draft report is extremely illuminating on this score: 
 " The Committee has asked for the papers relating to the
transactions so as to enable it to obtain the opinion of the
Attorney-General as to whether it is legally permissible to create a mortgage
in such a fashion <*> dotted-line</*> we are practically convinced that it is
not permissible.


However, the financial institutions required repeated prodding to
bring before the Committee the very scanty information and ultimately did
to make sure it was too late to be able to take a legal opinion of the
Attorney-General.


They gave the impression that they were reluctant to have the
matter probed or the legality scrutinised."   

 

This was possibly the reason why after the initial sanction of
Rs. 8  crores  by the three FIs for both movable and immovable
property, the rest of the term loans were all secured by only movable
property. 

 

The Company has been unable to honour its commitments on its
repayment schedule and the payments on some of its loans had to be
rescheduled.


The 1988-89 balance sheet of Bharat Hotels shows only the interest
accrued and due on term loans as Rs. 5.03  crores  .


It must also be born in mind that the company enjoyed a substantial
holiday before the instalments on its loans became due.


For example, the first instalment on a term loan sanctioned by
IFCI of Rs. 3.5  crore  , with the charge created on May
15,1986, was due only on May 15,1988, to be paid in six monthly instalments
right    up to   May 15, 1995. 

 

In the instance of the Bank of Baroda's euro-dollar loans
provided by BOB's London branch, the situation is so piquant, it is almost
a double blow.


According to the stringent requirements of the Bank of England,
the monitoring body in the UK, any loan on which there is a default of two
consecutive payments is classified as non-performing.


This is immediately reported by vigilant auditors and the bank has to
make a provision out of profits for the entire amount of the loan. 

 

Today, the bank has not recovered even the interest on its loans.


It has had to take special permission of the Reserve Bank under
Section 16 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act ( FERA) and is remitting
the interest component from its own funds to its branch in London.


If the bank wants to avoid any adverse reaction from Bank of England,
it will have to remit US

$ 1.977 million ( Rs. 3.3  crore  ) to date.


A large amount has already been remitted on this account. 

 

In fact, an internal note of BOB states that the party has failed
to remit interest on the euro-dollar loan deposit despite several reminders.


The documents are not executed properly and guarantee fees have not
been paid for the past two years.


It is also learnt that    in spite   of
the account classified as sick, a sum of Rs. 2  crore  has
been advanced against the shopping complex.


Legal action is now being contemplated to recover the outstanding.


 

The tangible security offered against these loans is extremely
inadequate to cover the Rs. 45  crore  plus dues of the
company. 

 

On January 1, 1988, when the banks and FIs has already advanced
Rs. 25.5  crore  to the company, the balance sheet showed the
written down value of the plant and machinery, furniture and fixtures and
vehicles at Rs. 16.58  crore  .


At the end of March 1989, the written down value had doubled to Rs.
43.5  crore  .


However, considering the nature of plant and machinery, comprising
mainly airconditioning plants and lifts which have no manufacturing output,
the maximum that can be advanced by banks is about 60-65 per cent.


Thus, the FIs and banks, had they followed norms, could not have
advanced more than around Rs. 30  crore  towards the project.


 

Further, the company exhibits an extremely poor    debt-equity   ratio of 25:1.


This is against 2:1 for a healthy company.


While the debt of Bharat Hotels amounts to Rs. 79.54  crore
 ( loan funds of Rs. 47.60  crore  plus deposits for
sub-licence fee on the shopping centre of Rs. 31.94  crore  )
the equity amounts to only Rs. 3.23  crore  ( shareholder's
funds and reserves totalling Rs. 14.33  crores  minus
carried forward losses of Rs. 11.09  crore  ) . 

 

In the present circumstances of increasing debts, rising losses
and uncertainty over the title of land, the company presents a very poor
investment for FIs. 

 

While the motivation for the financial 
infusion of funds needs to be probed, in order to protect their investment
they would be left with little recourse but to exercise their option to
convert, as stipulated in their agreements, 20 per cent of the loan amounts
aggregating Rs. 26.87  crore  into fully paid equity shares
and assume control of the company. 

 

The financial affairs of Bharat Hotels is symptomatic foremost of
the arbitrary functioning of financial institutions.


The government needs to send clear signals that the heads of FIs are
to strictly function within parameters and not seek to appease political
bosses to nurture prospects of personal advancement.

Big changes in industrial policy: Hegde 

 

<@PR> NEW DELHI {#}, <@DR> Jan. 6 {#}
- - The industrial policy will be changed  " radically,
drastically and substantially"  with special emphasis on
employment generation, poverty alleviation and rural development, the
Planning Commission deputy Chairman, Mr R.K. Hegde, said today, reports <@SR>
UNI {#}. 

 

The changes in the Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 and
subsequent Government statements in this regard would be finalized soon
after wide-ranging discussions with captains of industry. 

 

Briefing reporters on the three-day deliberations of the
whole-time members of the newly-constituted Planning Commission, Mr Hedge
said the draft approach paper on the Eighth Plan ( 1990- ) would
be ready by the end of this month. 

 

Mr Hegde said the approach paper would be drawn up in accordance
with the policies, programmes and priorities of the new Government and the
ideology of the National Front Government. 

 

The commission had worked out a time table for finalizing the
draft approach paper by the end of this month. 

 

Till then the commission would receive the views of various
representative organizations like the Chambers of Commerce and
Industry, since there  " is going to be a radical change" 
in the industrial policy. 

 

The consultation with the captains of industry was to ascertain
whether they were prepared to invest in the priority areas set by the new
Government. 

 

Mr Hegde said the working of the public sector units, particularly
in the spheres of steel, petro-chemicals, fertilizer and power, would be
reviewed.


This exercise would be designed to take  " corrective
action"  and remove weaknesses that had crept into the functioning
of the sector. 

 

Mr Hegde said there was consensus at the three-day meeting on
the need to reduce the number of Centrally-sponsored schemes.


 " We would rather have more and more of  panchayat
 , district and  zilla parishad  - sponsored schemes
than Centrally-sponsored schemes"  , he said. 

 

How drastically the Centrally-sponsored schemes were to be
reduced would be decided by the end of the month, he added. 

 

 He said the  Jawahar Rozgar Yojana  and
 Nehru Rozgar Yojana  would be recast, and their names
would be changed with  " good ones"  .  

 

Mr Hegde said local institutions would have a decisive role in
choosing the kind of employment to be provided to the rural unemployed.


 

There will be direct funding to  panchayat 
institutions but not from the  " Prime Minister to District
Magistrate"  , he said.


The State Governments  " will not be bypassed and we will
function within the federal framework"  .


The funding of the local bodies would be through the State
Governments. 

 

Mr Hegde said after the approach paper was ready, a meeting of
the National Development Council would be called to consider it  




 BUSINESS 


 Displaying success 


 Leather fair may net Rs 200  crore      

 

SOUTH  only annual international fair is
growing  'fairer'  by the year.


This  leather fair in Madras was an impeccable show
indeed - - scores of aesthetically designed cubicles, set in neat rows,
displaying an exhaustive array of goods and machinery.


The presence of a large number of foreigners, both as participants
and visitors, lent the grand event the international dimension. 

 

In terms of sheer size, the fifth India International Leather
Fair, in January, was unprecedented.


From a few hundred square meters in 1985 the display area had gone
up to 6,000 sq. meters.


More than a hundred of the 260 exhibitors were from abroad and this
was proof enough that the Madras fair has gained in importance the world
over. 

 

As in the previous years, the Italians with their sophisticated
machinery and upmarket products dominated the fair.


There were the Germans, the French, the British and the Americans
too, quite a few of them well-known names.


Visitors from 25 countries attended the fair and there were 20
official business delegations from abroad. 

 

A quick survey showed that nearly 15,000 business visitors were
registered on the first three days of the fair.


New business worth several  crores  of rupees was
struck at the fair.


Moreover the fair gave an opportunity to Indian exporters to
establish contacts with many foreign buyers. 

 

According to K.V. Rajan, chief general manager of Trade Fair
Authority of India, the organisers of the fair, participants of last  fair had reported business worth Rs 100  crore  as
a direct result of the fair.


 " This year it could be in the region of Rs 200  crore
 , "  he says. 

 

One criticism that has been levelled against the fair right from
its inception is that it is largely import-oriented.


The large turnout of machinery and equipment manufacturers from
abroad with their imposing gadgets has always kept the domestic industry
under their shadow, it is said.


Proponents of this criticism point to the number of import deals
struck at the fair, which are more than the export inquiries, as proof. 

 

Officials of the Trade Fair Authority of India and the Council of
Leather Exports ( CLE) justify that the import slant is    perfectly   in tune with the multi-faceted objective of the
fair.


M.M. Hashim, chairman of CLE, points out that the Indian leather
industry needs most urgently large-scale modernisation of its existing
production facilities to enable it to compete effectively in the highly
sophisticated international market.


  " Upgrading of technology will enhance the quality of the
products as also cut back on manufacturing costs.


Quality and price are the two significant factors that will
determine  future in the world market, "   he
feels. 

 

It is true that, despite the  impressive gains
made on the leather export front in the last few years, its share in the
total global imports has remained at a woefully negligible figure of less
than two per cent.


As per  projections,  exports should
reach five per cent of world imports by the turn of the century.


Expansion of the production base with a massive dose of modernisation
is the only way to achieve this.


 exports now stand at Rs 2,000  crore 
a year. 

 

In this context, the fair provides an excellent opportunity for
domestic entrepreneurs to get first-hand knowledge of the advances made in
the leather technology field.


This apart, small-scale manufacturers, who form 75 per cent of the
domestic cartel and who can ill-afford to go abroad, are immensely benefited
by the fair. 

 

A survey of the business inquiries at this  fair
has revealed that nearly half of the orders made were for exports.


The survey done by TFAI with assistance from NIIT of Delhi shows that
the percentage of exporters among the total business visitors was 37.37
whereas it is only 10.93 for importers. 

 

However TFAI has a problem: how to accommodate the growing number
of participants, year after year.


Space at Rajaji Hall in Madras is limited.


There was speculation that the fair may be shifted to Delhi from next
year onwards if a larger and permanent site could not be found in Madras.


But the rumours have now been scotched with the Union commerce
ministry announcing that the fair will continue to be held in Madras
considering its importance in the leather map of the country.


Besides, an overwhelmingly large number of participants, both
domestic and overseas, have expressed their preference for the city, with its
informal atmosphere and distinctive cultural ambience, to any other location.


While next  fair has been tentatively fixed to be held
at Rajaji Hall, TFAI has renewed its efforts to get a larger and permanent
site allocated by the Tamil Nadu government. 


 - - <@AS> JOS ALAPPAT {#}  




 MUSIC 


  L.  east-west fusion  


 Strings of success   

 

East is east and west is west; and never shall the twain meet.


Maybe.


But the Kipling cliche dissolves delightfully in the musical magic of
the master fusionist from Madras, L. Subramaniam.


Appropriately enough, the man who has blended the melody and rhythm
of his native idiom with the harmonic richness of European classical music
was the star of orchestral evening organised by the Indian Centre for
Cultural research in New  Siri Fort auditorium on East  republic day. 

 

The inspired violinist who has performed with legends like
Yehudi Menuhin, Zubin Mehta, Bismillah Khan and Ravi Shankar would have
been hunching over the sick and writing out prescriptions but for the
advice of the revered Carnatic vocalist Chembai Vaidyanath Bhagavathar.


Chembai told him:   " I have known and sung with five
generations of violinists, but none like you.


What are you going to do with an MBBS degree? Take my word, one day
you would become the king of violin."   

 

He did and became the first Indian violinist to have performed at
the Bolshoi Theatre, the Lincoln Centre, the Royal Albert Hall, and the
Champs Elysees Theatre.


The orchestral piece,  Fantasy on Vedic Chants  , he
composed when his mother expired has been performed all over the world
including at the famous Tchaikovsky Hall in Moscow by the USSR-TV Radio
Symphony Orchestra conducted by Vladimir Fedoseyov.


 The Fantasy, Turbulence  and  Shantipriya  proved
to be instant hits.


Besides, he composed the music for Mira  film 
Salam Bombay  and was the music    adviser 
 for Peter  stage production  Mahabharata  .


He has produced about 50 records including a five-volume 
Anthology of Indian Music  for Radio France. 

 

  Fantasy Without Limits  , one of
the first east-west albums released in the US, was selected one of the best
albums of the year.


 Blossom  won the Spring Journal Award in Japan.


Another milestone is  Conversations  , his album with
veteran violinist Stephane Grappelli which also featured the well-known Joe
Sample. 

 

  " I am very lucky to have been born in a musical
family.


My forefathers belonged to Alleppey, Kerala; my grandfather was a
boat manager.


And my mother also hails from Kerala,"   says
Subramaniam. 

 

 father Prof. Lakshminarayana, a violin
teacher, wanted to groom him as a vocalist.


Two-year-old  'Subbu'  would imitate the tunes hummed
by Lakshminarayana.


But  dream was shattered when
Subramaniam contracted diphtheria.


However, not losing heart, Lakshminarayana opened his 
eyes to the world of musical instruments.


First it was the harmonium: by age five Subramaniam took the bow and
at the age of six made his debut. 

 

The family moved to Jaffna, Sri Lanka, when Lakshminarayana got a
job in the Jaffna College, and later to Colombo.


In 1958 when Tamils of Indian origin were being killed, the family
migrated to Madras and settled down in Royapettah.


 " We had to leave all our belongings in Colombo and landed in
Madras with just the clothes we wore,"  says Subramaniam.


Lakshminarayana then started a troupe which launched  career. 

 

Even as a student of Madras Medical College, Subramaniam used to
accompany the leading Carnatic vocalists.


It was then that he came into contact with Chembai.


  " It was Chembai Mama who gave me encouragement to become
a solo violinist.


As he predicted, I have never earned a single rupee by writing a
medical prescription to date,"   says Subramaniam. 

 

  " While I was attending the medical course I asked
the university authorities to allow me to pursue a music course at the
same time.


But their rules did not allow me to do so.


Later, after completing MBBS, I approached them again.


This time they said that I had to undergo the whole process of
college studies and the shortest time they specified to earn a degree in
music was six years."   

 

He then sent an application to the California Institute of Arts
along with a recorded tape of his music.


Meanwhile, a visiting professor from Ithaca College, Inar Holmes
offered him admission to the Ithaca College on condition that he join his
troupe which had performed all over the world.


Concurrently, the California institute offered him admission
straightaway to the MA course.


Subramaniam went to California, completed his two-year MA course
in nine months, headed the department of South Indian Music till 1976, when
he quit  " because I started performing in so many places that it
became difficult for me to do justice to teaching"  . 

 

The westerners in the seventies, believed that the Indian
violin, performed by half-nude men sitting on the floor, was nothing but a
folk instrument.


To them only  tabla  and  sarod  were
Indian classical instruments.


Subramaniam, in an effort to change this attitude, related
Bach and baroque music to Indian music.


That, now everyone concedes, has broken down the east-west
barrier in violin music. 


 - - <@AS> DEVIKA RANI {#}

MATHEMATICS       

 

  MANY   laymen regard infinity
as a kind of number larger than all numbers, but infinity is not a number at
all.


It is a  concept,  the name of which is derived from the
Latin word   infinitus   meaning without limit.


It would not be an exaggeration to state that mathematics cannot
exist without the notion of infinity, because one comes across the
infinite in mathematics at almost every turn; there are infinite natural
numbers 1, 2, 3, 4 <*> dotted line</*>, there is an infinity of fractions
between any two integers such as 0 and 1; numbers like 1/3, <*> square-root
</*>  2 and <*> pie </*> have an infinite decimal
expansion; there is an infinity of geometrical points in any line,
straight or curved, and so on.


As the great German mathematician, David Hilbert ( 1862-1943)
rightly put it,  " Mathematics is the science of infinity."
 

 

The story of infinity begins with the ancient Greeks, who were
among the first to recognize infinity as a central issue in mathematics and
to study its mysteries.


It is a story of many fascinating paradoxes and seemingly absurd
situations which have baffled mathematicians for well over 2,000 years.


With their penchant for logical rigour, the ancient Greeks naturally
had a deep-rooted suspicion of the infinite and tried to avoid its use at
any cost, thereby hindering the development of mathematics.


Under the influence of Greek thought, infinity was for a long time
regarded as the   enfant terrible   of
mathematics.


Even the great Galileo suggested banning its use in  mathematical discourse. 

 

The ancient  fear of infinity was prompted to a
large extent by the famous paradoxes of Zeno, a Greek philosopher who lived
in Elea in the fifth century BC and who is said to have been instructor to
Socrates.


Zeno was investigating the question as to whether finite magnitudes (
of distance and time) are infinitely divisible.


He attempted to show that they are not, as otherwise all motion would
be impossible! 

 

In his first paradox, known as the paradox of the runner, Zeno
argued that in order for a runner to move from one place to another, say, 1
km away, he must first cover half the distance between the two places, then
half of the remaining distance, then half of what remains next, and so on (
Fig.1).


If we assume that distance could be infinitely subdivided, then
this halving process continues   ad infinitum  
because, regardless of how little distance remains to be crossed, it can
still be halved.


The distance in kilometres to be covered by the runner may be
represented by the sum of an infinite series ( 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 +
1/32 ) .


Since this would require an infinite number of steps, Zeno argued
that the winner would never reach his destination!


He may get arbitrarily close but he would never really get there.


 

Worse, it would seem that the runner cannot even begin!


Employing a similar argument, it is seen that to go from one place to
another, the runner must first cover half the distance, to go half the
distance, he must first go one-fourth; to go one-fourth he must first go
one-eighth and so on.


Again, the halves from an infinite sequence.


So how does he get started? 

 

In  second paradox, known as the paradox of
Achilles and the tortoise, the swift-footed Achilles races the slow-moving
tortoise, giving the latter a head start of 100 m.


If we suppose that Achilles can run 10 times as fast as the
tortoise, then by the time Achilles covers 100 m, the tortoise would have
moved forward by 10 m.


By the time Achilles covers 10 m, the tortoise is 1 m further on.


By the time Achilles covers this 1 m, the tortoise is 1/10 m ahead,
and so on ( Fig.2).


( We are again assuming here that distance can be infinitely
sub-divided.)


The distance Achilles must travel to be level with the tortoise is
given by the sum of the infinite series ( 100 + 10 + 1 + 1/10 <*> dotted
line</*> ) .


The  conclusion is that Achilles will never be able
to catch up with the tortoise; always during the time it takes Achilles  to reach its last position, the tortoise would have
edged a little forward. 

 

Of course, Zeno knew fully well that both these conclusions were
absurd, but if one followed his line of argument, the conclusions seemed
inescapable.


Should we therefore infer that space and time are not infinitely
divisible and that an indivisible unit, an  ` atom'  of space
or time, would ultimately be reached?


 other two paradoxes, namely, the paradox of the arrow
and the paradox of the stadium, also state that space and time can only be
subdivided a definite amount.


Thus the four paradoxes, taken together, seemed to show that space
and time are neither continuous nor discrete.


Obviously, something was wrong somewhere. 

 

 paradoxes had to wait another 20 centuries
before they could be resolved, which was possible only with the formulation
of the concept of the <quote > ` limit'  of a convergent infinite   series.


Simply because a series has an infinite number of terms, it does not
mean that its sum must always be infinite.


It is possible for certain types of infinite series to converge to a
finite limit or sum - - a fact which the ancient Greeks did not accept.


Once this fact is accepted, we can assume space and time to be
infinitely divisible and the resulting paradoxes can be easily explained
away. 

 

For example, the infinite series ( 100 + 10 + 1 + 1/10 + <*>
dotted line</*> ) which appeared in  paradox of Achilles and
the tortoise, is known to converge to the limit 111.1111 <*> dotted line</*>
or 111 1/9; that is, as the number of added terms increases to infinity, the
sum of the series approaches 1/9 as its limit.


The paradox is therefore resolved by observing that Achilles will
overtake the tortoise after he has covered a distance of exactly 111 1/9 m
from his starting point. 

 

The resolution of  paradox of the runner is a
little more subtle.


Stating that the runner will never reach his destination amounts
to saying that he will take  infinite  time to cover the
distance.


So, to resolve the paradox we have to simply show that the runner
will reach the end-point after a  finite lapse of time  .


Now, the series ( 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 + <*> dotted line</*> ) ,
representing the distance to be covered by the runner, is known to converge
to the limit 1.


If we assume that the runner maintains a steady speed, the time
intervals it takes him to cover these distances will also follow the
same series and will converge to a finite limit.


In other words, the runner will cover the entire distance in a finite
span of time.


( It must be borne in mind that many infinite series diverge, the
simplest example being the sum of all natural numbers 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + <*>
dotted line</*> ) .  

 

If the concept of limit of infinite series helped resolve one set
of paradoxes, it posed new ones - - paradoxes which puzzled mathematicians
of the 17th and 18th centuries in much the same way as 
paradoxes had puzzled Greek philosophers.


Consider, for example, the Grandi series 1-1 + 1-1 + 1-1 + <*> dotted
line</*> 

 

Representing the series as S, we may write :


S = ( 1-1) + ( 1-1) + ( 1-1) + <*> dotted line</*> = 0 + 0 + 0 + <*>
dotted line</*> = 0


But we can also represent S as, S = 1 + ( - 1+1) + ( - 1+1) + ( -
1+1) + <*> dotted line</*> = 1 + 0 + 0 + 0 <*> dotted line</*> = 1 

 

Grandi discovered this series in 1703 and claimed that God must
have used a technique based on this series in order to create something from
nothing, and got the world going. 

 

It is possible to manipulate the Grandi series yet another way :


S = 1 - ( 1-1 + 1-1 + 1-1 + <*> dotted line</*> ) = 1-S


Therefore, 2S = 1, or S = 1/2. 

 

Which is the real limit of the Grandi series: 0, 1 or 1/2 ?


Surprisingly, none of these is the answer, for the Grandi series does
not converge at all; it is a divergent series. 

 

Consider the infinite series of the reciprocals of natural
numbers, with the signs alternating.


It is known to converge to the natural logarithm of 2 ( written in
2 ) . 


1/1 - 1/2 + 1/3 - 1/4 + 1/5 - 1/6 + 1/7 - 1/8 + <*> dotted line</*> =
In 2


If we multiply both sides of this equation by 1/2, we get: 1/2 -
1/4 + 1/6 - 1/8 + <*> dotted line</*> = 1/2 In 2  


We now add the two series, term by term vertically.


1/1 + 1/3 - 1/2 + 1/5 + 1/7 - 1/4 + <*> dotted line</*> = 3/2 In 2

 

The last series is simply a rearrangement of the first, yet
its sum is 3/2 of the sum of the original series! 

 

Now, in our ordinary finite calculations, rearrangement of the
order of the terms does not affect the value of the sum.


Thus 1+2+3 = 2+1+3 = 3+2+1.


Shouldn't this rule apply to the sum of an infinite number of terms
as well?


Our intuition seems to say yes, but then it would lead to the absurd
result 1= 3/2.


We must, therefore, conclude that the two infinite sereis are not the
same and that in respect of an infinite series, rearrangement of the terms
may  sometimes alter the sum. 

 

We get the first hint here that the ordinary rules of
arithmetic, always valid for finite calculations, may break down in the realm
of the infinite.


In an infinite series, rearrangement of the terms may, under certain
conditions, not only affect the limit to which the series converges, it may
even change a convergent series into a divergent one. 

 

The man who succeeded in taming the mathematical monster of
infinity and in placing it on a sound logical footing was the Russian-born
German mathematician Georg Cantor ( 1845-1918 ) .


In a series of highly original papers published between 1874 and
1897, Cantor laid the foundations of a new  ` arithmetic of infinity'
 .


His results were based on two very simple concepts; that of a set
and a one-to-one correspondence. 

 

Until  time, mathematicians held the view that
the infinite had only a potential existence and that there was no actual ( or
completed) infinite.


For example, mathematicians would say that the collection of natural
numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, <*> dotted line</*> is potentially infinite because
every number can be succeeded by an even larger number, but they would
deny that the collection is actually infinite since it does not exist as one
finished thing.


Cantor made a departure from this well established view by accepting
the actual infinite as a full-fledged mathematical entity and by insisting
that infinite aggregates must be regarded as a  totality  , as an
object which our mind should conceive of as a whole.


His concept of a set, and of an infinite set in particular, came in
handy in this regard. 

 

What is a set?


A set is any collection of objects, physical or mathematical.


Cantor himself defined a set as  " a many which allows itself
to be regarded as a one." 


Sets may be either finite ( like the set of letters of the English
alphabet ) or infinite ( like the set of all natural numbers, the set of all
points on a given line etc. ) .


A subset is any collection of elements taken from the original
set and regarded as a new set.


Thus the set ( a, b, c, d ) is a subset of the set of the letters of
the English alphabet.


Similarly, the set of all even numbers and the set of all prime
numbers are subsets of the set of all natural numbers. 

 

The cocnept of a cardinal number is basic to the theory of sets.


It is a measure of the size of a set, that is, the number of elements
a set contains.


For example, the cardinal of the set S = ( a, b, c, d ) is 4.


How do we specify the cardinal of an infinite set?


For this, we would need an infinite number. 

 

Cantor employed the concept of a one-to-one correspondence to
find out whether two sets, finite or infinite, are of the same size or
different.


It is not necessary, he said, that we should be able to  count
 the number of elements in two different sets in order to say which set
is larger.


( Of course, in case of infinite sets such counting is
impossible.)


We can simply match the elements of the two sets on a one-to-one
basis; if there is an exact matching, we say that the two sets are equivalent
or have the same cardinal; if, however, such an exact matching is not
possible, and in one of the sets some unpaired elements are left, we
say that this set is larger ( that is, it has a bigger cardinal) than the
other. 

 

Now, there was nothing new about the principle of 1:1 matching.


Both Galileo and the 17th century German scholar Leibnitz had
employed it about two centuries earlier and they had  
arrived at the  ` absurd'  conclusion that the infinity of
natural numbers is just as large as the infinity of perfect squares or the
infinity of even numbers.


Cantor first set about resolving these two paradoxes.


He made the bold assertion that since an infinite set can be matched
with its own subset on a 1:1 basis, the two are in fact equal, and if this
result contradicts the maxim,  ` the whole is greater than the part'
 , then the fault lies only with the maxim.


This maxim, Cantor said, is true of finite sets only; in the world
of the infinite  ` a part is equal to the whole'  .


In fact, he seized upon this strange property as the definition of
an infinite set:  ` A set S is said to be infinite if it can be
matched one to one with a subset of itself; in the contrary case, S is said
to be finite.' 


Here the infinite is defined positively, and it is the finite set
that is characterized negatively ( as one that is not infinite ) .


Thus Cantor made a virtue out of what Galileo and Leibnitz regarded
as a vice.

 Group Superannuation Scheme - - New  Annuity
Plan with Return of Capital Plus  Group Pension Terminal
Bonus on Death  <*> line from left to right</*> 


K.S. VENKATACHALAM, Dy. General Manager ( P & A ) , J.K. Synthetics
Ltd., Kanpur.

 

  THE   Life Insurance
Corporation of  Group Superannuation Scheme is an instrument
for providing annuity to the employees or their dependants at the time of
superannuation, retirement or death, as the case may be.


The annuity is paid from the moneys contributed by the employer to the
fund during the service span of an employee.


Most of the well reputed companies in India have their own approved
superannuation fund, and the sums contributed to the fund, on behalf of
employees, together with accumulated interest, are utilised for purchasing an
annuity from " LIC " , at the time of retirement or death of
each employee.


The main object of creating a superannuation fund is to provide for a
regular income in the form of annuity to the employees after their retirement
from the service. 

 

Various annuity plans of " LIC " have come up for
criticism as the annuity paid to the employees at the time of superannuation,
retirement, as the case may be, is so meagre and inadequate that such amount
paid work out to a bare 11 per cent interest on the total corpus accumulated
from the sums contributed by the employer.


The " LIC " , by taking advantage of mandatory
provisions of rules 89 and 91 of the Income-tax Rules, which allows
commutation of annuity to the extent of one third, where an employee receives
gratuity, and one half in other cases, appropriates, the balance amount,
i.e., 66.66 per cent or 50 per cent, as the case may be.


Moreover, the annuity paid to the employees also ceases after a
specified guaranteed period.


If the employers are allowed to create their own funds and invest
similar amount in safe securities like " NSS, " "
NSC, " bank deposits, " UTI " , etc., the principal
amount is not only secured but the return on investment in such securities
would be far higher than what is offered under the annuity plans of "
LIC " . 

 

The LIC has recently introduced a new annuity plan to overcome
many of the shortcomings of its earlier annuity plans.


The new annuity plan provides for return of capital to the nominee /
beneficiary of the employee at the time of death.


This provision was not there in its earlier schemes.


An attempt has been made in this article to compare the benefits
offered under the new annuity plan which guarantees payment of annuity for a
specified period and life thereafter with other annuity plans.


A comparison has also been made on the rate of return on sums
invested in the new annuity plan and  " ` Jeevan Dhara'
"  , as it is felt that such comparison would be more
meaningful as both are deferred annuity schemes administered by " LIC
" .


Moreover, the contribution under  " ` Jeevan Dhara'
"  would qualify for deduction upto Rs. 40,000 from the
gross income of an employee under section 80 CCA of the Income-tax Act. 


 SUPERANNUATION FUND 

 

The objective of the superannuation fund is to provide for
annuity to the employees and their dependants on superannuation, death or
retirement as the case may be.


The sums contributed by the employers to the fund, during the service
tenure of the employee, gets accumulated together with interest and is
utilised by LIC for purchasing an annuity policy.


Any other investments, other than Group Superannuation Scheme of
" LIC " , would not receive the approval of the Commissioner
of Income tax, and will also not qualify for deduction on business
expenditure under section 36 of the Income-tax Act. 

 

The mandatory provisions of rule 89 of the Income-tax Rules make
it obligatory for an employer to constitute a trust for payment of annuity
by:


(  1  ) entering into a scheme with " LIC
" established under the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 ( 32 of ]
956 ) ; or


(  2  ) accumulate the contribution in respect of each
beneficiary / nominee and purchase an annuity from " LIC "
at the time of retirement or death of each employee. 

 

Rule 90 of the Income-tax Rules, 1962, allows for commutation of
annuity, provided such commutation of annuity does not exceed: ( a) in case
where an employee receives any gratuity, the commuted value of one-third of
the annuity which is normally entitled to receive; and ( b) in any other
case, the commuted value of one-half of such annuity. 

 

Such commuted value of annuity being determined having regard to
the age of the recipient, the state of his health, the rate of interest and
officially recognised tables of mortality.


The commuted value of annuity, as specified in rule 90, is exempt
from the income tax, and only payment of annuity made to the employee or his
dependants are treated as salary income for the purposes of tax. 

 

The Life Insurance Corporation of India offers two types of
superannuation plans: 


 1.  Money purchase scheme  

 

The rate of contribution payable by the employers in respect of
its employees it decided in advance in relation to his salary.


As per the present provision of the Income tax Rules, such rate of
contribution cannot exceed 15 per cent of the salary, if the  contribution to provident fund is equivalent to 10 per cent of the  salary.


The total contribution made by an employer towards superannuation and
recognised provident fund cannot exceed 25 per cent of the  salary.


The contribution made by the employer is utilised by " LIC
" to secure appropriate pension. 


 2.  Benefit purchase scheme  

 

The amount of annuity is invested by the employer in advance  in relation to the salary by an employee in the year
of retirement or the average salary drawn in the last 3 or 5 years, prior to
retirement.


For example, 2 per cent of the annual salary for each year of
service, subject to a maximum of 60 per cent of the salary.


LIC will determine the premium payable with respect to the employees.


 

The employee has also the option to elect any one of the
following types of annuities:


(  1  ) Annuity payable throughout his life time;


(  2  )


Annuity payable during his life time, but also guaranteed for a
specific minimum number of years ( 5, 10 & 15 years ) .


If he dies during the guaranteed period, the annuity will continue to
be paid to his beneficiary for remaining part of the period;


(  3  ) Annuity is payable throughout his life time
with death benefit equivalent to purchase price along with " GPT
" Bonus;


(  4  )


Annuity payable during the joint life time of the employee and his
wife, and continue thereafter during the life time of the survival: and


(  5  )


In the event of cessation of service or death of a member while in
service, prior to superannuation age, the moneys standing to the credit of
the employee would be utilised to provide pension to him or to his
beneficiary, as the case maybe. 


  JEEVAN DHARA  

 

The Life Insurance Corporation of India introduced a new
financial instrument known as   " " Jeevan Dhara"
"   for ensuring regular payment of annuity to persons
at the time of their retirement.


" Jeevan Dhara " offers the following additional
benefits:


- - Attractive annuity rates;


- - Enhancement of   ` GIVE'   ( Gross
Insurance Value Element) at the time of verifying by way of bonus which
correspondingly increases the annuity; and


- - On death after annuity payment commences, enhanced  GIVE
 with an additional lump sum bonus is payable to the heirs. 


  COMPARATIVE STUDY  

 

For the purposes of this study, the rate of return under the  new annuity plan has been compared with  annuity plan guaranteed for 15 years certain and life
thereafter and " Jeevan Dhara " . 


  ASSUMPTIONS  

 

The following assumptions are made for the purposes of comparing
the rate of return under the Group Superannuation Scheme and " Jeevan
Dhara " :


( a) The normal date of retirement has been taken as 55 years in both
Group Superannuation Scheme and " Jeevan Dhara " .


The rate of contribution, which is limited to 15 per cent of the  annual salary as provided in Rule 88 of the Income-tax Rules,
have been pre-determined till the age of retirement of an employee;


( b) An employee receives gratuity at the time of his retirement; and


( c) An employee commutes his/her annuity at the time of retirement,
as such commutation is not subject to income-tax. 


  NEW ANNUITY PLAN v. ANNUITY GUARANTEED FOR 15 YEARS
CERTAIN AND LIFE THEREAFTER  

 

It will be seen from the table  ( published on page 946 )
 that an employee entering the scheme at the age of 25 years on a salary
of Rs. 6000 per month, the cash accumulation under the 15 years scheme, on
contribution remitted @ 15 per cent of salary for a deferment period of 30
years would be Rs. 20,86,492.


The employee would also be eligible to commute one-third of the cash
accumulation standing to his credit at the time of retirement.


The annuity payable, if an employee commutes one-third of his
annuity, would be Rs. 13,395 per month guaranteed for a period of 15 years
and life thereafter.


However, if an employee dies, say, at the age of 65 years, his / her
beneficiary / nominee would receive annuity only for the balance period of 5
years under this plan, and thereafter, the payment of annuity will cease.


Thus, the sums receivable in the event of death of an employee would
work out to Rs. 14,99,197 ( annuity of Rs. 8,03,700 calculated @ Rs. 13,395
per month for the balance period of 5 years plus commuted value of annuity
amounting to Rs. 6,95,497.


In other words, under the scheme, " LIC " would be
appropriating Rs. 5,87,395 otherwise would have been legally payable to the
nominee / beneficiary of the employee.


At all age and income levels, there is a loss of capital amounting to
 lacs  of rupees under this plan. 

 

In the new annuity plan, the sums receivable in the event of
death of an employee would be Rs. 13,90,995, if an employee commutes his
annuity at the time of retirement.


The total sums receivable on account of commutation of annuity and
the sums receivable by the legal heirs would be Rs. 20,86,492 as against Rs.
6,95,497 ( commuted value of annuity) offered under the 15 years scheme.


There is, thus, a net gain of Rs. 13,90,995 in the new annuity plan.


It will be seen from the table that for all age and income levels,
the sum receivable under the new plan is higher compared to the annuity plan
guaranteed for 15 years certain and life thereafter.


This is primarily because of the provision of full return of capital
under the new annuity plan.


In the annuity plan for 15 years certain and life thereafter, 66.66
per cent or 50 per cent of the capital, as the case may be, is appropriated
by " LIC " by virtue of mandatory provisions of rules 89 and
91 of the Income tax Rules. 

 

In the example quoted above, the annuity payable under the new
plan would be Rs. 12,096 per month as against Rs. 13,395 per month in 15
years plan, i.e., a net loss of annuity amounting to Rs. 1299 per month.


Although, lot of important features have been introduced under the
new annuity plan like return of capital with terminal bonus in the event of
death of an employee, there appears to be a considerable reduction in the
matter of payment of annuity to the employees as compared to the 15 years
guaranteed scheme. 


  NEW ANNUITY PLAN v JEEVAN DHARA  

 

The rate of return on sums invested in  " Jeevan
Dhara "  is comparatively higher to the return offered under
the new annuity plan.


For example, for an employee entering the scheme at the age of 25 on
a salary of Rs. 6,000 per month, the payment of annuity at the end of
deferment period in " Jeevan Dhara " would be Rs. 22,686 per
month as against Rs. 19,051 per month ( annuity plus interest on commuted
value of annuity ) under the new annuity plan; a net gain of Rs. 3,635 per
month in " Jeevan Dhara "  policy.


Similarly, the sums receivable by the nominee / beneficiary in the
event of death of an employee under " Jeevan Dhara " would
be Rs. 22,68,611 as against Rs. 20,86,492 under the new annuity plan: a net
gain of Rs. 1,81,690.


It will be seen from the table that for all age and income levels,
the sums receivable under the new plan is much less compared to "
Jeevan Dhara " .


Similarly, there is also a reduction in the payment of annuity for
all age and income levels, as compared to annuity offered under "
Jeevan Dhara " .


The only drawback in the " Jeevan Dhara " policy is
that there is no provision for commutation of annuity, which is available in
the new annuity plan.

The M.A. Course in entire English will consist of eight Papers of
which five will be core Papers and the remaining three electives.


There would be five groups of electives subdivided into 2 subgroups
( A) of two papers and ( B) of one paper.


Of these five groups, a student may select any one.


From the group so selected the student may choose either all the three
Papers or Paper-IV & VII from sub-group A, and any one elective as Paper-VIII
from sub-group B. 

 

The objective of the core literature Papers is to provide the
student with an adequate knowledge of the tradition of English Literature and
respond independently to literary works; and the objective of the core
language paper is to provide for an advanced study of the structure and
function of Modern English with a view to sharpening the 
language sense.

1. English Poetry

five elective groups.

And two elective papers i.e. paper-VII from column A of electives
from the same group from which Paper-IV was offered in M.A. Part-I and any
