EDITORIAL    <*> five blank lines</*>



 DISQUIETING FISCAL SCENARIO  <*> four blank lines</*>  

 

IN its Report on Currency and Finance for 1989-90, the Reserve
Bank of India has forecast a higher deficit in the current year and has
called for adjustments to reduce the serious fiscal imbalance in order to
foster growth with stability.


The forecast is based on an assessment of the economy in which the
actual deficit at the end of March, 1991 would turn out to be larger than
what was budgeted.


The actual budget deficit of the Union Government was Rs. 13,000
crores on November 30 last as compared to Rs. 13,082 crores in the
corresponding period of 1989.


The budget deficit as on January 11, 1991 was still higher at Rs.
15.093 crores.


The Indian Economy has entered a period of growth stagnation on the
one hand and inflation on the other.


The agricultural sector has been relatively better for the past three
sessions - - thanks to good monsoons - - but it is not significant enough to
push the economy to a higher level of growth, largely because of decline in
growth that has set in the industrial sector.


The good performance of agriculture has been largely offset by the
setback in the industrial sector especially in 1990-91. 

 

The composite index of six infrastructure industries e.g. power,
petroleum, crude, refinery products, saleable steel, coal and cement,
recorded a  " sharp deceleration"  in the growth rate to
3.5 % in the current year as compared to 6.5 % in the comparable period of
the preceding year.


While output in absolute terms may have increased, it has fallen
short of the targets set.


The RBI report has attributed the rise in growth rates both in the
general index of industrial production and in the manufacturing sector in the
first seven months to the low base of the comparable period of the previous
year. 

 

The  " depressing performance"  of the
infrastructure industries as well as the lower availability of imported raw
materials and components consequent on the balance of payments crisis will
have an adverse impact on the overall industrial production in the current
year.


The anticipated growth rate of industrial output at around 6 to 7
percent in the current year as compared to 8.6 percent in 1989-90 reflects a
significant downturn and thus the overall performance of the economy is a
mixed one. 

 

While the agricultural sector scenario is encouraging, with the
exceptionally good South-West monsoon in 1990, leading to a record Kharif
foodgrain output of about 102 million tonnes, as against the target of 95
million tonnes, prospects for 1991-92 would depend as much on favourable
weather as on better management of supply of inputs and remunerative prices.


The prospects for commercial crops, with the exception of groundnut,
have also been satisfactory.


But the country needs to do more to increase oilseeds production to
reduce the drain on foreign exchange through imports of edible oils and to
lower the domestic prices of this essential commodity. 

 

The stagnation in industrial sector is accompanied by high prices
which do not induce producers to improve the supplies of goods and services.


From all directions there is indication of possible worsening of the
price situation.


Meanwhile, the trade gap is widening and net inflows of foreign
currency deposits are declining.


With the continuing decline in foreign exchange reserves, essential
imports to keep the wheels of industry moving are difficult to provide for.


 

The rate of inflation as measured by the wholesale price index is
likely to touch 13 percent by the end of the year ( March, 1991 ) .


One way to control inflation would be by mopping up excess liquidity
in the economy through fiscal measures and by controlling non-productive
expenditure.


Resources invested on creating productive assets must start giving
returns by accelerating the production process.


The infrastructure industries should be given special attention so
that industrial growth is enabled to regain its lost momentum. 

 

In overcoming the current stagnation and in controlling
inflation hard decisions are called for.


There will have to be incentives to produce more and export more and
for achieving this objective, resources will have to be directed to
productive purposes.


All this cannot be done through budgetary measures alone.


Some clearcut policy initiatives will be necessary, though in
siphoning off excess liquidity fiscal and monetary policies will come handy.


 

Now that a full-fledged budget is no to be presented and instead
a vote on account will be taken, a period of uncertainty is ahead and the
tasks of fiscal correction and launching of the Eighth Plan with a clear
demarcation of the roles of the public and the private sectors have taken
a back seat, at any rate for the present. 

 


  Method of Accounting  Under Companies
Act, 1956  and Income-Tax Act, 1961   


P.S. JOSHI  *  <*> line from left to right</*>  <*> line from left to
right</*>  

 

  THE   amendment to Section 209
of the  Companies Act, 1956  requires the companies to follow
accrual basis and double entry system of accounting.


Section 209 ( 3 ) further states that proper books of account shall
not be deemed to have been kept if such books are not on accrual basis and
according to double entry system of accounting. 

 

Companies had different accounting years and the  "
previous year"  under the Income-tax Act for the purpose of taxation
which was decided in accordance with Section 3 as it stood prior to
amendments brought by the  Direct Tax Laws ( Amendment ) Act, 1987. 


 

The amendment to Section 3 has brought in the concept of uniform
accounting year for the purpose of income-tax assessment.


 The  section  inter alia  provides that with
effect from 1st April 1989  " previous year"  for the purpose
of the Act means the financial year immediately preceding the assessment
year.


In order to comply with the uniform accounting year under the
Income-tax Act, many companies have changed their accounting year and
close their books of accounts on 31st March.


However, there is no amendment to Companies Act requiring
companies to adopt the accounting year from April to March and, therefore,
quite a few companies have continued to 
follow an accounting period different from financial year. 


  Method of Accounting  

 

In the past, companies have been following cash or hybrid or
mercantile system of accounting, but it has now become incumbent upon them
to switch over to accrual basis following the amendment to Section 209 ( 3 ) .


 

The accrual system of accounting has been defined in para 1.06
of the ICAI guidance note of 1983 on Terms used in Financial Statements.


As an accounting concept, accrual 
basis is not different from mercantile basis. 

 

In accordance with Section 145 of  Income-tax Act, 1961,
 the income chargeable under the head  " profits and gains of
business or profession"  or  " Income from other sources"
 shall be computed in accordance with the method of accounting
regularly employed by the assessee.


It is an accepted position that an assessee can adopt either
mercantile system or cash system  [ ( CIT. vs Chunilal vs Mehta & Sons P.
Ltd 82 ITR 55 ( SC ) ] . 


An assessee can also follow hybrid / heterogeneous system besides
cash / mercantile system according to Supreme Court decision in the matter
of  CIT vs Krishnaswami Mudliar, 53 ITR 122. 


It is also to be noted that the applicability of Section 145 of
Income-tax Act is in respect of all the assessees.


This means that non-company assessees can continue to follow cash
or hybrid system. 

 

It is also necessary to examine the requirement of tax audit
under Section 44 AB.


In accordance with Section 44 AB,  " Every person ( a)
carrying on business shall, if his total sales, turnover, gross receipt, as
the case may be, in business exceed Rs. 40  lakh  in any
previous year; or ( b) carrying on profession shall, if his gross receipts in
profession exceed Rs. 10  lakh  in any previous year,
get his accounts of such previous year audited by an accountant before the
specified date and obtain before that date the report of such audit in the
prescribed form duly signed and verified by such accountant and setting
forth such particulars as may be prescribed; provided that in a case where
such person is required by or under any other law to get his accounts
audited, it shall be sufficient compliance with the provisions of this
section if such person gets the accounts of such business  audited by an accountant before the specified date and obtain before
that date the report of the audit as required under such other law and a
further report in the form prescribed under this section." 


 

The proviso applies to all assessees who are required to get
their accounts audited under any law, and hence it is applicable to
companies also. 

 

In respect of companies having  an
accounting year other than financial year, say, 31st December, a question
arises as to whether under Section 44 AB of the Income-tax Act the tax
auditor can audit and certify the accounts for the period for which accounts
have been maintained under the Companies Act ( i.e. upto 31st December ) or
whether the tax auditor will have to certify the accounts for the relevant
financial year which is the uniform accounting year for tax purposes. 

 

This matter was referred to " CBDT " , which
vide their circular


561 dated 22nd May, 1990 has pointed out that as the income of
previous year is chargeable to tax and for the purpose of Income-tax Act, the
previous year is financial year, the tax auditor would have to carry out
the audit under Section 44 AB in respect of the period covered by the
previous year i.e. the relevant financial year.


The Board further clarified that the provision of Section 44 AB
covers only the cases where the accounts are audited under any other
law in respect of financial year.


The circular further states that where the accounting year is
different from the financial year, the provisions of Section 44 AB will not
apply.


In such cases, where the  accounting year is
different from financial year, the tax auditor would have to carry out the
tax audit in respect of the period covered by the relevant financial year and
submit his report in form 3 CB as required by rule 6G ( 1) ( b) of the
Income-tax Rules. 

 

The " CBDT " circular established a fact that
the tax audit under Section 44 AB is not necessarily linked with the
statutory audit under the Companies Act, and therefore, a tax auditor has
to carry out tax audit separately. 

 

The Board has, however, not considered the possibility where a
company which has been maintaining the accounts on cash or hybrid system
and has an accounting year same as  " previous year"  ,
prepares two sets of final accounts - - one under cash or hybrid system (
for income-tax ) and the other on accrual basis ( as required under
Companies Act ) , in the cases where Section 44 AB is applicable and the
cases in which Section 44 AB is not applicable. 

 

However, it can be concluded that the company would be within its
rights ( subject to provisions of Section 145 of Income-tax Act ) to
continue to maintain the accounts for the purpose of Income-tax Act, under
cash or hybrid system and prepare its accounts for the purpose of Companies
Act on accrual basis as required by Section 209 ( 3) of Companies Act.


 

Where a company having financial year as accounting year and
prepares two sets of accounts, it is necessary to examine whether the
Income-tax department would reject the accounts prepared undercash /
hybrid system, just because the income returned works out to be lower than
the income which would have been worked out on accrual basis.


In case the company had been regularly following cash or hybrid
system for the earlier assessment years, the department cannot reject the
cash / hybrid only on the grounds that a separate set of accounts has been
prepared on accrual basis as required under Companies Act. 

 

The power to reject the method of accounting has been split out
in the proviso to Section 145 ( 10 of Income-tax Act ) which is as under:
 Provided  that in any case where the accounts are correct and
complete to the satisfaction of the assessing officer but the method
employed is such that, in the opinion of the assessing officer the income
cannot be properly deduced therefrom, then the computation shall be made
upon such basis and in such manner as the assessing officer may determine.


 

In order to reject the method of accounting, it is necessary for
the assessing officer to establish that the income cannot be properly deduced
from the method of accounting followed by the assessee.


In case a company prepares two sets of accounts, a reconciliation
between the Profit & Loss Account under cash system and the Profit & Loss
account under the mercantile system, can be prepared in order to establish
that the income derived under the cash system is correct. 

 

The Andhra Pradesh High Court has held in  CIT vs Margadarsi
Chit Funds P. Ltd., 19 ( Taxman 73 )  that when the assessee has
followed a particular method of accounting and has been regularly following
it, the department must have sufficient material for rejecting the method of
accounting.


The learned judge has said that the choice to account for income on
an acceptable basis is that of the assessee and not of the department.


The  power to substitute a system of accounting for the
one followed by the assessee, flows from provisions of Section 145 of the
Income-tax Act.


It is, therefore, imperative that before rejecting the system of
accounting followed by the assessee, the ITO must refer to the inherent
defect in the system and record a clear finding that the true pofit / loss
cannot be deduced from the books of account maintained by the assessee.


As already observed, there is no finding to that effect in this case.


The  view that there could be a better system of
accounting is no reason for application of the provision of Section 145 of
the Act, especially in view of the fact that this system of accounting is
followed by the assessee uniformly and regularly for the past several years
and was accepted by the department without objection. 


  Change in Method of Accounting  

 

The insistence on the method to be followed on regular basis does
not debar the assessees from changing the method of accounting.


The assessee is entitled to change the method of accounting, but such
change should arise out of commer-      cial expediency and also should be a  
bona fide   one.


The change in accounting system should not be a casual departure.


 

In  " Padamsee Mulji Ginning & Pressing Co. ( P)
Ltd., 3 ITD 92 ( Bom ) , "  the assessee, a holding company,
had advanced loans to its subsidiary companies and interest chargeable on
such loans was regularly being returned by it as its income on accrual basis.


Later on the company resolved that interest receivable would be
accounted on cash basis, as the subsidiary companies are in financial
difficulties and, therefore, it did not return any income from this source.


The tribunal held, that so long as there was no   mala
fide   motives in changing the method, the assessee could not
be denied the privilege of changing the method of accounting. 

 

In the case of  " Rajiv Investment ( P) Ltd. vs lTO,
20 ITD 431 ( Cal ) "  it was held that if one regular method of
accounting was changed to another method of accounting and followed it
thereafter regularly, the department has to accept such change. 

 

It may be noted that the change in the method of accounting
should be on account of commercial expediency.


In the case of  " Deepnarin Nagu & Co I ITD 288 ( Indore )
, "  the assessee, after filing the original return of income
duly supported by valid accounts, decided to switch over from mercantile to
cash system of accounting and filed revised return of income supported by
revised sets of accounts.


The ITO and AAC declined to accept the revised return, holding
that the change in the system of accounting being not on account of
commercial expediency but was only an afterthought.


The Tribunal confirmed the view, holding that the assessee has
not proved that the change was   bona fide   .


 

The companies which plan to maintain accounts for income-tax
purpose as per cash or hybrid system and mercantile basis for Companies Act,
as against mercantile basis earlier followed for income-tax as well as
Companies Act, should ensure that sufficient evidence is placed on record to
prove that the change is necessitated by commercial expediency. 

 

It can therefore be concluded that companies, irrespective of the
accounting year followed by them for the purpose of  "
Companies Act, 1956, "  can continue to submit the accounts for
the  " previous year"  for the purpose of income-tax
assessments, if the company had been uniformly and regularly following the
said system in the past.  


 


When the assessee has followed a particular method of accounting and
has been regularly following it, the Income-tax Department must have
sufficient material for rejecting the method of accounting.  



 


The insistence on the method to be followed on regular basis, does
not debar the assessees from changing the method of accounting.  


  The author is a
member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India.

Campus Debate     

 

The three most striking developments in American higher education
in the past 30 years have been the transformation of the campus from a white
male preserve to one of racial and gender diversity; establishment of
specialized departments for the study of ethnic, gender, and international
issues; and a phenomenal increase in the number of foreign students,
particularly from the developing world.


We in India who have been watching the American higher education
scene, have considered these changes positive and enriching - - until Dinesh
  " Illiberal Education "  came
along. 

 

The complete title of the book,  " Illiberal
Education: " The Politics of Race and Sex on Campus  
*, succinctly describes the thrust of the book and spells out  major concerns about the current state of American higher
education.


The American campus once provided an intellectual and harmonious
environment conducive to the free flow of ideas; it gave impetus to
creativity and individual growth.


But today, laments D'Souza, it has been politicized over issues of
race and gender to such an extent that it is capable of providing only
illiberal education in an atmosphere of suspicion and hostility. 

 

D'Souza sees academic freedom being stifled, and group interests
being given precedence over individual rights and meritoracy.


He attributes this slide to selfish, shortsighted, and mindless
affirmative action policies of university administrations, abetted by
their  " politically correct"  supporters.


D'Souza observes that those who call themselves  " politically
correct,"  though in a minority, have succeeded in unleashing a
tyranny that is eating up the very vitals of American higher education.


They stand for multiculturalism, feminism, and diversity in the
curriculum. 

 

D'Souza uses the case study approach, citing concrete examples
for illustrating his arguments.


He lays bare the inner workings and the resultant injustice of
race-based admissions at the University of California, Berkeley; explains the
dynamics of black protest at Howard University in Washington, D.C., exposing
its hollowness and superficiality; and examines the University of  efforts to protect minorities by imposing <*> line </*>
 restrictions on this liberal campus  speech, expression, and behavior. 

 

Against the background of these disturbing trends, D'Souza
discusses how minority and politically correct activists have diluted the
objectivity, scholarly content, and rigor of the curriculum at Stanford
University in Stanford, California, and Duke University in Durham, North
Carolina.


He says that at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the
 academic freedom has been compromised by an aggressive and
committed ethnic and feminist minority that has charged the faculty with
being insensitive, if not bigoted, on race and gender issues.


Faced with such charges, and with no support from the weak and
apathetic university administration, the faculty has dropped controversial
courses and submitted itself to censorship, with knowledge and freedom as
the casualties. 

 

D'Souza has selected the six universities mentioned above for
special consideration because they are in the  " vanguard of the
revolution of minority victims"  and as such are role models for
others.


He also alludes to other campuses to show that the experiences
described are universal.


While giving an insight into the  " politics of race and sex"
 and a ringside view of university administrations' decision-making
processes, D'Souza makes several significant comments about American academic
in the broader perspective of the American democratic process. 

 

He recognizes that American higher education has a responsibility
to bring into the academic mainstream minority races and women who have
historically been deprived of higher education.


He firmly believes that higher education in multi-racial America
should not be the preserve of the white male.


Thus, D'Souza is not arguing against affirmative action  per
se  but rather against the ways in which it has been implemented.


He calls for an affirmative action policy that is in keeping with  commitment to individual rights and freedoms, one that would
avoid polarizing the campus into warring groups.


D'Souza urges that the pace, nature and execution of reforms be
worked out meticulously and sagaciously, so that they would not invite a
backlash from favorably disposed but status quo oriented whites. 

 

D'Souza offers some rather sketchy, tentative, and  "
modest"  proposals at the end of the book.


His first recommendation is   that universities continue with their  " policies of preferential
treatment but alter their criteria of application from race to socioeconomic
disadvantage." 


He is obviously trying to improve upon 
experiment, which has endeavored to diversify the student body according to
the proportions in which racial groups are represented in  population.


This has created a situation in which many Asians and whites with
superior test and academic records cannot find places while blacks and
Hispanics with average records can.


D'Souza would like to avoid such  " social engineering"
 that totally ignores equity, achievement and excellence.


Under his proposals, admission officers will consider  "
the  family back-ground, financial condition, and primary
and secondary school environment." 


If this record suggests that the  undistinguished
performance was not due to  " lack of ability or application but
rather to demonstrated disadvantage,"  the applicant would be
admitted. 

 

This solution does pose some practical problems regarding the
availability and verification of data.


While admissions based on race are mechanically given and candidates
are treated as members of a group, admissions based on socioeconomic criteria
would be made on individual basis only after careful evaluation of each  learning and growth potential.


Processing individual cases would prove cumbersome and time
consuming.


D'souza contends, however, that information required for making
admission decisions is available in university admissions and financial aid
offices. 

 

By replacing race with socioeconomic criteria, preferential
treatment for admission would be extended to a larger pool of applicants,
thus reducing opportunities for blacks and Hispanics.


Anticipating criticism, D'Souza is quick to counter by pointing out
that if being a member of a race can be  " shown to translate into
socioeconomic disadvantage currently suffered by the student applicant"
 he would continue to benefit under the scheme.


The number of racial minorities admitted to schools will not
diminish, only they will be getting into universities they academically
deserve. 

 

 second recommendation aims at arresting the
growth of separatism among minority students on the campus.


The author offers various explanations for a 
coolness toward integration.


He says an admission process that gives preferential treatment
to ethnic minorities ironically does not benefit them because they are so
inadequately prepared academically that it is difficult for them to compete
with highly motivated and meritorious students at prestigious
universities.


The minority dropout rate at Berkeley is high; fewer than 40 percent
of entering blacks and 50 percent of entering Hispanics graduate.


The blacks and Hispanics, lured to the campus with offers of
scholarships and other financial incentives, are told that because of their
backgrounds and viewpoints they are helping to produce a  " dynamic
intellectual environment"  and  " richer undergraduate
experience." 


Consequently, their poor performance comes as a rude shock and a
blow to their self-esteem.


In their despondency, the blacks, Hispanics, and American Indians
supported by foreign students, feminists, and homo-sexuals blame the  racist structure and  " white curriculum" 
for their poor performance. 

 

In this gloomy situation, minorities find solace within their own
ethnic groupings such as the Rainbow Coalition at Stanford.


The minorities  " tend to develop group consciousness and
collective orientation partly as a protective strategy." 


Some black organizations encourage  " anti-intellectualism"
 instead of starting remedial programs.


Minorities are told learning is  " acting white." 


It would seem that Martin Luther King,  movement for
equal rights and integration is being effectively challenged by Malcolm  ideology of separation and Black Power.


It is a  " fight between Martin and Malcolm." 


Historian Arthur Schlesinger aptly remarks,  " The meltings
pot has yielded to the Tower of Babel."  

 

The university policy of establishing separate dormitories,
cultural houses, and organizations for ethnic minorities also unwittingly
encourages separatism.


The extreme case is that of California State University at
Sacramento, which is planning an entirely separate  " college within a
college"  for blacks.


Whites, meanwhile are becoming bitter about race-based admissions,
faculty hiring practices, behavior codes, and sensitivity  training that they perceive as being selectively used against
them.


They charge that double standards are being applied in the way
university leaderships cultivate minority organizations and in the care and
tenderness with which they handle the campus protests of minorities. 

 

Having discussed the crucial issue of multiculturalism throughout
the book,  proposed solution is indeed disproportionately
brief and inadequate.


As he has proposed in the case of race-based admissions, D'Souza
wants the university to refuse to recognize and fund any group that is
 " racially separatist and excludes students based on skin color."



He wants ethnicity and gender to cease to be criteria; he would
replace them with intellectual or cultural interests.


D'Souza rightly points out that  " thought and expression are
the currency in which universities trade and speculate"  and that
universities therefore have no business in supporting nonacademic
politically popular causes. 

 

The third proposal is made in connection with courses classified
under the broad rubric of non-Western, ethnic, and gender studies.


When more than 20 years ago such studies were introduced in American
universities, they fulfilled an important need for covering intellectual and
geographical areas of study that had been largely neglected.


Eurocentric views had long dominated liberal arts education.


The new courses opened the window on the history of minority groups
and non-Western cultures.


This perspective was reinforced with visiting faculty and students
from foreign countries, and new opportunities wre created for Americans to
study, teach, and perform research abroad.


As a visiting faculty member teaching Indian civilization at a
Midwestern liberal arts college in the early 1970s, I personally experienced
the success of this internationalization.


I still vividly recall curious and eager American youth learning
about faraway Indian and the masterful term paper one of them wrote on
Emperor Akbar at the end of the semester. 

 

However, more recently,  academia has been
polarized between the politically correct scholars, who have made issues of
race, gender, and class central to their teaching and research, and the
traditionalists who advocate the study of Western civilization and culture.


The latter claim to have an  " objective"  approach to
scholarship and believe that it is important for Americans to study first the
civilization to which they belong before venturing to comprehend more exotic
cultures.


In their view, politically correct scholars allow their radical
political agenda to taint their scholarship and teaching.


In support of this contention they cite the example of the
politically correct describing Western culture as  " racist, sexist,
and oppressive,"  ignoring its many nobler aspects.


Research in non-Western areas is done selectively from the Western
perspective, the true culture eluding the researcher.


The teaching of non-Western courses leaves much to be desired and
students take them because they are trendy, thin in substance, and hence easy
to pass.


Western culture courses, on the other hand, argue the
traditionalists, are rich in content and <O> photograph of Book "
ILLIBERAL EDUCATION " etc., corner of column <&> therefore hard to
master. 

 

D'Souza, who sides with the traditionalists, is particularly
harsh on AfroAmerican and  studies programs, which he
thinks are committed to an activist ideology of the 1960s, closed to academic
argument, and  " hostile to alternative views." 


He finds these programs more political than scholarly and agrees with
sociologist Walter Allen that the  " departments play an affirmative
action role"  by providing opportunities to hire minority faculty.


Not academically serious, they are  " tolerated but never
fully accepted by traditional or mainstream fields." 


D'Souza calls Harvard  studies professor Alice  class  " so esoteric and yet so vulgar, so freewheeling
and yet so dogmatic, so full of political energy and yet ultimately so
futile."  

 

Considering that there are some 350 Afro-American and 500  studies programs in American universities, 
blanket condemnation appears too sweeping.


Western civilization and culture, and non-Western, ethnic, and
gender programs, complement each other.


Together they should really form the core of liberal arts education.


Realizing this D'Souza suggests universities devise  " a
required course or sequence for entering freshmen which exposes them to the
basic issue of equality and human difference, through a carefully chosen set
of classic texts that deal powerfully with those issues." 


This is not a novel concept and has been tried before.


A required course or sequence for entering freshmen will only be a
token effort given the significance of the subject matter involved and the
richness of materials available for teaching and research. 

 

The book and the  recommendations gain
signifilcance given the  background.


An Indian expatriate, D'Souza, 31, studied at prestigious Dartmouth
College in New Hampshire, wrote for conservative journals like  National
Review  , authored with Gregory Fossdal the biography of
tele-vision evangelist Jerry Falwell, worked for the Reagan White House,
and is now a research fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.


With such impeccable conservative credentials, one would expect his
work to be polemical.


Surprisingly, this representative of the pugnacious right is
balanced, understanding, and even somewhat sympathetic.


Perhaps his Indian background has something to do with this
restraint.


As a Roman Catholic, D'Souza belonged to a religious minority in
India and well knew what it was like living in a multicultural society that
faces some of the same problems as those in America.


India is struggling to reflect its multiculturalism in its own
curricula, to bring its scheduled caste and tribes into the academic
mainstream, and to effect a compromise between its  " politically
correct"  left and traditionalists of the right.


This lucid, analytical, and bold book will therefore be of interest
to Indians, particularly those in academia.  <*> small square </*> 


 About the Author: 


 Dileep Patwardhan is the regional officer for the Bombay branch
of the U.S. Educational Foundation in India.

The Aesthetics of Black Protest Theatre   


 K. Santhanam  


 Jamal Mohamed College, Tiruchirapalli 

 

CONTEMPORARY black drama has emerged not only as a source of
entertainment but also as an expression of culture and a medium of
instruction.


The new black dramatists in America have artistically depicted the
identity crisis faced by the black Americans in their plays.


Today there is a widespread recognition by black American dramatists
that theatre can have enormous impact on the black  struggle to
attain full equality and status in America and thereby regain his spiritual
strength.


So the performing arts have emerged as important means of reaching
wider audiences and getting greater recognition.


A number of dramatists have made very significant contribution,
towards the growth of black theatre in America and the success of their
effort is seen in the establishment of Black Protest Theatre there. 

 

The black protest theatre movement in America arises out of a
certain social and political philosophy of life.


Black dramatists like Baraka and Bullins firmly believe that 
" there are in fact and in spirit two Americas - - one black, one white"
   


These dramatists have lost faith in the concept of  ` American
Dream'  and the integrationist principles advocated by the middle
class American blacks.


Consequently these playwrights reject the Western dramatic theories
with their emphasis on social realism and the universality of human
experiences which have no validity in the context of black situation
prevailing in America.


These dramatists are of the view that long years of  suffering and oppression of the blacks have necessitated the adoption
of a new dramatic model that will address the black brethren directly leading
to the expression of their unique black experience in America.


Quite naturally, besides advocating racial and cultural
separation, these plays are addressed to the black people who have a social
and cultural tradition different from the mainstream American Society and
whose experiences run counter to the Western modes. 

 

Baraka in his essay  ` The Revolutionary Theatre' 
, has laid down the aims and objectives of this new kind of theatre which has
ushered in a new theatrical renaissance in America.


He says that this new theatre will bring in a new vision of black
reality by its open advocacy of violence and revolution which will lead to
the destruction of white America.


This theatre will present  " the black as a victim living in a
no- land completely invisible to white America."  
 


By presenting this theatre as a theatre of victims, it excites the
black spectators to anger and violence which moves them into liberation of
blacks from a sense of suffering and oppression in white America.


This theatre, by its advocacy of violence, murder and revolution
seeks to put an end to the suffering of blacks in America.


The violence it preaches is redemptive of a regenerative kind of
violence that envisages the establishment of a new world order based on
revolution.


Baraka, in his early plays presents his heroes as victims since they
refuse to act very firmly in time which makes them a prey to white power
structure.


But his later dramatic heroes emerge triumphant physically and
spiritually having acquired the revolutionary black consciousness.


The process of  ` razing'  gives rise to  `
raising'  a new black world.


 " The Revolutionary Theatre must expose.


It must Accuse and attack anything that can be accused or attacked.


It must Accuse and Attack because it is a theatre of victims."
    

 

The black dramatists like Baraka and Bullins are of the view that
their picture of black coloured realism depicting the sufferings of the
blacks is much different from the Euro-American concept of realism as
portrayed by the mainstream writers who  take no
cognisance of the black situation prevailing in America.


This revolutionary black realism not only aims at destruction of
social and cultural white America but also builds a new black world by
incorporating the Afro-American cultural values.


The black revolutionary writers like Baraka during the course of
their dramatic career are very much influenced by the theories of black
Aesthetics and Black Art, The advocates of this theory say that Black is
beautiful and produce literary works depicting black life with its
distinctive styles and rhythms of black people.


They try to go back to their black heritage and strength which have
enabled them to endure prolonged oppression.


Some black revolutionary writers like Baraka want the black writer to
create black art by separating himself completely from the American
mainstream and give expression to black experience.


The black Art which will directly address the black people will give
them a new sense of direction, a new mythology and symbolism which would help
in the shaping of the black artistic and cultural forms.


Any work of art if it does not adequately reflect the black
experience, does not confirm to the theories of Black Aesthetics.


The pragmatic value of a work of art, its effective quality is more
important than its expressive qualities.


According to the principles of black Aesthetic, the transmission of a
message from a teaching black author to willing black audience becomes the
   touchstone   of literary achievement.


According to the revolutionary protest writers, black drama or any
work of art arising from the oppression and sufferings of the black people
should change the structure of the American society and end the oppression of
the blacks.


Besides this, black community and thereby usher in a cultural
revolution. 

 

The black critics have come out with certain new artistic
criteria in evaluating these black productions.


These critics want these black productions to be judged not on the
basis of western dramatic theories and practice, but on their own black
cultural    echoes   and tradition.


Since these plays are written out of the suffering and oppression of
blacks, they have to be judged based on Afro-American cultural tradition and
yardstick.


While evaluating a black performance, the critic has to take into his
consideration the subject matter of the play and its impact on the audience
since the black dramatists interested  in educating
the black community and thereby raise its consciousness.


Under such conditions a black play is not just a work of art but
becomes an effective tool in raising the black awareness of the entire race.


Therefore it would be better if the critic evaluates these plays with
a knowledge of Afro-American Culture and history.


By way of illustration, we can cite the example of Kathakali theatre
in Kerala.


A performance of Kathakali dance would make a better impact on an
indigenous audience with the significance of gesture, sounds, words and their
connotations.


While the Indian audience can share the reaction to the play it is
lost on a non-Indian audience.


Addison Gayle provides a proper evaluation of black production. 



 " A critical methodology has no relevance in the black
community unless it aids men in becoming better than they are.


Such an element has been solely lacking in the critical cannons
handed down from the academics by the Aristotlean critics, the Practical
critics, the Formalistic critics, and the New critics.


Each has this in common : it aims to evaluate the work of art in
terms of its beauty, and not in terms of the transformation from ugliness to
beauty, that the work of art demands from its audience.


The question for the black critic today is not how beautiful is a
melody, a play, a poem, or a novel, but how much more beautiful has the poem
melody, play or novel made the life of a single black man." 
   

 

This Black Protest Theatre makes no distinction between actors
and audience or stage and the street or the plays illusion and  reality.


Such distinctions which form part of the Western theatre do not hold
good in revolutionary black theatre.


One another important characteristic of Black Protest Theatre that is
distinct from the mainstream theatre is its ritualistic aspect.


The ritualistic elements refer to the presence of symbols,
characterisation, themes, and language styles which are frequently repeated
in all the plays.


This brings to the    audience  
certain identifiable patterns which affirm the values of the black community
for whom these plays are written. 


Baraka employs all these devices to produce a ritualistic effect in
his Revolutionary Theatre.


At the apparent level  " Great Goodness of Life
"  is an allegory.


It is the story of a weak man who kills his son rather than resist
the pressures of an oppressive white power.


The deeper meaning of the play is that a middle class black is unable
to protect the life of his son because of fear of the whites.


He prefers the killing of his son to resisting the white power. 

 

Baraka has employed symbols in his revolutionary dramas which
bring out the meaning of the play in very clear terms.


The white woman in his plays represents evil who taunts the black
male with her perverse sexuality.


Lula in  " Dutchman "  represents the
white female temptress and she is the symbol of the white middle class
America who tempts Clay into violent action. 

 

Baraka by the use of his language has ritualised his plays.


He has accepted a particular style of language with regard to white
and black characters.


The black hero is a  ` hip'  whose language reveals
his heightened black awareness.


His language emanates from the street world of pimps and prostitutes.


The  ` square'  is a despised character who employs a
different language register, who is considered to be dangerous to the black
world. 

 

In the later black revolutionary plays, Baraka incorporates the
ritual form with black symbols and images to give expression to his
revolutionary consciousness.


A  " Black Mass "  is a typical black play
which utilises Afro-American mythic structure incorporating the music of
Sun Ra and the ideology of the Nation of Islam.


Baraka, in his effort to bring out his revolutionary black
consciousness repeats these devices from play to play so that these patterns
are easily recognised by the black audience. 

 

The idea of an autonomous dramatic form conceived in the Western
tradition gives place to a theatre that demands audience involvement and
participation to achieve its aims and objectives.


This process is described  " as a movement from mimesis,
representation of an action, to methexis, communal helping out of action."
   


Through this process, the black  audience is
transformed from spectators of drama to participators of ritual with no
distinction between actor and spectator. 

 

Another important feature of Black Protest theatre by which it
distinguishes itself from the mainstream theatre is in its use of music and
dance.


The black dramatists, by incorporating the elements of black music
and dance, in their plays, give expression to their unique black experience.


This theatre, by stressing the close relationship that exists between
black artist and the black spectator, gives way to improvisational action
leading to emotional participation.


Under such theatrical condition, the traditional distinction
between the spectator and the actor is blurred when they become one. 

 

This black theatre bears a close resemblance to Antonin  Theatre of Cruelty.


According to Artaud human beings are governed by certain
incomprehensible malignant cosmic powers.


The universe with its violent irrational forces is cruel.


The theatre should reveal the essence of human nature by  ` a
drama of cruelty'  .


Such scenes must be presented to purge the audience of the
corresponding emotions in them.


So, a  ` true theatre'  disturbs repose, frees the
repressed unconscious, incites a kind of revolt and exteriorises latent
cruelty, certainly most of  plays disturb repose and uncover
source of conflict.


On one occasion the performance of  " Dutchman "
 was cancelled on the ground that it would incite the feelings of black
audience shortly after the assassination of Martin Luther King. 

 

We can also compare the dramatic theories of this black theatre
with those of the epic theatre advocated by Bertolt Brecht.


According to Brecht the highest form of theatre induces the audience
to act and also demands decisions from them.


Brecht also emphasises the apartnesses of the theatrical activity
wherein the spectator is transformed into an observer.


He is of the view that too much emotional involvement of the audience
with the performance has dried them of the creative energies needed to bring
about the desired changes in the world.


Brecht says that the spectators should leave the theatre with tools
of heightened scientific perception.


However, black revolutionary dramatists are different in that they
aim at complete emotional involvement on the part of the audience with the
actors, a fact proved by his agit - - prop plays which carry  the message to the black community in a simple but effective
way. 

 

The Western drama since Aristotle by following the
conventional dramatic devices has always attempted to uphold the existing
social and cultural values of the society.


But Black Protest Theatre not only questions the traditional validity
of the social and cultural values of the Western Society but also rejects
them completely with the purpose of inculcating new values.


Consequently this Black Protest Theatre makes the audience realise
the sad aspect of their lives and forces them into continuing group action.


 

The Black Protest Theatre goes beyond pointing out injustices
meted out to the black community or making meek appeals to the white society
to put an end to its oppression of the Blacks.


This theatre that aims at liberating the entire black race, becomes a
theatre of communal deliverance, which aims at freeing the black race from
the shackles of the white power structure and build a new black world founded
on justice, dignity and pride.

of Reprobation"  : A note on the  " Black Revolutionary

"  , Vol.  1,  ed. Errol Mill ( Englewood
Cliffs, NJ : Prentice Hall, 1980 ) , p. 193.  


 2 Le Roi Jones  " The Myth of a Negro Literature"
 in  " Home "  ( New York : William Morrow,

PROTECTING  


 MINORITY  


RIGHTS  


by A.G. NOORANI 

 

 The determined efforts of American lawmakers and judges,
backed by public opinion and the media, have secured justice and equality for
minorities in the United States.   <*> bold line below </*> 

 

The word  " minorities"  nowhere occurs in the
United States Constitution.


When it was enacted 200 years ago, the concept did not figure in the
reckoning of the Founding Fathers.


It is a tribute to the United States Supreme Court and the United
States Congress that the Constitution has been adapted with remarkable
success to protecting minority rights. 

 

Neither, however, could have accomplished much without the
backing of public opinion and the support of the media.


Awareness of minority rights is a fact of American life today.


On February 7 last year, while the Gulf war was raging in fierce
intensity, General Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff - -
and the first black to hold this position - - was asked about the role of
minorities in the U.S. Army when he testified before the House Armed Services
Committee.


The General lauded the opportunities afforded to minorities in the
military but did not stop there.


He said with typical American candor, " I wish that there were other
activities in our society and in our nation that were as open as the military
is to upward mobility, to achievement, to allowing them in."


No society in the world can afford to be complacent about its record
on reconciling the diverse interests of a pluralistic society.


Acknowledgment of imperfection is proof of integrity and maturity.


 

In the past three decades, the U.S. Congress has enacted
several laws to protect the rights of minorities.


The most recent of these is the Civil Rights Bill of 1991, which,
according to the  Congressional Quarterly  ,  " seeks to
broaden the reach and remedies"  of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the
most comprehensive piece of legislation on the subject in the century. 

 

Proposals for that landmark law were submitted to Congress by
President John F. Kennedy in June 1963, a few months before his
assassination.


Only the ardor and political skills of his successor, President
Lyndon Johnson, could have secured their enactment the next year. 

 

The provisions of this statute are of abiding relevance.


Title II is the heart of the Act.


It declared all persons to be entitled to  " the full and
equal enjoyment"  of the facilities of  " places of public
accommodation,"  such as inns, hotels, motels, restaurants, motion
picture houses, theaters, concert halls, and sports arenas,  " without
discrimination or segregation on the grounds of race, color, religion, or
national origin." 


These guarantees were applicable to any establisment if it
 " affects commerce or if discrimination is supported by state
action." 


This last was said to be present if discrimination was carried on
under color of law, was required by local custom or usage enforced by state
officials, or was required by the state itself. 

 

Other provisions of the law range over a wide variety of civil
rights problems.


Title III authorized the attorney general to file suits to compel
desegregation of public facilities.


Title IV required the commissioner of education to conduct a survey
of the lack of availability of equal educational facilities because of race,
color, religion, or national origin and also authorized him to  "
render school baords technical assistance"  in preparing the
desegregation plants.


It also authorized the attorney general on complaint to institute
suits to desegregate public schools. 

 

Title V empowered the Civil Rights Commission to investigate all
situations where citizens are deprived of the equal protection of the laws
because of race,  color, religion, or national
origin.


Title VI prohibited discrimination in any program receiving federal
financial assistance.


Title VII created a five-man Equal Employment Opportunity
Commission, banned discrimination in employment on account of race, color,
religion, or national origin by employers, labor unions, and employment
agencies; and gave the new commission power to enforce the law through
investigations, hearings, and civil actions.


Title X established the Community Relations Service to assist
communities in resolving  " disputes, disagreements, or difficulties"
 relating to discriminatory practices. 

 

One area of weakness in the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was its
Title I provision on voting rights.


While race, color, religion, or national origin could not lead to
disenfranchisement, literacy tests and other devices had been used for years
to disqualify blacks and other minorities as voters.


Title I incorporated a few measures  " to provide more
effective enforcement of the right to voice in Federal elections without
regard to race or color,"  but this accomplished little more than the
acts of 1957 and 1960.


According to Chief Justice Earl Warren, the ineffectiveness of these
laws stemmed from the fact that they tried  " to cope with the problem
by facilitating case-by-case litigation against voting
discrimination." 


Writes Bernard Schwartz in  " Statutory History of the
United States: "   " Individual law suits could scarcely
resdolve the problem presented by a system of mass discrimination <*> dotted
line</*>


By 1965 only 71 cases had been filed by the Department of Justice
<*> dotted line</*>


A new and more drastic congressional approach was demanded." 


 

On March 15, 1965, President Johnson, in an address to a joint
session of Congress, urged for new legislation to secure the right to vote
for minorities.


Two days later the Administration presented a bill to Congress.


After relatively quick discussions in the Senate, the Judiciary
Committee, and the House, the bill was approved and signed by early August.


According to Schwartz, it is  " in many ways, the most drastic
civil rights statute enacted by Congress."  

 

The Voting Rights Act of 1965 did away with  " any test or
device as a prerequisite for registration or voting." 


Its effect was dramatic, as evidenced by the sharp rise in the
registration of black voters in just two years - - for instance, from 27
percent to 53 percent in Georgia, 19 percent to 52 percent in Alabama, and
seven percent to 60 percent in Mississippi. 

 

The next landmark act came three years later.


The Civil Rights Act of 1968 outlawed discrimination in the sale or
rental of all housing - - and not just in public or public-aided housing - -
because of race, color, religion, or national origin.


The 1960s thus ended with significant statutory gains for the civil
rights movement. 

 

The famous American historian, Henry Steele Commager, had
published a series of his lectures in 1943 under the title  "
Majority Rule and Minority Rights "  ( Oxford University
Press ) .


The lectures did not deal with minority rights as we now know them.


They dealt with majority rule and limited government and the
perennial theme of judicial review in a democracy.


But it is precisely from this outlook, which he so eloquently
articulated, that concern for minority rights has grown.


No majority - - whether of opinion, religion, or other - - can
have absolute power.


Absoluteness belongs to certain values.


Even so, at times competing values do clash.


That is where the judiciary comes in.


The courts had made small but significant attempts at protecting
minority rights by citing older legislation - - the Thirteenth,
Fourteenth, and Fifteenth amendments to the Constitution that, respectively,
abolished slavery, confirmed citizenship rights on  " all persons born
or naturalized in the United States,"  and declared that race was no
bar to voting rights. 

 

Perhaps the most effective provision was the guarantee of
equality in the Fourteenth Amendment:  " Nor shall any state <*>
dotted line</*> deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal
protection of the laws." 


As former U.S. Solicitor General Archibald Cox recalls,  " The
Supreme Court decisions under the equal protection clause halted hostile
governmental discrimination against blacks, Hispanics, and other ethnic
minorities."  

 

The clause provided the legal basis.


The supreme  creativity did the rest.


Cox described its impact graphically;  " At the same time that
the  sense of responsibility for individuals and
minorities was growing, losers in the political process were becoming more
conscious of the potentials of constitutional adjudication for achieving
goals not attainable through the political process, and they were also
becoming better equipped to use them.


Constitutional litigation came to be conducted more and more by civil
rights and civil liberties organizations, by radical political associations,
and later by law offices funded to stimulate community action and provide
legal services to the poor."  

 

The letter of the Constitution had not changed but new life was
put into the language in the light of the conditions of the times.


This is the essence of judicial statesmanship. 

 

The doctrine of  " State action"  propounded by
the Supreme Court proved handy.


Technically, it means action by State organs - - executive,
legislative, or judicial - - as opposed to private action.


The doctrine, however, his even private action where some State aid,
use of State facilities, or any State sanction was involved.


The exclusionary policies of private clubs were hit by the courts
though congressional legislation did not cover them. 

 

The  rulings over the years are a fascinating
story in themselves.


The  ruling in  Brown v. Board of Education 
in 1954 outlawing racial segregation in schools, needs no recounting
today.  

 

With the  " Bakke "  case ( 
" Regents of the University of Califormia v. Bakke  " )
the Court entered, in 1978, the new and highly controversial field of  "
affirmative action." 


It disallowed ( five to four ) the kind of explicit, rigid racial
quota established by the university but upheld ( five to four ) the use of
race as a tool of affirmative action programs.


The majority ruling left intact the bulk of affirmative action
programs that gave special consideration to minority groups and women
while sounding an alarm on rigid quotas.


Justice Lewis F. Powell cast the decisive vote breaking a four -
four deadlock among the eight other justices.


The Court ruled that a university has a  " substantial
interest"  in a diverse student body that  " legitimately may
be served by a properly devised admission programme involving competitive
considerations of race and ethnic origin."  

 

Earlier, in 1971, the Supreme Court had ruled in  "
Griggs v. Duke Power and Co. "  that  " discriminatory
preference for any group, minority or majority, is precisely and only what
Congress has proscribed.


What is required by Congress is the removal of artificial,
arbitrary, and unnecessary barriers to employment when the barriers
operate invidiously to discriminate on the basis of racial or other
impermissible classification." 


Obviously, this may sometimes require preference to minorities to
overcome handicaps or to correct past wrongs. 

 

Thus the  " Bakke "  ruling did not
come all of a sudden.


It had been in the making for some time.


In 1977, for example, in  " United Jewish Organizations
v. Carey "  , the Supreme Court upheld a New York statute
that  " deliberately increased the non-white majorities in certain
districts in order to enhance the opportunity for election of nonwhite
representatives from those districts,"  even if it disadvantaged
certain white Jewish communities.


Three members of the Court, including Justice William H. Rehnquist,
who is now the Chief Justice, explained that  " no racial slur or
stigma with respect to white or any other race"  was involved.


In 1979, after Bakke, in  " United Steel Workers of
America v. Weber "  , a five to two majority held that
private employers could set up a quota system with separate lists for
selecting trainees for a newly created craft program.


In  " Fullilove v. Klutznick "  six members
of the Court led by then Chief Justice Warren E. Burger unequivocally upheld
a law that reserved ten percent of federal public works programs for
minority contractors. 

 

This case, decided on July 2, 1980, is of seminal importance.


Section 103(6)(2) of the Public Works Employment Act, 1977, provided
that no federal grant would be made for any local public works project unless
the applicant gave  " satisfactory assurance"  that at least
ten percent of the amount of each grant  " shall be expended for
minority business enterprises ( MBE)." 


The expression was defined to mean a business of which at least 50
percent was owned by minority group members or, in the case of publicly owned
business, at least 51 percent was so owned.


The minority groups were also specified by the provision - - American
citizens who were  " Negroes, Spanish-speaking, Orientals, [
American ] Indians, Eskimos and Aleuts."  

 

The Supreme court upheld this law six to three.


Chief Justice Burger, delivering the judgment of the Court, observed:
 " Congress had bofore it, among other data, evidence of a long
history of marked disparity in the percentage of public contracts awarded
to minority business enterprises.


This disparity was considered to result not from any lack of capable
and qualified minority businesses, but from the existence and maintenance of
barriers to competitive access which had their roots in racial and ethnic
discrimination, and which continue today, even absent any intentional
discrimination or other unlawful conduct.


Although much of this history related to the experience of
minority business in the area of federal procurement, there was direct
evidence before the Congress that this pattern of disadvantage and
discrimination existed with respect of State and local construction
contracting as well.


In relation to the MBE provision, Congress acted within its
competence to determine that the problem was national in scope." 
 


 The letter of the Constitution had not changed but new life
was put into the language in the light of the conditions of the times.


This is the essence of judicial statesmanship.  


 In 1978 the Court entered the controversial field of  "
affirmative action." 


It disallowed rigid racial quotas, but upheld the use of race as a
tool of affirmative action programs.  <&> at the end of column ie the
article, " about the author " <*> line from left to
right</*>


 About the Author : 


 A.G. Noorani, a frequent contributor to " SPAN
" , is a Bombay-based lawyer and constitutional expert.
