The rail car came out of the long tunnel into the Himalayan
country.


Tunnel number 16 was the dividing point between the plains and the
hills.


Under the early evening light, the earth was covered with pastel
shades of green.


The white car pulled up at Barog station, and everyone, except two
passengers, got out to have tea. 

 

A girl who had been sitting on the other side came over and opened
the window in front of Bauji.


The cool air poured in.


 ` Chinese set to grab our land'  , screamed a newsboy.


Leaning far out of the window, the girl called out to the boy.


She spoke louder than necessary, as if he were a great distance away.


 

The boy, weighed down with books, papers and magazines, hurriedly
walked over to her.


His face was partially buried in a scarf.


It must be could, thought Bauji.


And here was this boy burdened by the useless rhetoric of
politicians.


It was good to be free and a democracy, but the politicians were a
price that had to be paid for this privilege.


The girl bought a newspaper, and a copy of the " 
Illustrated Weekly of India  . " 

 

 "  getting cold isn't it?"  she said
to the boy as he handed her the change.


Bauji was bothered by the melancholy news of the Chinese, but he
tried to put it out of his mind.


Instead, he thought of the girl.


He thought that she had a beautiful young voice, but it was also a
little sad.


From the material and the cut of her coat, he surmised that she came
from a wealthy family.


Her youth and her manner suggested that she was unmarried; her tone
of voice was that of someone who was used to getting her way. 

 

The girl shut the window, and pressed her hands to her slightly
red cheeks.


She moved back to her seat.


The tea drinkers returned+ the dining room, and the rail car pulled
away from the station.


It had begun to grow dark outside and soon the lights were turned on
inside the car.


As a result, the windows were transformed into mirrors, and it
created a strange atmosphere of forced intimacy.


Putting his face against the window, Bauji tried to look out.


The sky  behind the mountain carried red traces of the
setting sun.


Individual shapes on the dusky landscape although still visible,
were becoming harder to distinguish.


The train climbed the northern slope of the second range into another
tunnel.


They came out at the other end in a mountain valley.


Sudden faint bursts of colour appeared from the chasms between the
mountain peaks. 

 

His gaze returned to the girl, who was now absorbed in the
magazine.


He was looking at her from an unusual angle, and peculiar emotions
welled up inside him.


As he stared at her long neck, bent slightly to one side, he seemed
to feel the vital memory of the woman he had left behind in Pakistan.


However, the more he tried to call up a clear picture, the more his
memory failed him.


She seemed to fade far away, leaving him with nothing to catch or to
hold.


In the midst of the clouded past, the neck of the girl in front
reappeared - - it was damp - - and it seemed to push him forward into the
future.


Suddenly  eyes floated before him.


He gasped in astonishment.


The figures and the background were unrelated, sometimes vivid, other
times dim, melting together in a strange combination of the past and the
present.


A light from the outside unexpectedly flashed on the 
face, and Bauji felt his chest rise at its strange beauty.


The face in the mirror-window moved steadily across the landscape.


 

He woke up with a start.


As he came to, he realised he must have been dreaming.


The reflection of the girl in front was still there in the window.


He hastily lowered his eyes, feeling guilty for having+ at the
stranger.


To cover up his embarrassment, he put his face to the window and
looked at the darkness outside.


At the next moment, he pulled out a large white handkerchief, and
cleared the steam which had gathered on the window. 

 

The bewitching stranger continued to read.


From the way her shoulders were gathered, Bauji sensed an
independence of nature.


The peculiar angle at which her neck was tilted suggested more,
perhaps a touch of arrogance.


There was a fierce intentness in her eyes, which did not permit her
even to blink.


It was a cool, piercing beauty, which exerted a strange, unreal power
in the mirror-window.


Feeling startled, Bauji lowered his eyes again.


Although he knew it was improper to stare like this, he consoled
himself with the thought that there was no way for her to know that she was
the object of his attention.


From where he sat, he could see what she was reading.


Having just completed a short story, she was now skimming over an
article on  China policy.


The man sitting next  to her also saw her
reading it, and he could not contain himself. 

 

 " How dare the Chinese cast eyes on our land!" 
he said to her with outrage in his voice. 

 

 " Well, it is disputed territory, isn't it ? " 
said the girl. 

 

  " Disputed, my foot !


They have tricked us.


First they talk of friendship and   Hindi-Chini bhai bhai
  and then they want to take over our soil."  


Before the girl could answer, he turned around to face Bauji, hoping
to find a more sympathetic listener.


Bauji did not want to talk to the man, but he changed his mind
because he thought it might be a way to get to know the girl. 

 

 " It is  fault for believing them,"
 said Bauji.


  " He is too much of an idealist and forgets that the
pursuit of the  self-interest is the only responsible course
for a leader.


Moralising must take second place.


He feels let down by the Chinese because he trusted+


And  no room for trust in these things." 
 

 

Not finding Bauji sympathetic to his point of view, the man
grunted and turned around in a huff.


The girl did not get a chance to say anything because of the abrupt
way the man closed the subject.


Or more likely, Bauji thought, she did not want to get into a
conversation with strangers.


The rail car again became silent and Bauji went back into his own
private world. 

 

Bauji was startled when the rail car reached Simla.


He saw the girl rise.


He had been lost in thought for three-quarters-of-an-hour.


His private battles against Nehru as well as his secret romance in
the mirror-window had disappeared in the reality of the brightly lit
platform.


Suddenly, he spotted Tara and Seva Ram in the distance.


He did not wait for them to approach, but stepped out of the carriage
with a resolute step.


As soon as Tara reached him, she flung her arm around his neck, drew
him rapidly to her, and embraced her father warmly.


 eyes sought out the attractive stranger, who was now
on the platform, surrounded by several equally well-dressed people.


She obviously belonged to the best society.


Standing there, he thought she was not beautiful, but rather there
was a youthful elegance and grace about her whole figure.


As he looked around, she too turned her head.


Her shining, dark eyes, that looked darker from the thick lashes,
rested with cold attention on his face ( as though she were recognising him)
and then she promptly turned away.


In that brief look, he noticed a suppressed eagerness which flitted
between her brilliant eyes and a faint smile that curved her lips.


It was the look of a young lady who is sure of her own beauty, and
like all such women, a little cruel.  

 

 "  very sweet, isn't she?"  said
Tara. 

 

  " Sweet?


Do you know her?"   

 

 " Yes,"  relied Tara, as she waved to the girl,
who waved back enthusiastically.


There was a bustle in the station as the+ train from Kalka was
approaching, several hours late.


The black and white signal indicated  ` down'  , and
there was a rush of porters, attendants and people meeting the train.


Through the vapour, could be seen ill-clad workmen crossing the
rails.


The engine whistled in the distance.


Seconds later, the platform was quivering, and with puffs of steam
hanging low in the air from the cold, the engine rolled up, the lever of its
middle wheel rhythmically moving up and down, and the figure of the engine
driver stooping low. 

 

In the confusion of the arriving train, the girl had disappeared
in the crowd.


 " Can you guess?"  asked Tara. 

 

  " What?"   

 

  " Who she is?"   

 

He shook his head. 

 

  " Your friend Sanat  grand-daughter.


She lives here with her mother."   

 

  " What is her name?"   

 

  " Priti."   


  11 

 

It was the day of the  reception.


Since morning, Arjun had been in a state of wild excitement.


As he was combing his hair in the mirror, he was overcome with
despair.


He thought he was not good looking.


He imagined there could be no happiness for one with such long ears,
such a broad nose, thick lips, and brown eyes as his.


He would have given anything for a handsome face so that he could
appear attractive to Priti. 

 

Karan came promptly at seven to collect them for the reception.


He had informed the Mehtas that  Bauji  would also
come.


When Karan saw Tara, his eyes widened and he remarked that she
looked beautiful.


She felt flattered because she had gone to considerable trouble to
put up her hair in a special bun, which was considered fashionable at the
time.


Arjun too was proud of his+ and thought that she looked lovely in
her Madras silk  sari  .


So rarely did they go out that Arjun felt it strange to see his
mother all dressed up.


He was proud that her thick hair was still black, and the bun showed
her long neck and her ears to advantage.


She wore her  sari  in modern style, comfortably and
not too tightly, with a nicely cut blouse, which focused on her attractive
bosom and gave her a lean and youthful look. 

 

Karan invited  Bauji  to ride in his rickshaw but
 Bauji  refused.


He was still upset with Karan.


Thus father and daughter rode together and Arjun rode with Karan.


As they rode to the Mehta house in the raw chill of the Simla
autumn, Arjun tried to imagine the brilliance of the grand reception that
awaited them -- the brightly lit drawing rooms, the splendour of the clothes,
the sumptuously laid food, the dignitaries and important people.


Karan had said in an off-hand way that a Cabinet Minister and the
Governor would be coming, as well as several members of the diplomatic corps
who were visiting Simla.


While Arjun was lost in the spectacle of his imagination, Tara was
preoccupied in safeguarding her hair and her silk  sari  .


 

As they approached the Mehta house, they were impressed by  the brilliant lights which blazed from the numerous
windows of the mansion.


A police guard stood at the brightly lit, carpeted entrance.


As the rickshaws drove away, new ones took their place.


From the rickshaws descended beautifully dressed women.


Before Arjun realized what was happening, they were in the mirrored
vestibule, taking off their coats, helped by a liveried servant.


Arjun tried to assume a dignified manner appropriate to the
occasion.


He glanced into the mirrors, but he could not see himself clearly.


He seemed to+ a part of one glittering whole.


As they reached the door leading to the main drawing room, a
continuous sound of voices and glasses and the rustle of silk  saris
 greeted them.


Amrita was at the door, and she smiled at them.


She greeted  Bauji  with special warmth.

A political expedient  

 

THE Central  proposal to provide an
additional five to 10 per cent reservation in jobs for the poor is a
half-hearted and belated concession to the upper castes.


While the proposal, announced by Prime Minister V.P.Singh in
Parliament, is welcome, it carries the stigma of political expediency.


At a time when all right-thinking people have veered round to the view
that there should be a national consensus on the entire issue of
reservations, the National Front Government is taking ad-hoc decisions.


When Mr. V.P. Singh announced the  decisiion to
implement the Mandal Commission report on August 7, he have rise to criticism
that he was guided by the desire to upstage the dismissed Deputy Prime
Minister Devi Lal, who was busy organising a  rally on
August 9.


That decision, made in utter haste, exposed the populistic
considerations weighing with the Prime Minister.


In the first place, the announcement did not square with the Prime
 oft-declared intention to evolve a consensus on every
national issue.


As no political party is against providing reservations for the
disadvantaged sections of society, it would not have been difficult for the
Government to hammer out a consensus on the Mandal Commission report.


It was only when a storm of protest had broken out in many States did
the Prime Minister drop a hint that he was prepared to make appropriate
concessions to the upper castes.


One would like to know what had prevented him from evolving a
consensus on the reservation of five to 10 per cent of jobs in the Central
Government and the public sector.


The additional reservation is no more than a sop to the upper castes.


The Prime Minister seems to be very much confused on the subject.


On August 8 - - that is, a day after the announcement of the decision
on the Mandal Commission report - - Mr.V.P. Singh said in the  Rajya
Sabha  , somewhat light-heartedly, that since the poor
constituted 40 per cent of the population of India, 40 per cent of the seats
in the legislatures should be reserved for them.


If he had really pondered over the issue, he would not have made the
statement. 

 

The point is that the Prime Minister is guided more by political
expediency than by anytying else.


Now he must be counting on the additional reservation to defuse the
anti-quota agitations rocking many States.


There is a convention that, when Parliament is in session, all
important decisions of the Government should first be announced in the House.


When the announcement outside Parliament was objected to by the
Opposition, the Prime Minister resorted to semantics by saying that what was
announced was only a proposal and not a decision.


It is clear that he is in a hell of a hurry to do something to
contain the anti-reservation sentiment that is spreading like wild fire.


Surely, this is a case of out of the frying-pan into the fire.


The haphazard manner in which the Government is going about
reservations makes one thing clear: it has no considered stand on the issue.


 

A solution to the problem seems to lie in a round table to work
out the modalities of implementing the  Mandal  Commission
report, as suggested by BJP leader Atal Behari Vajpayee in Hyderabad the
other day.


The conference could also consider the additional reservation.


The Prime Minister cannot be unaware of the Supreme Court ruling that
at no time should the percentage of reservations cross 49.


With the announcement of reservations for backward classes, the job
quotas have already touched 50 per cent.


Now is the time for the Government to strive for a consensus on the
issue which has already triggered caste feeling in many parts of the country.
 




  Violence in the Valley  

 

That the Kashmiri militants should have stepped up their violent
activities soon after the Kupwara incident in which the Pakistani troops
resorted to heavey artillery shelling against Indian posts is something that
should make the Indian leaders sit up and do something to arrest the perilous
drift in the valley.


The Pakistan-trained subversives have bombed three bridges on the
Srinagar-Leh highway near Srinagar.


And the  jawans  of the Defence 
Border Road Organisation ( BRO) have become a target for the militants.


With the virtual military take-over in Pakistan, there is a danger of
the  " semi-war"  between India and Pakistan along the line of
Actual Control in Kashmir escalating into a full-scale armed conflict.


The Kashmiri militants are backed to the hilt by Pakistan, whose
President, Mr. Ghulam Isaq Khan, thinks that the Kashmir issue is the
unfinished agenda of Partition.


He is playing second fiddle to the all-powerful Pakistani Army,
which, with a civilian mask, is in virtual control of the country.


Pakistani intervention in Kashmir as well as in Punjab still
continues unchecked.


Even during the recent short-lived democratic rule in Pakistan, the
Army persisted in orchestrating the communal strife in the two Indian border
States.
 Though the deposed Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto blandly assured
India that her Government was determined to check infiltration of terrorists
from Pakistan into India, the Army cared two hoots for her assurances.


It is strange that the Pakistan-abetted subversion in the two
communally sensitive States of India should have increased after the change
of government in India.


From all this, one cannot help inferring that the political
developments in India are proving to be an irresistible temptation to the
Pakistani Army, which is believed to abound with many elements loyal to the
late President Zia-ul-Haq. 

 

Indeed, the dismissal of the Benazir Government marks the return
of Ziaism.


This has grave implications for India because  phased
plot to plunge Kashmir into communal turmoilnow seems to be at its final
stage.


This must be the reason why the Army has got rid of the elected
Government and installed in its place a puppet regime.


The military manipulators of political power are undoubtedly spoiling
for an armed adventure against India.


This is indicated by the Kupwara clash.


Tension along the Line of Actual Control is mounting and the
subversives from across the border are increasing their attacks on the Indian
security forces.


If this is viewed against the backdrop of the failure of the two
rounds of secretary-level talks between the two countries to yield the
expected results, one can understand the gravity of the situation along the
border.


Pakistan seems fully prepared for a war over the Kashmir issue.


Which means India should be able to respond to the Pakistani,
provocations deterrently and decisively. 

 

After the Kupwara clash, Prime Minister V.P. Singh spoke of a
graded response to Pakistani aggravation of tension.


But what the situation calls for is something more than a graded
reply.


The motive behind  opposition to joint patrolling
of the border is now staring everbody in the face.


If Pakistani intervention continues, India will be justified in
resorting to hot pursuit, even if it means waging a war.


Pakistan has already started such a war.


But the challenge that the militants are posing from within the
Indian territory exposes the  monumental failure on
the political front.


The situation would not have come to the present tragic pass if the
National Front Government had refrained from acting vindictively against
the Farooq Abdullah Government.  




  Plan accent on small units  

 

THE National Development Council ( NDC) has put its seal of
approval on the approach paper to the Eighth Plan, the main thrust of which
is the removal of poverty and unemployment.


Development of small and tiny industries with an enlarged list of
reserved items will be an important component of the strategy for generation
of employment.


This objective is fully in consonance with the National Front  commitment to make the right to work a Fundamental Right.


Employment generation is the one area where the new Government can
demonstrate its economic dynamism.


Most of the participants in the NDC meeting called for an increase in
the opportunities for self-employment.


The scope for such employment is vast in the rapidly expanding
small-scale sector.


The total investment in the small-scale sector is expected to
increase to 30,000  crores  in 1994-95 from  Rs.
 17,015  crores  at the end of the Seventh Plan.


This level of investment, according to a study made by the Federation
of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry ( FICCI), will provide jobs to
6.1 million persons by the end of the Eighth Plan against the employment of
3.4 million at the end of the Seventh Plan.


The net addition to employment during the next Plan period will be of
the order of 2.7 million.


It is now realised by all concerned that the promotion and dispersal
of small industrial units will go a long way in solving the unemployment
problem.


But this sector is afflicted with many infirmities.


It is more vulnerable than the medium and major sectors to what is
known as sickness, which is mainly attributable to the non-availability of
working capital when it is needed most.


Pleading with the Central Government to take a fresh look at the
entire gamut of problemes faced by the small and medium sectors, the
All-India  Association ( AIMO) has suggested waiver of
the huge accumulated interest payable by 1.5  lakh  units in
the two sectors.


Such a step, AIMO feels, will provide employment to about 45 
lakh  persons immediately. 

 

Consolidation of the progress already made in the small sector
shiould be one of the aims of the strategy outlined in the Eighth Plan.


In other words, consolidation and expansion should go hand in
hand.


Realising the employment-generating potential of this sector, the
previous Union Government brought in legislation for the establishment of the
Small Industries Development Bank of India ( SIDBI).


The Bank, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Industrial Bank of India (
IDBI), began its operations about two months ago.


One is confident that the SIDBI will play a major role in promoting
and strengthening the small and tiny units.


Marketing continues to be one of the serious problems.


And that problem needs the special attention of the Government,
both at the Centre and in the States.


One complaint that is common to most small entrepreneurs is that the
marketing tie-ups agreed to at the time of starting their units are not
properly adhered to by the Government dpartments and other
quasi-governmental organisations.


Added to this is the short-shrift given to the products of the small
sector in the Southern States by the Directorate General of Supplies and
Disposals. 

 

There is urgent need for the Central Government undertakings to
rectify the regional imbalances in the quantum of purchases made by them from
the small secotr.


As most of the small entrepreneurs are self-employed, the Government
is under an obligation to help them market their products.


Otherwise, it would be guilty of leaving them in the lurch.


It would be too much to expect the small and struggling units to
compete with the well-established medium and major industries.

Philosophy and Methodologies for Protection of Mankind and
the Environment from Harmful Effects of Ionizing Radiation   


 A. Nagaratnam   Defence Metallurgical Research
Laboratory, Hyderabad  - 500 258

 

 In the nuclear energy field, the consciousness of safety,
the planning of facilities and operations to ensure safety, the methods for
monitoring to ensure compliance with safety standards, as well as the record
of safety have been of a very high standard, in contrast to the situation
with respect to control of hazards from chemical pollutants.


The philosophy, methodologies and the data bases that the radiation
protection community has evolved are of great relevance and applicability in
the wider context of environmental protection, public health and industrial
safety  .   


  Introduction  

 

Mankind is reaping immense benefits from the application of
nuclear energy in various fields - - power production, medicine, industry,
agriculture and research.


We know that any facet of human advance involves acceptance of some
risk, and radiation is no exception.


We have to balance risks vs benefits and arrive at an optimum
solution.


In the nuclear energy field, the consciousness of safety, the
planning of facilities and operations to ensure safety, the constant
review and updating of risk estimates in the light of newer knowledge, the
methods for monitoring to ensure compliance with safety standards, as well
as the record of safety are unparalled, Chernobyl notwithstanding.


In contrast, the situation with respect to control of hazards from
chemical pollutants is grim.


Bhopal was the worst industrial disaster in history, but it is clear
that we have learnt very little from " Bhopal " in terms of
corrective measures that have been instituted by the chemical industry
community anywhere in the world.


The response of nuclear experts to Chernobyl stands in refreshing
contrast. 

 

The philosophy, methodologies, techniques and the data bases that
the radiation protection community has evolved are of great relevance in the
wider context of " environmental protection " , "
public health " and " industrial safety " .


Whereas we have extensive knowledge on the long-term effects of
low level ionizing radiation, there is very little corresponding
information for the thousands of chemicals in extensive use.


Generally the immediate toxic effects are those that determine the
setting of limits ( like TLV ) for chemicals.


Because of this wide difference in our knowledge in the two cases,
attempts have been made to equate the hazardous effects of chemicals in
terms of a unit called " REC " , radiation equivalent
chemical. 


  INPUTS TOWARDS SAFETY IN NUCLEAR ENERGY APPLICATIONS
 

 

Around 10 - 15 % of the total capital costs of major systems like
a nuclear power plant go towards safety features such as shields and
stacks.


Similarly around 5 - 10 % of running costs and manpower are devoted
to safety maintenance, whether it is a major activity like operating a
nuclear reactor or a much smaller activity like running a radiotherapy or
nuclear medicine department.


In this connection it is instructive to have a look at the figures
for our nuclear energy activities.


The data have been kindly supplied by Sri S.D. Soman, Director,
Health and Safety Group, BARC ( Soman, 1988 ) .


We have around 34,000 radiation workers ( 12,300 in the
establishments of the Department of Atomic Energy and 21,500 in non-DAE
establishments, mainly in diagnostic X-ray departments and other medical
applications as well as some industrial and research application areas ) .


There are around 820 scientific staff in DAE who are dedicated to
looking after the safety of these workers, giving a figure of one safety
person per 41 radiation workers.


In fact, around 45 % of these workers do not get any radiation dose
at all.


If this is taken into account, there is one safety person per 23
workers with non-zero dose.


The annual per capita expenditure on the safety of each radiation
worker getting non-zero dose is Rs.  2660/-. 


  THE ROLE OF THE INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY ( IAEA )
 

 

" IAEA " has brought out so far around 1150
publications.


Out of these 28 % are listed directly under the heading  `
nuclear safety and environmental protection'  .


Another 3 % deals with  ` radiation biology, dosimetry and
pollution studies'  , which are directly concerned with protection.


In addition, another 8 % is concerned with  ` reactor control
instrumentation, reliability, inspection and quality assurance' 
which have a direct bearing on safety.


Thus around 40 % of the total publications deal with safety.


Is there a similar parallel in any of the other industries or
occupations ?


The International Nuclear Information System ( INIS ) is
comprehensive, systematically organised and standardised.


Information retrieval with respect to any aspect of nuclear energy is
easy and quick.


For example, full details of alI power and research reactors all over
the world are available at one place.


Can we hope to get information at short notice about any of the
chemical plants that are potentially hazardous, say, those producing
pesticides ?


In 1974 " IAEA " initiated a programme on Nuclear
Power Plant Safety Standards ( NUSS ) , which today consist of 5 Codes of
Practice and 60 Guides giving procedures for implementing the Codes. 

 

Ater the 3 mile Island accident in 1979  safety programme was reviewed, and in 1981 a separate
Division of Nuclear Safety was established.


Several elements were added, including Operational Safety Review
Teams ( OSART ) , the Incident Reporting System ( IRS ) , and an
International Nuclear Safety Advisory Group ( INSAG ) .


" IAEA " seeks to promote emergency planning and
preparedness.


Guidelines were developed in 1984 for mutual emergency assistance.


In 1985 a Radiation Protection Advisory Team ( RAPAT ) was
established to deal with non-power applications of nuclear energy.


What about Chernobyl ?


The international nuclear community was partially prepared even
before the accident for managing an event like Chernobyl.


Immediately after the accident " IAEA " received
information on fallout levels from various countries and helped to a
certain extent in the dissemination of information.


But, in the overall context, as Hans Blix, the Director-General
of " IAEA " handsomely admits, important elements
were missing in a viable international safety regime ( Blix, 1987 ) .


But " IAEA " has not spared any effort to learn from
Chernobyl and has expeditiously taken all appropriate corrective measures.


Within a month of the accident, texts of two conventions, namely
early notification convention and convention on assistance in the event of a
nuclear accident or radiological emergency, were adopted.


The weak links in the chain were identified and action taken by
the " IAEA " for better information exchange, man-machine
interface, operator qualifications, international accreditation of
training programmes, fire protection, medical judgement, and biological
dosimetry. 


  " lCRP " PHlLOSOPHY AND METHODOLOGIES
 

 

The International Commission on Radiological Protection ( ICRP )
makes periodic recommendations on all aspects of radiological protection.


Although it is only an Advisory Body, its recommendations have been
unanimously accepted by each and every country in the world, as well as by
international organisations like " WHO " , " FAO
" , " ILO " and " IAEA " .


" lCRP " has brought out so far 55 publications
running into about 7000 pages.


 policy is to consider the
fundamental principles upon which radiation protection measures can be
based.


Because of the differing conditions that apply in various
countries, detailed guidelines on the applications of its
recommendations, either in regulations or codes of practice, are to be
elaborated by the appropriate national or international bodies.


For this reason,  recommendations
provide a degree of flexibility.


" ICRP " defines the objective of radiation
protection as follows :  ` Radiation protection is concerned with the
protection of individuals, their progeny, and mankind as a whole, while still
allowing necessary activities from which radiation exposure might result.'



The level of safety required for the protection of humans is thought
likely to be adequate to protect other species as well. 


  Detrimental effects against which protection is required
 

 

The detrimental effects against which protection is required are
Somatic and Hereditary.


Somatic effects become manifest in the exposed individual himself and
hereditary effects affect his descendents.


" ICRP " makes a distinction between stochastic and
non-stochastic effects.


Non-stochastic effects are those for which the severity of the effect
varies with the dose, and for which there is likely to be a threshold  dose below which no detrimental effects are seen.


Examples are cataract, damage to bone marrow leading to blood
deficiencies ( like anaemia ) , impaired fertility, etc. 

 

Stochastic effects are those for which the probability of an
effect occurring, rather than its severity, is a function of the dose.


To be on the safe side it is conservatively assumed that stochastic
effects have no threshold; even the smallest dose does have a probability of
producing the effect.


Cancer induction and hereditary effects are the major causes of
concern in stochastic effects.


To illustrate the nature of the stochastic effect, we may notice
that when a person gets leukaemia as a result of radiation exposure,
whether he gets the disease from a dose of 100 rem or 200 rem is immaterial;
the disease is going to run the same serious course.


All that one can say is that the probability of getting leukaemia
from an exposure of 100 rem is less than that from an exposure to 200 rem.


It is worth noting that even in the case of chemicals we should
legitimately make this distinction between stochastic and
non-stochastic effects, but this is not explicitly done. 


  Aim of radiation protection  

 

The aim of radiation protection is to prevent non-stochastic
effects and to limit the probability of stochastic effects to levels deemed
to be acceptable.


Non-stochastic effects can be prevented by setting the dose limits at
sufficiently low values so that the threshold dose would not be reached, even
following exposure for the whole of a lifetime ( for members of the
public ) or for the total period of working life ( in the case of
occupational exposure ) .


The limitation of stochastic effects is dealt with later. ) ICRP
publication 26, brought out in 1977, is an epoch-making document.


( It is likely to undergo a major revision in 1990. )


It recommends a system of protection whose philosophy and
methodologies have profound implications in all areas of risk management (
" ICRP " , 1977a ) . 


  System of dose limitation  


This has 3 components, namely " Justification " ,
" Optimisation " , and " Dose limitation
" .

 

 Justification : 


No practice shall be adopted unless its introduction produces a
positive net benefit.


( This implies a cost-benefit analysis. ) 

 

 Optimisation ( ALARA ) : 


All exposures shall be kept as low as reasonably achievable, economic
and social factors being taken into account.


This is the famous ALARA principle.


( It implies a differential cost-benefit analysis. ) 

 

 Dose limitation : 


Doses to individuals shall not exceed the prescribed limits.


( This is the overriding clause.


It is intended to ensure that the risk to any individual does not
exceed acceptable limits, even if the practice might have been justified.


" ALARA has " to be applied subject to this
limitation on individual dose ) . 

 

The concepts of justification and Optimisation have been
elaborately developed by  " ICRP " and guidelines have
been provided for applying them in a variety of practical cases.


A parameter used for optimisation is the collective dose, which is
the product of the number of persons exposed in a group multiplied by the
average dose to this group.


It is a measure of the total health detriment to the population as a
whole and of the burden on society that this detriment will impose ( say,
in terms of hospitalisation facilities or economic expenditure ) .


This parameter is of applicability to chemical pollutants as well.



  Categories of exposure  

 

" ICRP " distinguishes between controllable and
non-controllable exposures.


In the former case, the occurrence of the exposure is foreseen and
can be limited by control of the source and development of satisfactory
operating procedures.


ln the case of uncontrollable exposures ( as in the case of
accidents ) , the exposure is not subject to control, so that subsequent
exposure can be limited, if at all, only by remedial action.


Since remedial action itself ( for example evacuation, denial of
certain areas or contaminated foodstuffs for a time period ) may interfere
severely with normal activities, impose a social or economic burden, and in
certain cases pose its own hazards, the type of remedial action should be
planned on the basis of a cost-benefit analysis. ( Paractical guidelines for
specific situations are given by " ICRP " . ) 

 

" ICRP " has developed to a high degree of
sophistication probabilistic risk assessment methodologies.


Other institutions in the nuclear field have also devoted
considerable attention to risk assessment; as an important example may be
mentioned the " Event-Tree " and " Fault-Tree
Analysis " extensively developed for assessment of reactor safety in
the monumental  monograph brought out in 1976 in
USA and usually referred to as the " Rasmussen Report " or
" WASH-1400 " .


" ICRP " also makes a distinction between
occupational exposure and exposure of a member of the public.


The former is characterised by involving a small number of persons,
who will be adults above the age of 18, with a knowledge of radiation hazards
and protective measures, taking up the occupation willingly, and under strict
health physics and medical surveillance.


On the other hand, the members of the public comprise a much larger
population, including radiosensitive groups like children and pregnant
women and women of reproductive capacity, not capable of strict supervision,
and generally not benefiting from the radiation exposure.


Hence different dose limits are prescribed in the two cases.


It is obvious that such a distinction applies in the case of
chemical pollutants as well.

  Jurisdiction of the Collector of Central Excise  vis-a-vis Section 11A of the Central Excises 
& Salt Act, 1944   <*> line from left to right</*> 


GODFREY W. PIMENTA, Officer-Central Excise, Pfizer Ltd., Bombay.

 

  AFTER   the enactment of
Central Excises and Salt ( Amendment ) Act, 1985, the office of the Collector
of Central Excise has assumed greater importance.


Ordinarily, under the Act, the show cause notice has to be issued
within six months from the relevant date.


However, proviso to section 11A ( I) stipulates that a notice can be
issued within five years from the relevant date if, the non-levy, short levy,
or erroneous refund has occurred on account of any of the following
conditions viz., - -  ( a)  fraud;  ( b)  collusion  (
c)  wilful mis-statement or suppression of facts; and  ( d) 
contraventions of any of the provisions of the Central Excises and Salt Act,
1944, or rules made thereunder, with an intent to evade payment of duty. 

 

The notice which is contemplated under proviso to section 11A ( 1)
is mandatory in nature and condition precedent before any action is to be
taken under the said proviso, for recovery of duties short levied or short
paid, erroneously refunded for breach of any of the conditions laid down
therein, which seeks to invoke the extended period of limitation specifically
devised by the Parliament. 

 

This extraordinary power of invoking the extended period of
limitation of five years under proviso to section 11A(1) now vests in the
Collector of Central Excise by virtue of the Central Excises and Salt (
Amendment ) Act, 1985.


The object of bringing about this amendment is made clear in the
Statement of Objects and Reasons appended to the Central Excises and Salt (
Amendment ) Bill, 1985, which states that, show cause notice in regard to
duty of excise short levied or short paid, etc. by reason of fraud,
collusion, or any wilful mis-statement or suppression of facts should be
issued and such cases decided by the Collector of Central Excise instead of
Assistant Collector of Central Excise. 

 

Now the question of law that arises and which is subject matter of
conflicting decisions of various tribunals and Courts, is that whether the
Collector includes Additional Collector as contemplated in proviso to section
11A ( 1) to the Act.


But unfortunately, there is no clear cut decision on this vital
point, which has resulted in controversies between the assessees and the
Excise Department. 

 

The word  ` Collector'  is not defined in the Act,
but rule 2 (  2  ) of the Central Excise Rules, 1944, defines
the word which means: ( A) in relation to excisable goods other than Salt - -
<*> dotted line</*> ( B) in relation to Salt, the Salt Commissioner; and
includes Additional Collector and any officer specifically authorised under
rule 4 or rule 5 to exercise throughout any State or any specified area
therein all or any of the powers of a Collector under these rules. 

 

The definition of Collector as defined in rule 2 (  2
 ) of the Central Excise Rules, 1944, was a matter of controversy
between various decisions of tribunals,   inter alia 
, " Khatri Biri Works, Beawar v. Collector of Central Excise ;
Jaipur "  [ 1983 E.L.T. 645 ( C.E.G.A.T. ) ;  "
Sunil Kumar Ghosh v. Collector of Central excise & Customs, West Bengal,
Calcutta "  [ 1983 E.L.T. 1964 ( C.E.G.A.T. ) ; and 
" S. Kumar and Others v. Collector of Central Excise and others
"  ( 1983 E.L.T. 1057 ( C.E.G.A.T. ) ] 

 

This controversy was laid to rest by the decision of Calcutta
High Court which examined the issue in detail in case of  "
Bansal Industrial Gases ( Bihar ) Ltd. v. Collector of Central Excise
"  [ 1988 ( 37 ) E.L.T. 347 ( CAL. ) ] , wherein the Court has
held that the post of Additional Collector of Central Excise is the same and
equivalent to the post of Collector. 

 

However, it is to be noted that the decision of Calcutta High
Court referred to above was in the context of sections 33, 35 and 35B of the
Act, which is not the issue at present. 

 

There is an equally applicable decision of the Special Bench in
the case of  " Mahavir Products v. Collector of Central Excise,
"  [ 1989 ( 41 ) E.L.T. 491 ( Tribunal ) ] , wherein the
appellant had raised the preliminary objection on the ground that after the
Amendment Act of 1985, the Collector was not empowered under the Act to have
the proceedings transferred to himself from the Additional Collector.


However, while negativating the above contention of the Appellant,
the Tribunal observed as follows:


 " The objection is not valid for two reasons.


 First,  what happened on 27. 12. l985 was that by amendment
of sections 11A ( I) and ( 2), Collector became the competent adjudicating
authority in cases in which proviso to section 11 A ( I) ( for extending the
limit of 5 years ) had been invoked.


Since in the present case, the said proviso had been invoked, there
was nothing wrong in transferring the proceedings to the Collector.


 Secondly,  both the Additional Collector and the Collector
had jurisdiction to adjudicate in the matter.


Both were proper officers.


Both were competent adjudicating authorities under section 33 and
further under rule 2 (  2  ) ,  ` Collector' 
by definition, included Additional Collector as well.


The appellants cannot complain of any prejudice or illegality so long
as their case was adjudicated upon by another officer having jurisdiction
after due notice to them and after granting them a fresh personal hearing.


There is no merit in the  point that the
proceedings before the Collector were without jurisdiction"  . 

 

However, it is respectfully submitted that, the observation of
CEGAT in case of  " Mahavir Products "  supra is
not correct, because in the statement of Objects and Reasons of the Central
Excises and Salt ( Amendment ) Bill, 1985, it was specifically and
categorically stated that, show cause notice in regard to duty of excise
short levied or short paid, etc. by reason of fraud, collusion, or any wilful
mis-statement or suppression of facts  should be
issued and such cases decided by the Collector of Central Excise instead of
Assistant Collector. 

 

In this connection, it is relevant to mention the decision of the
Supreme Court in the case of  " Rib Tapes ( India) Pvt. Ltd
" and Another " v. Union of India and Others, "
 [ 1986 ( 26 ) ELT 193 ( S.C. ) ] herein it was held:  " It is
not in dispute that in order to interpret a particular provision and to infer
intention of the Legislature, the Objects and Reasons stated in the Bill,
when it is presented to the Legislature could be used"  . 

 

It, therefore, follows that the Collector of Central Excise, who
has been named the only person in the Central Excises and Salt ( Amendment )
Bill, 1985, is the sole authority in whom the power to issue show cause
notice as well as to adjudicate upon the same under proviso to section 11 A (
1) is vested after the amendment. 

 

However, it is to be borne in mind that the Central Board of
Excise and Customs, in exercise of the powers conferred by clause ( b) of
section 2 of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, and rule 4 of the
Central Excise Rules, I944, has been empowered to appoint such officers as it
deems fit and invest in him such powers as may be specified in the
notification issued in this behalf. 

 

This provision as contained in the Act and rules made thereunder
cannot override the express provision of proviso to section 11 A ( 1).


The Additional Collector of Central Excise, who is an authority
subordinate to the Collector of Central Excise cannot usurp the jurisdiction
of the Collector for the purpose of proviso to section 11 A ( 1).


If that was the intention in law, then Parliament would have so
expressed it.


However, it is respectfully stated that as per proviso to section 11
A ( 1), the power has been exclusively vested in the hands of the  "
Collector"  and Parliament has not anywhere in the Act defined the
expression  ` Collector'  as including an Additional Collector
or any other officer.


In this connection, it would be relevant to mention the decision of
CEGAT in  " D.C.W. Limited v. Collector of Central Excise,
Madurai "  ( 1988 ( 35) E.L.T. 167 ( Tribunal ) , wherein it
was held:  " The Central Excise Act has been amended by Central
Excises and Salt ( Amendment ) Act, 1985, with effect from 27. 12. 1985 to
the effect that after the amendment, the show cause notice for recovery of
duty falling under the proviso to section 11 A ( 1) shall have to be issued
only by the Collector of Central Excise and also the Collector is required to
determine the amount of duty excess demanded in the said show cause notice.


In other words, the  Collector alone is given the exclusive
jurisdiction to issue the show cause notice as well as to determine the
amount of duty demanded"  .  

 

There is also a decision of the South Regional Bench of the
Tribunal in  " Punalur Paper Mills Ltd v. Collector of Customs,
Cochin "  [ 1987 ( 31) ELT 770 ( Tribunal ) ] wherein it was
held that  " the show cause notice for recovery of duty for a period
beyond six months under that section has to be issued by the collector."
 

 

Now, another question which arises is that, whether the order
passed pursuant to adjudication by the Additional Collector under proviso to
section 11 A ( 1) after the Amendment Act of 1985 would be  non-est 
in law and, therefore, void   ab initio  .  

 

Since the Collector is mandatorily required under proviso to
section 11 A ( 1) to issue show cause notice as well as to adjudicate upon
the same, it follows, that, if any show cause notice is issued by the
Additional Collector under proviso to section 11 A ( 1), the hearing and
adjudication, and passing of the order upon such adjudication would be a
non-entity in law, i.e., without jurisdiction and would be nullity since
jurisdiction cannot be conferred either by consent or by executive
instructions, if any.


In this connection, it is relevant to mention the decision of the
Supreme Court in the case of  " Kiran Singh v. Chaman Paswan
"  [ AIR 1954 S.C. 340 ] wherein Justice Venkatramma Ayyar
observed as follows:  " It is a fundamental principle well established
that a decree passed by a Court without jurisdiction is a nullity and that
its invalidity could be set up whenever and wherever it is sought to be
enforced or relied upon, even at the stage of execution and even in
collateral proceedings.


A defect of jurisdiction, whether it is pecuniary or territorial or
whether it is in respect of the subject matter of the action, strikes at the
very authority of the Court to pass any decree and such a defect cannot be
cured even by the consent of the parties"  . 

 

It is a well settled position in law, clinched by catena of
decision of tribunals and courts, that show cause notice invoking extended
period of five years under proviso to section 11 A ( I) has to be issued by
the Collector himself; otherwise, a show cause notice issued by any other
officer other than the Collector would not be legal and proceedings in
pursuance of such notice would be legally untenable as may be seen, 
 inter alia   in the following decisions: 
" Mysore Prefabs and Prefabs India v. Collector of Central Excise
"  [ 1987 ( 27) ELT 487 ] ; " Gujarat State Fertilisers
Co. Ltd. and Another v.  Union of India and Others "  [
1988 ( 34) ELT 4421 ] ; and  " H. Guru Instruments ( North India )
Put Ltd. v. Collector of Central Excise "  [ 1989 ( 40) E.L.T.
180 ( Tribunal ) ] . 

 

To sum up, this anomaly in law will be unresolved till the same
is properly interpreted by the Supreme Court or the law as it stands today is
amended by the Parliament.  <*> square</*>

CONSTITUTIONAL DEMOCRATIC STATE OF INDIA : A CRITIQUE 


 

 

FORMAL, LEGAL and institutional arrangements for the governance of
India have been laid down in great details by the Constitution of India.


The philosophy and legality underlying the Constitution establishes a
democratic, federal, secular and welfare State in India.


Carl J. Friedrich, in his classic  Constitutional Government and
Democracy  , observes:


Constitutionalism by dividing power provides a system of effective
restraints upon governmental action.


For studying it, one has to explore the methods and techniques by
which such restraints are established and maintained.


Putting it in another, more familiar, but less exact way, it is a
body of rules ensuring fairplay, thus rendering the government  `
responsible'   1  .  CONSTITUTIONAL DEMOCRATIC STATE

 

The constitutional democratic State of India is the best example
of  picture of consitutionalism.


The Indian Constitution has provided for complex web of checks and
balances to ensure  ` accountability'  and  `
responsibility'  of every public institution and public functionary.


Parliamentary democratic State ensures accountability of the
political executive and competitive politics and periodical elections, on the
basis of universal adult franchise, are meant to ensure  popular 
control over the political executive.


The political executive is dependent on the verdict of the voters and
it has to abide by the decisions of the independent Supreme Court which is
the  Guarantor  of the Constitution and the Rule of Law.    Modern State 

 R. M. MacIver, in his classic,  The Modern State  , observes
that  " Representative government distinguishes the modern State from
all other"  .  2  

 

The Indian Constitution makers established a  ` modern
State'  by evolving a scheme of representative government at the
Centre, the State and the local levels in a federal country and  essential principle, like  , is fully contained in
the Indian Constitution. 

 

Further, modern Marxist and Liberal Democratic Theories demand a
few new things from the modern States at the close of the Twentieth Century.


The Liberal Theorists evaluate a Constitutional Democratic State on
the basis of the effectiveness of the institutions of the State to protect
and promote  individual rights and justice  .


The State is a means to an end.


The development of a liberated individual is the goal of all social
institutions, including the State and autonomous civil society is an
essential condition for promotion of individual personality and
potentialities.


Edward Shils elaborates on this theme of homogenisation of the
individual and local communities by the power of the Centre which is a threat
to the peripheries.


Shils observes: 

 

The growth of national societies, of national and international
intellectual and professional communities, of ethnic communities--all of
these have grown at the cost of local communities.


The primacy of kinship, as a criterion on the basis of which
solidarity was formed, has receded.


The attachment to locality has been attenuated by the extension of
attachment to larger territories, to provincial or national territories.


There are even instances where attachment to national territories has
become very ineffectual and attachment to transnational territories and to
humanity beyond kinship, ethnicity and nationality.  3   
Limitations 

 

The Constitutional Democratic State of India operates under the
limitations of Part III of the Constitution which provides for Fundamental
Rights for individuals which protect not only the political rights but also
cultural rights of every citizen of India, including the minorities.


The Supreme Court of India, as a guardian of the constitutional
democracy, is a watchdog of Fundamental Rights of the Indian citizens.


The concept of individual rights has expanded in the Western Liberal
Democratic theory where good governance depends on deference to Human Rights
of the citizens.


Durga Das Basu observes:  " The ambit of the freedom of
religion guaranteed by Articles 25 and 26 has been widened by the judicial
interpretation that what is guaranteed by Articles 25 and 26 is the right of
 the  individual  to practise and
propagate not only matters of faith or belief but also those rituals and
observances which are regarded as integral parts of a religion by the
followers of its doctrine"  .  4  

 

Thus, the greatest human right of Indians, in a highly religious
society, which also happens to be the home of all major religions and belief
systems of the world, has been fully guaranteed by the consitutional
democratic State of India and Durga Das Basu observes:  " The
sum-total of the above provisions make our State more secular than even the
United States of Aemrica"  .  5    Human Rights as
the Yardstick 

 

Secularism in India is a necessary but not a sufficient condition
for the modern liberal theorists to accept that individual citizen in India
has enough freedom to develop his own potential. 

 

Stephen Macedo in  Capitalism, Citizenship and Community
 states that  " The authors of  Habits of the Heart  (
Robert N. Bellah, Richard Madsen, William M. Sullivan, Ann Swindler, and
Steven M. Tripton) charge that America is losing the institutions that help
to create the kind of person who could sustain a connection to a wider
political community and thus ultimately support the maintenance of free
institutions  "   .  6 


If the home of liberal democracy is castigated for crippling
individual rights, liberal democrats cannot fully accept that the Indian
State protects, preserves and promotes Human Rights.


Stephen  own position is:  " Liberals who
take Tocqueville seriously should be concerned about 
connections with larger wholes than sustain their allegiance while supporting
their individuality, their liberty, and their capacity for self-government.


It is not enough to hold out a vision of a selfless social harmony
that is incapable of attracting the energetic support of people as we know
them"  .  7  

 

The yardstick of the Western Democratic Liberals is freedom for
the individuals and the nature of the State.


Every Democratic and Constitutional State will be scrutinised on the
basis of its Human Rights record and India cannot be an exception to this
rule.


The critique of Indian State by the Indian liberals is on the basis
of the actual practice of the institutions of the State in dealing with the
issues of individual rights and justice. 

 

The European Marxist writers, like Ralph Miliband and N.
Poulantzas from 1970s and early 1980s, drew their inspiration from Italian
communist philosopher Gramsci and they have maintained that   "
 the capitalist State has ideological apparatuses and administrative
coercive apparatuses to govern for the extraction of surplus value.


Every capitalist State hegemonises on the 
basis of its ideology and the citizens are conditioned to view the capitalist
State a  ` legitimate'  .


A critique of State emerges only when we concentrate on the issues of
State Hegemony, Legitimacy and the role of the apparatuses of the State"
  8  . 

 

The sum and substance of the discussion in the preceding paras is
that the formal, legal and institutional structure of the democratic,
pluralist, federal and welfare Constitutional State of India is a framework
which is based on normative and many ethical principles with emphasis on
legality which takes care of political and social morality.


But the actual practice of the constitutional State of India cannot
be understood without focusing attention on some real processes of politics
which seem to be contrary to the images of the Constitution makers.  
Mirrors Reality of Indian Politics 

 

It was the explicit and the implicit premise of the Constitution
makers that universal adult franchise with regular elections will make a
highly apathetic and a political society quite politicised and socially
assertive.


Constitutional Democratic State of India has held ten elections to
the Lower House of the Indian Parliament and regular elections for the State
Assemblies and by 73rd Amendment of the Constitution, regular elections for
the local self-governing institutions have been made legally compulsory.


A Democratic State gains in legitimacy where people participate in
governance through regular elections and hold the political executive
accountable and  ` responsible'  to use the concept of
Friedrich and Maclver.


For Marxists, if a State has strong legitimacy, its capacities to
hegemonise its citizens increase and the coercive apparatuses of the State
are not employed in a ruthless manner to deal with  protests
and struggles.


Similarly the Western Liberal Democrats concede that States with
strong democratic and electoral legitimacy are relatively better in
protecting Human rights than the States which have weak democratic
legitimacy.


The democratic legitimacy of the Indian State has been seriously
questioned by the Liberals and the Marxists.


The Liberals in India have maintained that the election process is
completely vitiated and rigged.


The glowing corruption of the electoral process has eroded the
legitimacy of the demoratic and constitutional State of India.


The Indian political class is manufacturing electoral legitimacy
through completely unfair electoral practices.


The consitutional democratic State of India has lost its moral
foundations because it is based on manipulated and rigged electoral process.


The pillar of democratic and constitutional State of India is  vote and this pillar lies in shambles.


If elections have become illegitimate, if Indian democratic, federal
and constitutional State is also illegitimate, the 
philosophy of the Constitution makers has met with its Waterloo because of
the actual practice of Indian electoral process. 

 

The Marxists and many socially  ` marginal groups'
 who are at the  ` periphery'  of the society maintain
that the democratic State of India has been derailed because instead of
 ` negotiations'  with the deprived groups on demands, it has
become confrontational State.


The Constitution makers laid down the legal framework for  `
accommodation'  of demands of the labouring classES and cultural
minority groups.


It was expected that during the last 47 years this process of
political accommodation will get strengthened.


Unfortunately failure to accommodate has lead to a situation where
politics of coercion as concretised by the bureaucratic and police
apparatuses of the Indian State has emerged more significant than the
politics of accommodation.


This trend of suppression of emerging social asseRtions has been
growing and the Indian State had to enact the Terrorist and Disruptive
Activities ( Prevention) Act ( TADA) 0f 1985.


Not only this, the traditional police and paramilitary forces, like
the Border Security Force, the Central Reserve Police Force and Armed Police
Force of every State Government has expanded in numbers and their budgetary
allocations have increased astronomicaly.


Further, new forces like the Rapid Action Force and 30 battalions of
the Rashtriya Rifles, a new para-military arm under the Army Command, has
been created in 1994.


The reason for the establishment of new  Rashtriya Rifles 
is that the army in India is over-stretched in maintaining domestic civil law
and order.


An Army Officer, makes a telling comment on the creation of the
Rashtriya Rifles as follow:  " At present some of our boys on internal
security duties are not even managing one  rest in a week"
 .  9 


 India is witnessing growing politicisation alongwith
policisation of the society.   EXPLANATIONS FOR WEAKENING OF
CONSITUTIONAL DEMOCRATIC STATE

 

Rajni Kothari, who has combined positions of superstructural
analysis in "  Politics in India  "  10
with philosophical anarchist perspective in "  State Against
Democracy: In Search of Human Governance,  "  11 has
explained that the crisis of the constitutional State in India is
post-Nehruvian because the institutions for governance have been
delegitimised and destroyed.


If this is the explanation, then institutions for governance should
be reformed and restored back to their strength.


Political executive, bureaucracy, judiciary, Indian federalism and
all democratic institutions have been completely weakened, and in  analysis  " restoration of democratic institutions is
the need of the hour  "   .


In this philosophical-anarchist mould, Rajni Kothari observes that
the  model of Indian economic and political
development has led to the disenfranchisement of the tribals and the cultural
minority groups of India and it has led to peripheralisation of the majority
of the people.


The Indian State has lost its legitimacy because the  `
peripheral'  social groups have not been empowered to use Amartya  concept of Empowerment.


Amartya Sen has suggested that if India can spend more resources on
education, health and implement land reforms, democratic strength of India
can be restored. 


  Internal and External Vulnerability  

 

Marxist critique of the Constitutional Democratic State of India
is based on historical materialism and political economy approach.


Many streams of Marxist critique have emerged during the last 47
years.


First, India has a very  ` skewed'  market and the
absolute majority of the people do not have purchasing power.


This is a serious constraint on the political economy of the Indian
State and unless purchasing power is created by involving the labour classes
in the productive process of India, the Indian State will remain externally
and internally vulnerable.


It is a vulnerable State because it has a very narrow social base
because of the type of capitalist path of development followed by it. 
12 

 

India can resolve its multi-dimensional crises if it can tackle
 ` demand constraint'  by deepening and broadening the Indian
market.


The Indian State is in the danger of losing its sovereignty to global
capitalism if it does not address itself to the problems of rural India and
the deprivations of the working classes.


Second, a Marxist critique is rooted in the history of State
formation in India.


The Democratic and Constitutional State of India has emerged out of a
very powerful anti-colonial Third World nationalism, but it is a State in the
process of formation and it is a weak State.


The essence of this State is weaker ideological hegemony, weak
political legitimacy and fragmented and fractionalised State institutions for
governance.


This phenomenon needs explanation.  13 


  Weak Ideological Hegemony  

 

India is a multi-structural society where the India State is
building modern capitalism and modern institutions for governance on the
basis of social relations and values which belong to the past.


The present India is haunted by the legacies of the past, like caste,
community, territoriality and social exclusivity of superior-subordinate
cultural hierarchies.


The Indian State does not have ideological hegemony because India is
involved in a  basic struggle to fight against the
hangovers of the traditional identities with the values of egalitarianism,
secularism and democracy of the modern State system.


This social and cultural struggle is fundamental and it has complex
political manifestations.


If on the one hand, the modern Indian State is crippled by the
hangovers of the appeals of the historical past, on the other, economic
development of India is based on class-differentials, regional differentials,
rural-urban disparities, rich States and backward States conflicts and the
global pressures of the New World Political and economic Order.


The leader of the New World Order sees India as a  ` market'
 and it demands from the Indian State maintenance of standards of
Western values of governance.


This aspect of external dimensions of the Indian State cannot be
ignored because in the present inter-dependent and highly stratified global
power relations, the Indian State will have to respond to subtle and
sometimes open pressures of the aid-giving countries.


It is not only the ideological hegemony of the Indian State which is
weak because of the conflicts between the continuing power of the past
historical consciousness and the emerging trends of modernisation.


Such a conflict between the inherited loyalites of the past and the
weak rising forces of modernisation leades to weakening of the democratic
legitimacy of the State.


The political class has defamed and drailed the electoral process,
and the fractions and fragments of the political class have intensified
caste, and community, region and religious divisions to create a political
constituency for winning elections.


In the process, every poliltical party has become weak and
sectionalised.  14 


  Elections and Sectarianism  

 

How can Indian political executive and bureaucratic institutions
gain democratic strength when elections have become contest of sectarianism?


Political leaders have intensified sectarian violent conflicts and it
requires regular intervention and involvement of the para-military forces in
the routine governance of India.


Facts speak for themselves.


The Indian Lower House of the Parliament was informed on August 25,
1994 that the expenditure on the Border Security Force has been increasing
every successive year since 1991 and it has reached a high level of Rs.
949.13  crore  of 1993-94.


The annual expenditure on the BSF for 1991-92 was Rs. 719.24 
crore  and for 1992-93 it was Rs. 80.52  crore. 
15 


 CONCLUSION 

 

It may be mentioned that if politics and elections are reformed
along with the reform of bureaucracy and judiciary, governance of India will
be according to the spirit and not to the letter of the Indian Constitution.


While reforming the  is a necessary condition
for governance of the  country, it is not a
sufficient condition to deal with the deeper multidimensional crises of the
Constitutional Democratic State of India.


If politicisation of India is a positive sign of democratisation of
Indian society, the growing policisation is a sign of growing social
discontent in the country.


India is involved in a dialectical process of a conflict between the
positive and the negative as reflected in the democratisation of society as
well as policisation of the country.  16


Many post-Marxists, who believe in class politics, and liberal
democrats have drawn our attention to  the autonomy of the political
 .


Without going into the details of the relative autonomy of the
State, it will suffice to say that if sectarianism of politics is continued
unchecked, the State apparatus will become captive for, by and of the
dominant sectarian groups.


Such a process is at work in India which is reflected in caste 
versus  caste, community versus community, region  versus 
region and tribe  versus  tribe politics.  17


In such a situation, relative autonomy of the State becomes a
