  Participation of Workers in Management Bill,  1990   <*> line from left to right</*> 


N. RAMASWAMI, Dy. Chief Personnel Officer, Southern Railway, Madras.

 

 "   THE   plurality of
meaning reminds one of the old story of blind men coming across an elephant
on the road - - each group in the country sees the same elephant, i.e., 
" The Concept of Workers Participation "  from a
different angle.


The owners of company thinking it to be  ` snake'  - -
the trunk; the Managers  up against the landslide - - the belly;
the trade unionists  ` a tree'  - - the leg."  
  

 

The concept of  participation in management was
very confusing and we are nonetheless wiser now !


Mohtras V. G. writing in  " Labour Participation in
Management "  in 1966 itself observed that participation means
 " sharing of decision making power "  by rank and
file of an industrial organisation through proper representations at all
levels of management in the entire range of managerial action.


Decision making involves three steps: one should become aware of as
many alternatives as possible which are relevant to the decision, define each
of these alternatives and, exercise choice.


Decision making process on any level or sphere should have the scope
of the views of everyone being considered, if there is participation.


Participation means  " " having a share take part
" , etc." 


The managerial prerogatives should also be shared by everyone.


If the aim is that of Ian Clegg, then  " it implies a
situation where  representatives, to some extent, are
involved in the process of management decision making but where the ultimate
power is in the hands of Management"  .


On the other hand, if one has to follow Dr. Davis  " it is a
mental and emotional involvement of a person in a group situation which
encourages him to contribute to goals and share responsibilities in them."



In Indian context  participation is to bridge the
gap between management supremacy and  control by work place
consultation and joint consultation.


This can be illustrated as follows:  

 

As pointed out by Walker K.E in  " 
Participation in Management in practice - - An international perspective,
"  there are two basic ideas in the concept of  participation in management: two groups of people in an undertaking - -
managers and workers - - and two separate sets of functions to be performed -
- managerial and operative.


Managerial functions are distinct from operative functions and are
divorced of operative functions, i.e.,  functions.


 participation is essentially aimed at meeting the
psychological needs of workers at work.


Comte & Owen, in early days advocated the participation of workers in
management for achieving distributive social justice.


Karl Marx advocated trade unionism and 
participation as an alternative for industrial self-government. 

 

One of the references to  " Sachar Committee
"  on Companies   and M.R.T.P. Acts, 1977, is to report the measures by which ( and
at whether )  participation in the share capital and
management of the companies is to be brought about. 

 

In the evidence given before the Committee, " ASSOCHEM
" stated that labour should be given opportunity to participate
meaningfully in the ownership of capital as well as in decision making level,
where the contribution would be meaningful and useful.


But " FICCI " argued that  " it was not
advisable to rush through the legislation without properly preparing the way
by ensuring that the concept of  participation is readily
acceptable before introducing any Act  "   .


The " INTUC " advocated the  " labour are
equal partners in the establishment and, therefore, should have equal
representation, with the shareholders on the board to ensure co-determination
as is found in Germany"  .


The " ClTU " averred that it is not possible so long
as the primary motive oF production is an individual profit and also
maintained that no scheme of  participation can be
successfully implemented without changing the basic direction of economic
policies.


" CITU " , however, demand that 
representatives be given  ` equal status'  . 

 

The  " Sachar Committee "  did not
adequately answer the terms of reference like comparing with French Law where
there is some provision for setting apart a part of profit of the company.


The Committee was expected to go into the question oF incorporation
oF provisions required to be made to prevent mismanagement with reference to
safeguarding of  interests and the public interest.


However, the Committee did make some drafting changes in the
provisions of the Companies Act and suggested some changes in the procedure
and administrative machinery.


The Committee felt that their recommendations would mean meaningful
participation by workers on the boards of companies.


The Committee recommended  participation at board
level in companies with more than 1000 workmen ( as defined in the Industrial
Disputes Act ) .


They also suggested consultations regarding the proportion of
worker-directors.


The choice of worker director was to be only from amongst the workmen
with a tenure of 3 years.


To quote the  own word:  " in order to
ensure effective participation by  representatives at the
board level section 292 ( of the Companies Act ) should be amended.


Worker-director should not be barred from board meetings because of
section 299 / 380 of the Companies Act.


For proper performance, worker-directors should be given training in
commercial law, etc." 


The Committee expressed the hope  " that the participation of
workmen at the top management level in a company will lead to greater
industrial harmony <*> dotted line</*>"  

 

In December 1983 the Government introduced a comprehensive scheme
on  participation in management, operating at the shop floor
and plant levels.


The approach to Eighth Plan envisages to  base labour
relations to  participation and concern for productivity.


It is, perhaps, in this background, that the present Bill is
introduced.  


  OBJECTS OF THE BILL  

 

The objects of the Bill are based on Article 43- a of the
Constitution.


In the Statement of Objectives, it is stated,  " the
non-statutory schemes have not been able to provide an effective framework
for a meaningful participation of workers in management at all levels"
 .


The Bill is, therefore, aimed to  " provide for specific and
meaningful participation of workers in management at shop floor level,
establishment level and board of management level"  .


This would mean that at the shop floor level the elected person works
as  " manager"  and becomes an addition to the existing
persons and superceding even a supervisor!.


Perhaps, what is intended is  " specific and meaningful
participation in management of workers at shop floor level <*> dotted
line</*>"  .


In Europe, where  representation on the board is
quite common, the management structure follows the two-tier pattern initially
evolved in Germany.


Essentially, the system consists of a  ` management board'
 and  ` the advisory or supervisory board'  .


The management board consists of senior executives of the company
exercising substantial managerial powers while the supervisory / advisory
board consists of workers.


The advantages of the two-tier board over a unitary board have been
broadly accepted by the western countries.


The  " Sachar Committee "  never favoured
the two tier board itself since it raises problems of demarcating precisely
the functions of two boards in the Indian context.


The Committee felt that introducing three formal layers of authority
with inevitable overlapping would not be conducive to efficiency and quick
decision making. 

 

Management means skillful treatment and a manager is one 
" who controls a business"  .


Section 2 ( 24 ) of the Companies Act defines  ` Manager'
 as  " an individual who, subject to the supreintendence of
control and direction of the board of directors has the management of the
whole, or substantially the whole of the affairs of a company <*> dotted
line</*>"  . 

 

The preamble of the Bill deals with  " participation of
workers in the management of undertakings,  " establishments
"  or other organisations engaged in any  industry 
and to provide for <*> dotted line</*>"  . 

 

Clause 2 ( k ) of the Bill states:  " words and
expressions used but not defined in this Act and defined in the Industrial
Disputes Act, 1947 ( 14 of 1947 ) shall have the meanings respectively
assigned to them in that Act"  .


The term  ` establishment'  is covered by the Shops
and Establishments Act and not by the Industrial Disputes Act.


The term industry has attracted a number of judicial decisions.


Section 2 ( j ) of the Industrial Disputes Act reads as follows:
 " industry means any business, trade, undertaking, manufacture or
calling of employees and includes any calling, service, employment,
handicraft or industrial occupation or avocation of workmen"  .


( The term  ` workmen'  is related to industry ) .


The word  ` undertaking'  means  " anything
undertaken or any business etc." 


The widest ( wildest ! ) possible amplitude to the word  "
industry"  has been given by Krishna Iyer, J. ( and concurred in by
others ) in the seven judge bench of the Supreme Court in the famous case of
 " Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board "  [
1978 Lab-lC 467 ( SC) ] . 

 

Clause 2 ( e ) defines  ` other worker'  to mean a
worker other than a workman, while clause 2 ( i ) defines worker as  "
any person employed in any industrial establishment to do any manual,
unskilled, skilled, technical operational, clerical, supervisory, managerial
or administrative work <*> dotted line</*>" 


However,  ` workman'  is defined to mean any worker
but not a person employed in a managerial or administrative capacity; or a
person in but supervisory who draws wages exceeding Rs. 1600 per month <*>
dotted line</*>  .


Section 2 ( s ) of the Industrial Disputes Act while dealing with the
word  " workmen"  has drawn a number of court cases including
the Supreme Court.


Unlike the Industrial Disputes Act, a difference is sought to be
brought about between worker and workman in the Participation of Workers in
Management Bill.


A workman may be a worker who is not a supervisor, manager, etc. but
a worker is a person employed in managerial capacity also.


The normal connotation of the word  ` workers'  is
 " a person who works"  (  " Oxford Advanced
Learners Dictionary "  ) and a  ` workman'  is a
 " man who earns a living by physical labour or at machines, etc. or
person who works in a specified way"  .


The question that arises is - - why should there be another clause
mentioning about  ` other worker'  when a worker is other than
a workman.


The whole definition seems to create more confusion even to a layman !


 

Clause 2 ( b ) defines  ` Board of Management' 
and the links to body corporate.


 ` Body corporate'  is defined under section 2 ( 7 )
of the Companies Act.


Management of a company is always through a board.


The term  ` body corporate'  is much wider than an
undertaking, industry or establishment. 

 

Clauses 4 and 5 deal with shop councils, where 
representative will be decided and the   " modus
operandi "   of these councils.


Unless IPC is taken cognizance of, workmen may not include workwomen !


 

Clause 6, which deals with  ` Board of Management'
 would simply mean that every board of management in any industrial
establishment shall have persons to represent workmen and other workers,
subject to certain percentage. 

 

Clause 8 deals with  ` offences'  and fastens the
responsibility on the person  " incharge of and responsible to the
company for the conduct of business of the company"  .


This would mean that the  " worker", " other worker" 
or  " workman"  representative in the board or at any other
level is exempt, since they are only  " representative persons"
 and not  " worker directors"  though clause 6 ( 5 )
mentions that the representative shall exercise the powers and discharge all
the functions of a member of the board of management and shallbe entitled to
vote !


Again the question: that arises is - - will the definition of 
` Member'  under section 2 ( 27 ) of Companies Act apply ?


Under section 2 ( 27 ) of Companies Act, a member would mean a
shareholder.


If a workman who is not a shareholder of a company can become a
member of the board of management, the provisions of the Companies Act may be
violated and, therefore, every company may have to change the articles of
association with appurtinent consequences, particularly where some
qualifications have been prescribed for directors. 

 

Clause 13 lays down that the provisions of this Act shall have
effect notwithstanding inconsistencies with other Acts.


This, perhaps takes, care of section 253, 256, 259, 260 or 263 of the
Companies Act.


But what about removal of a director ?


Perhaps, the question will not arise, since the board of management
has only a representative with full powers of a director divested of
accountability. 

 

Clause 16 is the crux of the Bill.


This section states that section 



  3 of the Industrial Disputes Act
which deals with works committees shall be omitted.


These committees are like the joint production committees in U.S.A.,
Russia and Britain.


The object and purpose of these committees are three-fold - - ( a)
voluntary negotiation; ( b) mediation and conciliation; and ( c) arbitration
/ adjudication.


The main function of these committees is to secure and preserve amity
and good employer-employee relations.


They are concerned with normal day-to day working problems.


By the addition of clause 16 at the end of the Bill, it looks as
though the entire Bill is aimed at replacing these committees with a
three-tier committee.


This repeal runs contrary to the objects and reasons appended to the
Bill. 

 

Viewed from all the above angles, it is clear that the
recommendations of Sachar Committee do not seem to have been taken into
consideration.


The terms and definitions in the Bill are bound to attract
litigations and judicial inferences.  <*> square </*>

Literature : A Quest for Aesthetics of Liberty  



DR. B. GOPAL RAO

 

It is the function of the fine arts to provide us with pleasure,
but pleasure of a distinctive kind and quality.


Life offers many pleasures that are different in kind and are not here
in question.


The kind of pleasure provided by the fine arts is called aesthetic.


The term is not easy to define, and ever since Aristotle,
twentythree centuries ago, attempted to analyse the nature of the
aesthetic experience, philosophers and art critics have continued to debate
about it.


Nevertheless, even though we are as far away as ever from
understanding why the arts affect us as they do, the fact is uncontested that
in the presence of objects of art something happens to alter the quality of
our consciousness.


There is a marked intensification of the feeling-element, so marked
on occasion that it may even produce physical reactions, such as the thrill
which runs up the spine, or the inhibiting for a time of all other sensuous
experience.


The fine frenzy which possessed the artist at the moment of creation
is in some degree reproduced in the observer. 

 

Though the emotive nature of aesthetic experience is a matter of
controversy today, many would concede that the art object does induce an
evocation of the emotional side which our own experience corroborates.


Many would agree, in this regard, with what Leo Tolstoy says : 


 

To evoke in oneself a feeling one has experienced, and having
evoked it in oneself, then, by means of movements, lines, colours, sounds, or
forms expressed in words, so as to transmit that feeling that others may
experience the same feeling.


It is the activity of art <*> dotted line</*>


It is a means of union among men, joining them together in the same
feelings, and indispensable for the life and progress towards wellbeing of
individuals and of humanity.      

 

Aesthetic pleasure, then, is a function of feeling.


We have under the influence of great art a sensation of living more
abundantly.


Some deep-down levels of our personalities, normally quiescent, are
stirred so that we suddenly become more fully aware of ourselves and of the
possibilities that lie in us.


Through art the spirit of man is liberated from a concern with the
practical issues of life, and he stretches his hands towards the ideal.


As susanne K. Langer has rightly pointed out:  " Art is the
surest affidavit that feeling, despite its absolute privacy, repeats itself
in each individual life"  .    

 

Literature is concerned not only with what is, but how it came to
be what it is, and also with what it is in the process of becoming.


It compares and contrasts, seeks analogies, makes judgments, explores
the significances of things.


There are no regions of experience or speculation into which
literature does not penetrate and gather sustenance for the imagination. 

 

Among all the arts, therefore, literature, invading time and
space like a monarch, enjoys the widest franchise and wields the greatest
power.


Seeing the end in the beginning and the beginning in the end, it can
move in all directions at once.


It can bid us use our reason to follow a patient analysis of cause
and effect, or it can, in a single flash of imaginative insight, illuminate
the universe for us.


This is the reason why Indian aestheticians argue that art gives us
the privilege which only the gods and angels have: witnessing the artistic
experience without getting personally involved in it.


As Ananda Coomaraswamy discussing art in Indian life says  "
<*> dotted line</*> art reflects and answers to  every need,
whether of affirmation (   pravritti   ) or denial (
  nivritti   ) being no less for the spectator than
the artist a way (   marga   ) <*> dotted line</*>"
 .    

 

Literature is the art which helps each one of us to create for
himself a mental counterpart to the world of sense, a private universe of
thought and feeling in which one may move freely and at ease, and which for
many is far more vivid and palpable than the universe of things. 

 

Literary modes of expression are generally considered to be
cyclical alterations of human attitudes to the environment.


More often than not, it is forgotten that literature itself is an
education, a refinement of the human mind, interpreting human spirit in terms
of beauty.


Often literary categories are classified as Classicism or
Romanticism, Realism or Naturalism, without realising that these expressions
basically mean a certain kind of  endeavour on the
part of the human spirit.


The literary embellishment in which this effort is expressed has a
tendency to erect these categories as selfsufficient entities without any
relation to the basic impulses that give rise to them.


Hence we find literary discussion defining terms without realising
that ultimately they imply urges of the mind that are constantly seeking
creative selfexpression at once free and unrestricted. 

 

When the Romantic movement began to take shape with the
publication of  " The Lyrical Ballads "  , ( 1798)
of Wordsworth and Coleridge, it was taken to be a reaction to the 18th
century age of reason.


That it meant the quest for liberty which was denied by the restraint
of reason was hardly comprehended.


In fact, literature has always been a struggle to escape the bondages
under which life labours in its practical preoccupations.


It is true that on the level of day-to-day existence the
considerations of practical life have to be paramount.


But man is fundamentally an incarnate isolation, being essentially
separated from others by his corporeal individuality.


In realising and asserting this individuality lies the freedom and
authenticity of human existence.


Hence the human spirit always breaks out in rebellion against every
form of restraint and tries to be free and uncontrolled.


As we cast a glance at the literary history of the western world, we
realise that literature has always been a quest for liberty in spite of
certain periods during which restraint became the dominant note of literary
creation. 

 

The Grecian world was basically an individualistic world in spite
of the city states and the social consciousness that governed it.


Homer, Aeschylus, Sophocles, or Euripides represent the
individualistic heroism of the Greek mind achieving tragic majesty by defying
every restriction, imposed not only by the society but also by Moira, the
deity of Fate herself.


Breaking away from bondage and experiencing the highest reach of
human power in physical or spiritual spheres was the ideal that inspired the
Greek heroes.


For them the world was a prize to be conquered by the might of  own self by setting at nought the opposing will of even Zeus
himself.


This quest of might underwent a radical disintegration, during the
one Hellenistic period, when the pursuit of might turned to pursuit of
pleasure on the one hand and pursuit of ascetic cynicism on the other.


Even this expression of the self was a form of realizing  possibilities after having arrived at one ultimate in the heroic
direction.


Inevitably the Roman world brought in the Stoic restraint and the
Augustan law and order.


But the Latin literature was also a quest of realizing the
unrestricted integration that the mind is  capable of
restraint for the sake of restraint ends in literature that is without the
vitality of the spirit and turns out to be a kind of preaching or propaganda
that lacks the creative impulse. 

 

The Medieval world was essentially restricted in its theological
outlook and as a result gave rise to a Chivalric literature that sought
freedom in heroism and love.


The tension between the Medieval theology and the Chivalric impulse
constitutes one of the major illustrations of the literary urge for freedom
in spite of oppressive social bondage. 

 

The Renaissance asserted the right of man for absolute physical
freedom even to the highest tragic extent.


 plays indicated  lust for
power,  lust for knowledge, the Jew of 
lust for splendour and Hero and  lust for passion.


Unrestricted outward plunge into space from the earlier theological
confinment marked the Renaissance quest for liberty.


When this external adventure grew sadistic and masochistic, the age
of reason stepped in to control the disintegration and contribute a new
dimension in selfintegration.


By accident the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries supported the
rational orientation of integration by discovering a universe characterized
by law and order.


But it was soon realised that the restraint of integration has a
tendency to suppress the impulses and it was no surprise that the Romantic
wave set in with a view to transcending every restriction.


Wordsworth, Coleridge and Scott sought a physical orientation by
identifying themselves with the multiplicity of nature the supernatural and
the historically remote.


Byron, Shelley and Keats went still beyond and sought a spiritual
freedom through egoism, mystical love, and pagan identification with the
sensuous and the concrete.


The Romantic age indicated  essential character
to seek liberty and found that with the restraining society that was
emerging, literature was never to be at ease in the social practical sphere.


The literary man began to find himself alienated and an outsider.


 

Since the 19th century, the individual artist has realized that
he is a unique existent and that his genuiness lies not in conformity but in
authentic freedom of experience and expression.


The literature of today is basically turning to extentialism because
of the human  uncompromising quest for freedom.


It is only when we realize the character of literature as quest for
liberty that we begin to under stand the nature and dimensions of literary
terms.

christian thought, of any real depth, before the students, join the  
post graduate classes, 


Nor is there any serious attention, to the history of ideas,  
or evolution of the western culture, is Greek or Roman Christian texture  
<,> 


Any knowledge of Greek and Latin, or even a gentle fascination  
for them, , is nowhere in sight, 


Again, there is no knowledge or sense of the genuises, rise  
evolution and decay of the stars of epic, tragedies, romance,  
allegory etcetera, 


Nor is there a critical awareness, or    discussions  , or the matters involved in the study of  
the classics, among the extremist either, 


In short as far the teaching of the classics is concerned, you  
are working in a thorough vacuum, 


Though your  nature, may abhor it, 


If you have to reach the students with your classics, in your uh  
<,> ah in your hand, you have to undertake the adventure, of piercing  
through a silence of seven-fold or nine-fold, or manifold ignorance, 


But should you despair and give up the sword of teaching, then  
as a sheer wild goose chase, 


 an emphatic " no " to say to this  
pessimism, 


It is possible to put those classics across, to the students,  
Indian students, not because they are the  or credilous  
<,> but because, the classics have an intrensic power, in themselves  
<,> on the one hand, and students have an intrensic an instinctive  
responsiveness, to them on the other, 


Should a classic fail,  a pity, 


Something must be wrong either with the teacher, or with the  
student, and between them they have missed an opportunity of a life-time  
<,,> 


It is a challenge for any teacher, to steer an ancient classic  
through successfully, in a class without being assisted by a cultivated  
response in it, 


But I think the solution to the problem should  divide  
another way, 


Instead of being exasperated by a classical innocent class, a  
teacher has to exploit the virgin field, and convert innocence into an  
advantage, 


The basic wealth, he should realize, lies in the  
responsiveness of the class to any literature, our literature, British  
or  own, 


Once  sure of the aesthetic or literary sensibility  
<,> so he can find a way for the classic into the imagination of his students  
<,,> 


When I say that a literary awareness is the most vital factor, I  
do not employ that a classic should be reduced to an, easily knowable text  
<,,> 


The teacher should have a complex economy at his command, 


He must know, uh the right dosage of each element, before he  
administers a classic, to the open minded , students of  
the class, 


Were one, to teach for example,  "  
Illiad " I,  taken just one example, 


One must know how much of the theory of the epic of growth, or  
archeology, he must give to his students, 


If you get lost in the theory of the oral or authentic epic, you  
may not reach Homer at all, 


On the contrary, you may raise serious suspicion, in the  
minds of the students, whether a poet called Homer ever existed at all, 


Having introduced the term authentic, oral epic, you gently  
pass on to the Homeric age, or the heroic age, not as a fossil of  
history, but as a genuine milieu for the creation and sustenance of the  
kind of epic that " Illiad " is, 


If the students know nothing of the heroic age, Achilles would  
cut an utterly sorry figure before them, a spoiled child, a wilful  
imbecile, 


Personal honour then was supreme, and dying for glory, the  
consummation  devastly  wished, by a hero was his name, 


The co-ordinates of the age, co-ordinate, coincide with the  
co-ordinates of the morality of the hero, 


The Lords have donned a heroic society, have to be    accepted   in a spirit of willing suspension of  
disbelief, or of a voluntary poetic accent, 


By this, the epic is saved an enormous infancy, of  
primitivity, 


With a select historisity in mind, you go straight to the human  
condition, 


So that given, differing historical co-ordinate, 


There is an unerring core of the human fate involved, 


Once the right key note is struck the classic is preserved, 


Similarly you have to introduce them, to the rules of the epic  
game, the conventions, the invocation, the catalogues of men and  
ships and so on, 


The strolling epic simile, the ruthlessly delightful  
battlefields, the feudal games, the lamentations etcetera, 


And then the gods, their politics, their devious ways,  
their over-determinations of human affairs, and  constant  
negotiations, with them, 


The supernatural frame-work, not to be reduced to the  
supernatural machinery, that they use  but to be kept,  
as a mysterious divine environment in which man has to struggle, rise  
afore, 


You have to identify and establish, the force of gravity,  
that holds in tension, the fears of men, 


All this has to be done not in a spirit of solemn scholarship,  
but as a matter of enlighten information, to hinder the hindrances, to  
enjoying such works, 


But this is only half the work, 


You have to get the work closer to the world of the  own experience, or sensibility, 


I have been trying to do this, task not by denuding Homer of its  
specific, but by gathering him to a vision of what I might describe, as  
 perennial, 


The perennial poetry, which refuses to divide poetic experience  
or vision in a parochial way and reduce, reduce it, to a  parochialist, uh provincial poetry, 


Explain the unknown Homer, in terms of the known, of  
" the Upanishadas, the Vedas, the Bhagwatgeetas, the  
Mahabharat, and the Ramayan and the Bhagwat ", 


Do not tell me that our own works, are less known to our  
students, than the western classics, 


I have been doing, in this way, from long before the , had serialised " the Mahabharat ", and "  
the Ramayan ", 


Our work, the culture that they are embodiments of, our  
already embedded in the instinctive responses of our students, 


And they have to be carefully and convincingly evoked by the  
teacher, 


Let me give just a couple of examples, in a characteristically  
comprehensive Homeric statement, 


In the thick of the battle, Dimades challenges Glocus and Glocus  
replies what does any lineage matter to you, 


Men in the generations, are like the leaves of the tree, 


The wind blows, and one years leaves are scattered on the ground  
<,> but the tree is burst into buds, and put on fresh ones, when the  
spring comes round, 


In the same way, one generation flourishes and the another nears  
its end, 


This, inevitably reminded me of the statement from the "  
Katho Upanishad ",  Satya mevap madhya pakshatye sasya mev  
tasya mev ajayte punha  


The muscle hyphens and, ripens, ends like corn, and stalks  
up again like corn, 


The metaphor of the leaves in Homer, corresponds greatly with  
metaphor of the corn, in the " Katho Upanishad ", 


And both bring out, vividly and crystalize the phenomenon of  
mutability, 


The cycle of birth death and rebirth, 


The Homeric metaphor, as that of the Upanishadic, unites  
human experience, so effectively that you cease to separate the west from  
the east, and start inhabiting a common state of human faith, 


To cite another example from the " Illiad " itself  
<,> here is Andromache " Illiad book six ", trying to  
persuade her husband Hector not to go to the fatal battlefield, 


 So you Hector, are father and mother, and brother to  
me, as well as my beloved husband, 


Have pity on me now, stay here on the  tar  , 


Put beside this, a statement from the " Ramayana  
", made by Seeta as a confession of  love for her  
<,> before Anusuya, 


This is Ayodhyakand " one eighteen " four, uh  
 Seetanurago dharmatma matrivat pitravat priyah , 


With this kind of a parallel, so this is I think you will know  
this Sanskrit, I mean the student, 


Seeta in love, righteous, dear like the father the mother, 


With the kind of a parallel in mind, you do not wish to separate  
the two works, the two culture, and see them in isolation, a bridge  
is flown across the two, 


And the one text reinforces and illuminates the other, the  
phobia that a stranger  is dissipated, and an Indian  
reader student teacher is gratified, that a common humanity pervades text  
apparently separated by differing cultures, and languages, 


When I say this, I am not way laying the students, into the  
phony field of the comparative literature, as such but only knocking down  
walls or barriers that separates two literatures, 


It is a matter of, of nativising,  an alien  
literature, not by sipping it of its specifics, but by opening a new  
channel of communication, 


So many problems of interpretation, both literary and  
theological, can be lightened by calling to aid works like " the  
Mahabharat, Ramayan, Bhagwat " and pressing them , into service to gain and access into a pre-Christian  
work, like " Illiad " which raises insoluble problems in  
the mind of western Christian reader, 


I have tried to put across " Illiad ", without  
tearing off its Roman roots, to my students by a free use of material,  
from our ancient texts, 


The benefit has been double if not multiple, 


Our students have freely enter the western classics with a native  
appreciation of them, on the one hand and  seen the relevance  
<,> and significance of our own work, on the other, 


There was a time when the professor of English, looked down  
upon our works, in a bid to  outer  English to English, 


Those days, I wish to believe, are behind us, but that  
also implies a responsibility, a need to emancipate oneself from  
bookishness, into a heaven of genuine learning, 


 been tackling works like the " Illiad,  
Paradise Lost, The Divine Comedy ", with an amount of freedom  
to release the classics from the prison of impenetrability, or mere tacit  
riven, and make them speak to us as living works, 


 also been trying to light up areas of darkness,  
in interpreting our own works, like " the Mahabharat, Ramayan  
the Bhagwat " all these, or the " Bhagwatgeeta "  
by a constant reference to the " Illiad, the Aeneid Paradise Lost  
or The Divine Comedy " so that, a new discourse is generated,  
by the free jostling together, of great works, 


This has helped remove, to a great extent, the grimness,  
or the the gravity, the solemnity that seem to weigh upon our own works  
<,> fallen on the trodden ways of orthodoxy, 


The use of the Bible, both the old and the new Testament,  
the entire western mystical tradition, uh, has been of great benefit in  
the interpretation of our own works, too, 


Here again the walls of prejudice and wooden scholarship collapse  
<,> and the great work starts becoming parts of the same space, the  
aesthetic and the ethical, 


 also been getting, appreciable success bringing  
together the Greek and the Shakespearian tragedies, 


Understanding a Greek phenomenon with a Shakespearian example,  
or vice-versa, 


Should I read more, and be conversant with Sanskrit drama, I  
hope to understand the more by a kind of a cross irradiation, 


What  uh been doing with the ancient classics,  
classics should be possible, with the post- renaissance, modern, and  
post-modern works too, 


But one needs to be sailing the razor edge path of one if one were  
not to mess up things, 


This kind of activity needs a great expansion of mind, an  
intellectual tolerance, that makes holding many peaks of excellance or  
phenomenon of significance together, simultaneously without reducing or  
abolishing the uniqueness of each, 


I also felt always, that a teacher needs to be free from any  
obsession, with one particular theory of literature, or, or  
criticism 


If    they   want to save themselves  
from the dangers of distortion, 


At the same time, he must be fully aware of the whole plethora  
of the theory, so that he is able to make use  of  them freely,  
even as an electronics engineer, uses a thousand of keys, to produce a  
unified effect, 


I may however say that my key to the classics is only a key, a  
key, and I do not know of a master-key, which can unlock, uh the  
treasures, of all literature, 


I do not exactly know, where I stand as regard to theme of the  
lecture series, creative writing and literature teaching interphase, 


But this much I can say, that literature teaching is not,  
much less creative, than creative writing itself, 


In fact, you create as you teach, 


And a creative work unless it is creatively read, remains just  
a close book, it does not become a text, to borrow a term from Burke  
<,,> 


It is a teacher, who stigmaties to teach a text, can really  
transform it into what it really is, a text, which requires, as  
Burke would say, an attempt to abolish, or atleast to lessen the  
distance between writing and reading, not by intensifying the readers,  
projection, into the work but by linking the two together, in a single  
signifying process, 


A teacher, if he succeeds, does reduce the distance between  
writing and reading, 


He rewrites the works, and reincarnate the text, everytime  
<,> he successfully performs, in a class, 


Thank you,

AN EASTERN PROMISE


 


An easy-to-follow guide to exotic Indian cuisine  <O>


 by MRIDULA BALJEKAR   
 


  SPICY PINEAPPLE PUNCH  

 

( A lovely drink to welcome your guests, serve it warm before
lunch, especially at Christmas time, or enjoy it chilled with the barbecue
during the long, warm summer evenings.) 


  Serves: Four 


Time required: 35 minutes


225 ml. water


500 ml. pineapple juice


12.5 cm. cinnamon, broken into pieces


6 cloves


6 green cardamoms, bruised


1 1/2 tsp. ( 7 g.) fresh mint leaves, chopped


90 ml. brandy 

 

PUT the water, half the pineapple juice, cinnamon, cloves,
cardamom and mint into a saucepan.


Bring to the boil, cover the pan and simmer gently for 20 minutes.


 

Remove from the heat and allow to cool.


Keep the pan covered. 

 

Strain the drink and add the remaining pineapple juice and the
brandy.


Mix well. 


 Nutritive value of each serving:


Calories: 167.9 kcal.


Proteins: 1.5 g.


Fat: 0.87 g.


Minerals: 1.3 g.


Fibre: 1.2 g.


Carbohydrates: 24.9 g. 


  MEAT  SAMOSAS   

 

( The ever popular  samosas  make a wonderful
treat on any occasion.


In India,  samosas  are a familiar sight at wedding
receptions and cocktail parties.) 


 Makes: 16  samosas 


Time required: One hour 10 minutes plus cooling time


For the filling:


2 tbsp. ( 30 ml.) oil


2 ( 110 g.) onions, chopped fine


225 g. lean lamb or beef mince


4 flakes ( 8 g.) garlic, crushed


1.5 cm. ginger, grated fine


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) turmeric powder


2 tsp ( 10 g.) coriander powder


1 1/2 tsp. ( 7 g.) cummin powder


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) chilli powder


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) salt or to taste


125 ml. warm water


150 g. frozen green peas


2 tbsp. ( 30 g.) desiccated coconut


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) garam masala powder


2 green chillies, chopped fine ( deseeded if a milder falvour is
preferred)


20 g. coriander leaves, chopped


1 tbsp. ( 15 ml.) lemon juice


For the pastry ( for the covering):


225 g. flour


50 g. ghee or butter


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) salt


75 ml. warm water


oil for deep frying


To prepare the filling: 

 

HEAT the oil over medium heat and fry the onions till light
brown.


Add the mince, garlic and ginger.


Stir-fry over low heat until almost dry.


Add the turmeric powder, coriander powder, cummin powder, chilli
powder and salt.


Stir-fry until the mince is lightly browned.


Add the water and the green peas and bring to the boil.


Cover and simmer for 25 to 30 minutes.


If there is any liquid left, remove the lid and cook the mince over
medium heat until it is completely dry, stirring frequently.


Stir in the desiccated coconut, garam masala powder, green chillies
and coriander leaves. 

 

Remove from heat and add the lemon juice.


Cool thoroughly before filling the  samosas  . 


  To prepare the pastry:  

 

Add the butter and salt to the flour.


Rub in well.


Add enough warm water to mix a soft dough.


Knead until the dough feels soft and velvety to the touch.


Divide the dough into eight portions and roll into 10 cm. discs.


Cut each into two.


Roll each semicircle of the pastry to make an envelope.


Moisten the straight edge with a little warm water.


Fold the semicircle of the pastry in half to form a triangular cone.


Join the straight edges by pressing them hard into each other.


Make sure that there are no gaps. 

 

Fill these cones with the prepared filling, leaving about 1/2 cm.
border on the top of the cone.


Now moisten the top edges and press them hard together. 

 

Deep fry the  samosas  in hot oil over gentle heat
until they are golden brown  and drain on absorbent paper. 


  Nutritive value of each  samosas  : 


Calories: 200.7 kcal.


Proteins: 5.6 g.


Fat: 13.3 g.


Minerals: 0.55 g.


Fibre: 1.2 g.


Carbohydrates: 13.7 g. 


 


CHICKEN  CHAAT   

 

( Cubes of chicken meat, stir-fried with a light coating of
spices, impressive with a colourful salad and taste superb.) 


 


Serves: Four 


Time required: 25 minutes


700 g. chicken breast, skinned and deboned


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) salt or to taste


3 flakes ( 6 g.) garlic, coarsely chopped


2 tbsp. ( 30 ml.) oil


1 1/2 tsp. ( 7 g.) coriander powder


1/4 tsp. ( 1 g.) turmeric powder


3/4 tsp. ( 4 g.) chilli powder


4 tsp. ( 20 ml.) lemon juice


30 g. coriander leaves, chopped fine 

 

WASH the chicken and dry on absorbent paper.


Cut into 2.5 cm. cubes.


Add salt to the garlic and crush to a smooth pulp. 

 

Heat the oil in a frying pan, preferably a non stick or cast
iron, over medium heat.


Add the garlic and fry until it is lightly browned.


Add the chicken and fry for about seven minutes stirring constantly.


Add coriander powder, turmeric powder and chilli powder.


Fry for four minutes, stirring frequently.


Remove from heat and stir in the lemon juice and chopped coriander
leaves. 

 

Serve as a starter, garnished with crisp lettuce leaves, sliced
cucumber, raw sliced onion and wedges of lemon or with a selection of 
chutneys  .


Chicken  chaat  can also be served with drinks on
cocktail sticks, hot or cold.  


Nutritive value of each serving:


Calories: 284.3 kcal.


Proteins: 46.3 g.


Fat: 9.2 g.


Minerals: 2.7 g.


Fibre: 1.5 g.


Carbohydrates: 3.6 g.     


  CHICKEN LIVER  MASALA   

 

( Curried liver, quite popular with the Muslims in India, is
made more interesting by adding diced potatoes and frozen green peas.) 


  Serves: Four 


Time required: 55 minutes


450 g. chicken liver


4 tbsp. ( 60 ml.) oil


1 ( 70 g.) onion, chopped fine


5 cm. cinnamon, broken into pieces


225 g. potatoes, peeled and diced


1 1/4 tsp. ( 6 g.) salt or to taste


90 ml. warm water


4 flakes ( 8 g.) garlic, crushed


1 small tin of tomatoes


100 g. frozen green peas


3 green chillies


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.)  garam masala  powder


Mix to a paste with two tsp. ( 10 ml.) water.


2 tsp. ( 10 g.) coriander powder


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) cummin powder


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) turmeric powder


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) chilli powder 

 

CLEAN the liver, remove all the skin and gristle, and cut
roughly into 1.5 cm. pieces.


Heat two tbsp. oil over medium heat and fry the onions and cinnamon
until the onions are soft.


Add the potatoes and 1/4 tsp. ( 1 g.) salt and stirfry the
potatoes for about two minutes.


Add the water.


Cover the pan and simmer until the potatoes are tender. 

 

Heat the remaining oil over medium heat in a heavy bottomed wide
pan.


A non stick or cast iron pan is ideal as the liver needs to be
stir-fried over high heat.


Add the garlic and stir-fry for 30 seconds.


Add the spice paste, lower the heat and stir-fry for about two
minutes.    

 

Add half of the tomatoes, along with some of the juice, stir and
cook for a further two to three minutes, breaking the tomatoes with the
spoon. 

 

When the mixture is fairly dry, add the liver and adjust heat to
medium high.


Stir-fry the liver for three to four minutes.


Add the remaining tomatoes and the juice, stir-fry for five to six
minutes. 

 

Cover the pan and simmer for about eight minutes.


Add the potatoes, green peas, green chillies and the remaining salt
and cook for a minute or two.


Adjust heat to medium and cook, uncovered, for further five minutes.


Stir in the  garam masala  powder and remove from
heat. 

 

Serve with plain fried rice or  chapaties  or
 rotis  and  saagwala dal  . 


  Nutritive value of each serving: 


Calories: 194.0 kcal.


Proteins: 8.5 g.


Fat: 5.1 g.


Minerals: 1.9 g.


Fibre: 4.7 g.


Carbohydrates: 28.2 g. 


   KHEEMA MATTER   

 

( Lean mince is combined with garden peas and ground almonds and
garnished with sliced hard-boiled eggs to make an attractive and delicious
dish.) 


  Serves: Four 


Time required: 55 minutes


6 tbsp. ( 90 ml.) oil


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) cummin seeds


2 red chillies


450 g. lean lamb or beef, minced


1 large ( 70 g.) onion, chopped fine


2.5 cm. ginger, grated fine


4 flakes ( 8 g.) garlic, crushed


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) turmeric powder


2 tsp. ( 10 g.) coriander powder


1 1/2 tsp. ( 7 g.) cummin powder


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) chilli powder


1 small tin of tomatoes or 3-4 ( 200 g.) fresh tomatoes, skinned and
chopped


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) salt or to taste


1 tbsp. ( 15 ml.) curd


175 ml. warm water


1 ( 60 g.) potato, peeled and cubed ( optional)


100 g. shelled fresh or frozen green peas


1 tbsp. ( 15 g.) almonds, ground to a paste


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.)  garam masala  powder


2 eggs, hard-boiled and sliced


25 g. coriander leaves, chopped 

 

HEAT one tbsp. oil over medium heat and season with cummin
seeds.


Add the red chillies and then the mince.


Stir and cook until the mince is evenly browned. 

 

Heat the remaining oil over medium heat and add the onions.


Stir-fry till the onions are soft.


Add the ginger and garlic and stir-fry for a further two to three
minutes.


Stir in the turmeric powder and then the coriander powder, cummin
powder and chilli powder.


Add the tomatoes along with all the juice, and saute for four
minutes.


Add the mince and cook for eight minutes, stirring frequently.


Add the salt and water and stir in the curd.


Add potato cubes, if using them.


Cover the pan and simmer for 20 minutes. 

 

Add the frozen peas and simmer for a further 10 minutes.


If using fresh peas, boil until tender before adding to the mince.


Stir in the ground almonds and simmer for two minutes.


Remove from heat and stir in the  garam masala 
powder. 

 

Transfer onto a serving dish and arrange the sliced eggs on top.


Garnish with the coriander leaves. 

 

Serve with  chapatis, parathas  and/ or fried
brown rice and potato  raita  . 


  Nutritive value of each serving: 


Calories: 550.9 kcal.


Proteins: 36.7 g.


Fat: 37.1 g.


Minerals: 3.6 g.


Fibre: 5.0 g.


Carbohydrates: 16.8 g. 


  GREEN BEANS IN GARLIC BUTTER  

 

( Tender green beans, cooked in their own juice, make a
mouth-watering accompaniment to any rich meat, fish or poultry dish.) 


  Serves: Four 


Time required: 15 minutes


25 g. unsalted butter 


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) cummin seeds


4 flakes ( 8 g.) garlic, crushed or finely chopped


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) chilli powder


450 g. frozen whole green beans


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) salt or to taste 

 

MELT the butter over low heat and season with cummin seeds.


Add the garlic and fry for one minute.


Add the chilli powder and immediately follow with the beans.


Stir-fry for a minute.


Add the salt and mix thoroughly.


Cover the pan and simmer the beans in their own juice until they are
tender for 10 to 12 minutes, stirring occasionally.


Remove from the heat. 

 

Serve with chicken  korma  , fish 
shahjahani  or  murghi badami  . 

 

For a variation, add cauliflower cut into small flowerettes,
instead of the beans. 


  Nutritive value of each serving: 


Calories: 81.6 kcal.


Proteins: 2.3 g.


Fat: 5.3 g.  


Minerals: 0.83 g.


Fibre: 2.3 g.


Carbohydrates: 6.2 g. 


   ALOO KI BHAJI   

 

( Boiled potatoes, diced and braised with a few whole spices and
onions make a quick and easy side dish.) 


  Serves: Four 


Time required: 40 minutes


700 g. potatoes


6 tbsp. ( 90 ml.) oil


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) mustard seeds


3 red chillies


a pinch of fenugreek ( methi) seeds


225 g. onions, sliced fine


2 green chillies, sliced lenghtwise ( and deseeded if a milder
flavour is preferred)


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) turmeric powder


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) salt or to taste


25 g.


coriander leaves, chopped 

 

BOIL the potatoes in their jackets and allow to cool thoroughly.


( Boiled potatoes can be left for a day or    two in the refrigerator.)


Peel and dice them evenly. 

 

Heat the oil over medium heat in a wide shallow pan and season
with mustard seeds.


When they splutter, add the red chillies and fenugreek seeds,
immediately follow with the onions and green chillies.


Fry the onions for about 10 minutes or until they are golden brown.


Add the turmeric powder, potatoes and salt.


Stir-fry gently until the potatoes are heated through or for 10
minutes.


Remove from heat and sprinkle the coriander leaves over. 

 

Serve with  puris  or  loochis  to
make a substantial snack or as a side dish with rice, chicken or meat curry.



  Nutritive value of each serving: 


Calories: 420.6 kcal.


Proteins: 4.5 g.


Fat: 23.5 g.


Minerals: 1.8 g.


Fibre: 2.8 g.


Carbohydrates: 48.5 g. 


  SPICED GREEN BEANS  

 

( Sliced green beans are braised with a few spices then tossed
in roasted, ground sesame seeds to create the unique flavour of this dish.)



  Serves: Four 


Time required: 30 minutes


2 tbsp. ( 30 g.) sesame seeds


3 tbsp. ( 45 ml.) oil


1/4 tsp. ( 1 g.) mustard seeds


6 flakes ( 12 g.) garlic, chopped fine


2 red chillies, coarsely chopped


1/2 tsp. ( 2 g.) turmeric powder


1 tsp. ( 5 g.) coriander powder


450 g. frozen sliced green beans, defrosted and drained   


3/4 tsp. ( 4 g.) salt or to taste


1 tbsp. ( 15 g.) desiccated coconut 

 

HEAT an iron griddle or a heavy bottomed pan over medium heat
and dry-roast the sesame seeds until they are lightly browned, stirring
constantly.


Transfer them to a plate and allow to cool. 

 

Heat the oil over medium heat and season with mustard seeds.


When they splutter, add the garlic and fry till light brown.


Add the red chillies, turmeric powder and coriander powder.


Stir briskly and add the beans and salt.


Saute well.


Lower the heat and cover the pan tightly.


Cook until the beans are tender or for 15 to 20 minutes, stirring
occasionally. 

 

Grind the sesame seeds and the coconut in the coffee grinder and
stir into the beans.


Remove the pan from the heat. 

 

Serve with chicken  tikka masala, murgh musallam 
or  shahi korma  . 


  Nutritive value of each serving: 


Calories; 215.7 kcal.


Proteins: 4.5 g.


Fat: 17.8 g.

Methodologies for Environmental Monitoring   


 S. Hasan and P.K. Mathur 


 Lucknow University, Department of Chemistry, Lucknow - 226 001


 

 The information currently available on the status of
environmental pollution have been directly dependent on the advances made in
analytical techniques.


" Organic and inorganic toxic pollutants " are
generally present in micro and submicro quantities in the environment and
their determination at these level needs accurate, precise and sensitive
analytical techniques.


Some of the techniques used for environmental pollutants are based
on spectrophotometry, chromatography, polorography, mass
spectrophotometry, spectrofluorometry, ion selective electrodes and neutron
activation.


The selection of analytical technique depends on the expected level
and characteristics of the environmental pollutants.   <&> in two
columns  


  INTRODUCTION  

 

Environmental pollutants are discharged into air, water and soil
from anthrapogenic activity and depending on their characteristics, they
form an equlibrium between them.


Monitoring of environmental pollutants needs effective sampling
procedure and precise, sensitive and accurate analytical techniques.


Proper selection of sampling locations, preservation of samples and
analytical methodology are the important aspects of environmental
monitoring.


Sampling methods, and preservation of samples differ from one
component of environment to another.


Pretreatment of samples before using an appropriate technique also
differs for    various   components of
environment. 


  WATER QUALITY MONITORING  

 

Monitoring of pollutants in water starts from its sampling and
is based on the results of the analysis of the samples taken from a
particular site.


The monitoring results are actually indicative of the quality
of water sample under investigation rather than the water body from where the
sample is taken.


If water is of relatively uniform composition in both time and space
then any sample will suffice.


However, if the sample is nonuniform at sampling site or its
composition varies with time, then no single sample is truely representative.


Monitoring requires that water samples are collected at intervals so
that no change in quality could pass unnoticed.


The observed value and true value always differs due to various
reasons.


The larger the number of samples from which the mean is derived, the
narrower is the limit of the probable difference.


However, the sampling schedule is a compromise between accuracy
and facilities available for the work.


It is always advantageous to measure the pollutants   in
situ   by means of sensors which are lowered into the water
bodies rather than withdrawing samples.


This is not always possible and the samples are to be collected in
suitable containers.


Borosilicate glass or polyethylene bottles are suitable for sample
collection. 

 

Maintaining the integrity of the pollutants is an essential
pre-requisite for any monitoring programme.


Once the sample is taken the constituents of the sample must stay
in the same condition as collected.


Effective preservation method is, therefore, needed to find valid
data from monitoring.


Most of the chemical parameters can be preserved from one day to
14 day by storing the sample under refrigeration at 4 <*> degrees</*>C.


Trace metals may be preserved upto 6 month by adding 2 ml of
concentrated nitric acid per litre of sample so that pH goes below 2.


Only mercury requires 2 ml / l of 20 % potassium dichromate
solution prepared in 50 % nitric acid.


Phenol needs 6 ml of 6N sodium hydroxide solution per litre water so
that pH is above 12 and refrigeration at 4 <*> degrees</*>C for 24 hr
preservation.


Organics are preserved by storing water samples under
refrigeration at 4 <*> degrees</*>C for 7 to 14 day depending on their
nature.


However, it is advisable to extract the organics into suitable
organic solvent within 24 hr and then preserve the organic extracts under
refrigeration at 4 <*> degrees</*>C.


Certain specific compounds need special preservation which depends
on their chemical properties.


Preservation of sample is a very important step in water quality
monitoring and it should be strictly adhered to.  


  AIR QUALITY MONITORING  

 

Monitoring of pollutants in ambient air needs proper choice of
sampler.


For monitoring of metals adsorbed on the suspended particulate
matter, a high volume sampler is the most suitable choice.


A portion of the filter paper used for the determination of SPM is
cut and the metal is extracted in nitric acid which is used for metals
determination.


Gaseous pollutants are sampled in impingers with appropriate
adsorption solution.


The gaseous pollutants having acid nature need alkali solution as
the ultimate choice and for gases with alkali characteristics, the choice
is acid solution.


Mercury need acidic dichromate solution while pesticides need n -
hexane as trapping solution.


Recording of meterological data, like wind direction, wind speed,
temperature, relative humidity, etc., is essential.


Accurate flow measurement of sampling is most important.


Now-a-days automatic monitoring instruments based on infra-red
spectrophotometry, chemuluminiscence, conductivity and other
physico-chemical properties are also available for the monitoring of
gaseous pollutants. 


  ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING TECHNIQUES  

 

The requirement of the analytical technique selected for
determination of a pollutant in the environment is its capability to detect
and determine it at extremely low concentrations.


The technique should prferably be applicable to the sample
directly and be capable of yielding information on the nature of the species
present.


It is also desirable that the technique requires bare minimum
sample treatment to avoid contamination and subsequent enhancement of
blank values.


Some of the techniques used in environmental monitoring are described
here under. 


  Atomic spectrometry  

 

Atomic spectrometric methods have contributed significantly
towards environmental pollution monitoring studies on heavy metals.


Some of them have excellent detection limits and minimum
interference effects.


However, the technique is incapable of yielding information on the
species of the metals.


This technique determines the total concentration of the metals.


More than 60 elements can be determined at solution concentrations
between 0.1 and 100 <*> mu</*>g / l.


Atomic adsorption spectrophotometry is still the method of choice
for the analysis of environmental samples and both flame and non-flame
methods have been used for environmental monitoring.


The senstivity of the flame atomic adsorption spectrophotometry
is, however, not high enough to detect most of the trace metals at levels
they are normally present in the environment.


The sensitivity of the method may be enhanced by using the method of
complexation coupled with organic solvent extraction.


These additional steps, however, make the techniques time
consuming and sometimes increases blank values.


The flame atomic absorption spectrophotometry is suitable for major
elements, like " irom " , " manganese " ,
" copper " , " zinc " , etc., which
generally occur in the environment at concentrations which lie in the
sensitivity range of flame " AAS " technique ( Hasan and
Pande, 1978 ) . 

 

Flameless atomic absorption methods are most suitable for the
determination of trace metals, like " arsenic " , "
cedmium " , " chromium " , " cobalt
" , " nickel " , " lead " ,
" salenium " , etc.


The technique requires very small sample volume and has extremely
low detection limit.


This technique has, however, the problem of matrix interference which
are quite severe and at the atomization stage non-specific absorption can
be very significant ( Hasan and Pande, 1988a, 1983 b ) .


The matrix interference can be removed either by platform technique
or by matrix modification.


In the former a small graphite platform is placed inside the tube
and the sample is introduced on the platform.


The platform is treated primarily by radiation from the furnace
resulting in lower temperature in platform as compared to the temperature of
the tube wall.


This reduces the interference by lowering the rate of condensation of
analyte and recombination of atomic species. 

 

Matrix modification methods have been extensively used for the
determination of trace metals in water and wastewater.


It was observed that the addition of molybdenum minimizes several
interferences ( Henn, 1977 ) while addition of nitric acid decereases
non-specific absorption caused by sodium and potassium chloride ( Tanaka
 et al  ., 1978 ) .


Interference in the determination of lead and cadmium has been
successfully removed by the addition of aluminium ( Panda and Pendarkar, 1980 ) .


Addition of a mixture of ascorbic acid and ammonium nitrate
removes the interferences due to alkali metals, alkaline earth metals and
anions in the determination of manganese ( Kumar  et al  ., 1986 ) .


Determination of trace metals of environmental significance  has been reviewed ( Kumar  et al  .,
1987 ) .


Cold vapour atomic absorption spectrophotometry using the method
described by Hatch and Ott ( 19 68 ) and modified by Uthe  et al  .
( 1970 ) is most suitable for the determination of mercury.


The method involves wet acid digestion of the sample, followed
by reduction, aeration and measurement of mercury vapour absorption at 253.7
nm. 


  Plasma emission spectrometry  

 

A plasma is a gas whose significant portion is ionized and
thus large quantities of electrical energy can be transferred to it.


This source is, therefore, capable of atomization and excitation of
metals.


Based on this principle an inductively coupled plasma ( ICP )
source was developed.


This source is an electrodeless argon plasma formed at atmospheric
pressure and sustained by inductive coupling to high frequency magnetic
fields ( Fassel, 1978 ) .


Later on direct current plasma ( DCP ) which is an electrical
discharge maintained by a core consisting of a continuous " DC
" arc and stabilized by flowing gas, was also developed ( Andrew,
1982 ) .


Plasmas provide excellant "
vaporization-atomization-excitation-ionization " sources
for analytical atomic emission spectropcopy.


Plasma emission spectrometry is rapidly taking the position of atomic
absorption spectrophotometry.


The inter-element interactions are small or insignificant for
reasonable changes in the concentrations of concomitants under
experimental conditions.


It is possible to establish a single set of calibration curves for
the detection of analytes in a variety of sample matrices.


Spectral interferences are common in these techniques, however,
these may be reduced by judicious selection of the line to be used.


These techniques provide direct analysis of solid, liquid and
gasseous pollutants with minimal sample preparation ( Walter  et al  .,
1980 ) . 


  Colorimetry  

 

" Colorimetric " methods are very frequently
used in environmental monitoring and these methods were the only official
methods of determination three decades ago.


These methods are based on the formation of colour complexes with
the pollutants and then determining the absorbance of the colour which
ultimately gives the concentration of the pollutante.


Methods based on this technique have been described in standard
methods for the examination of water and wastewater ( APHA, AWWA, WPCF,
1992 ) .


These are universal methods and can be used for inorganic as well as
organic pollutants.


These methods have, however, the problems of non-specificity and
inferior sensitivity.


Colorimetric methods have got several advantages also as they do
not need sophisticated instruments or high skill and can be performed with
some specific chemicals and a simple spectrocolorimeter.


Extensive literature is available on these techniques and on
certain occasions when no other methods are available, one has to depend
on these methods only.


The sensitivity may be poor but accuracy and precision are
superior to other techniques. 


  Polarography  

 

It is an electroanalytical technique, in which the intensity of
diffusion current measures the concenetration and half wave potential
identifies the particular species.


This technique, however, has higher detection limit and, therefore,
it is not used much in environmental monitoring.


The advancement in polarography is  ` stripping voltammetry'
 , which has wide application. 


  Stripping voltammetry  

 

" Stripping voltammetry " is a 2 stage process.


The first stage is a preconcentration process in which the
analyte present in a liquid is concentrated at an electrode by
electrolysis.


The second stage consists of electrochemical removal of the
deposited analyte back into solution.


The second process is also called " stripping process
" .


The resulting current due to stripping is used to determine the
concentration of analyte in the solution.


The preconcentration step makes " stripping voltammetry
" a technique capable of determining extremely low concentration
of the analyte.


The stripping current is proportional to the depolarizer
concentration and is frequently related to the depolarizer half wave
potential.


The technique is useful in determining several species
simultaneously, differentiating different oxidation states and labile
and bound forms of metal in natural waters.


Depending on the deposition / accumulation and stripping, the
technique is referred as " anodic or cathodic stripping voltammetry
" .
