VIOLENCE IS BETRAYAL OF DEMOCRACY  

 

Violence has progressively increased in the years following 
  Independence.  


There is,    in fact   an alarming spurt
in the incidence of communal riots.


Against sixty one districts which had experienced communal trouble in
1661 there are now eighty one districts identified as hypersensitive &
another ninety eight as sensitive districts from the communal point of view.


It seems to be spreading its tentacles a bit wider.


Ahmedabad &    Meerut   have become 
  notorious   cities for breeding    communal   trouble.


It was hoped that as secularism entrenches itself, the forces of
communalism will become weak.


But far from subsiding the communal    centre
  is gaining ground. 

 

Communal tension of Hindu-Muslim variety has had a long & sordid
history.


It has been further compounded by the developments in Punjab during
the last five years.


These developments have injected into the situation the potential for
a Hindu-    Sikh   confrontation which
fortunately has not materialised.


If by & large the communities have restrained themselves &    retained   their sanity, it is inspite of the 
  communals   on either side.


But the restrained exercised by the two communities had come under
serious strain following the mindless killings of the   
Sikhs   in the week immediately following the assassination of Mrs.
Indira Gandhi & the three or four occasions when innocent bus passangers were
shot dead by the    terrorists   . 

 

Several    commissions   which
have probed communal riots have found that it was possible to have kept down
the extent of loss of lives & damage to property, had the steps taken by the
administration been timely & purposive.


It may not be possible to prevent a riot every time but it is
certainly within the capacity of the administration to contain the fall out.


But there was the lack of political will, not enough attention has
been paid to the question of conveying the message to those who have
developed a vested interest in promoting periodical riots that they cannot
hope to buttress their communal leadership.


   In fact   the base of their
leadership has been broadening with every riot. 

 

No less disquietening is the growth of caste violence which has
reached frightening proportions in some regions.


Dr. B.R.Ambedkar moving the final reading of the constitution in the
Constituent Assembly observed,  " On the social plane we have in India
a society based on the principle of graded inequality which means elevation
of some & degradation of others.


On the economic plane we have some who have immense wealth as against
many who live in abject poverty.


On Jan 26, 1950 we are going to enter into a life of contradictions.


In policies we will have equality & in a social & economic field we
will have inequality.


We must remove this contradiction <*> dotted line </*> else those who
suffer from inequality will blow up the structure of political democracy <*>
dotted line </*> " 


We are still in the process of dismantling what we had inherited.


We are trying to usher in a society in which violence of injustice,
violence of human dignity & violence to human rights will all become a part
of history that we have left    behind.  


For far too    large   we had a society
which can  aptly be deseribed, in the words of
Tagore as one in which  " the few are more than the many." 


Vested interests do not allow us to achieve the ideals laid down in
our constitution.


Whatever changes towards the personal relationship which regains a
measure of adaptability of the participants.


This has not been forth-coming.


So the result is conflicts & consequent violence which appear to the
concomitant of the ongoing social change. 

 

The rural areas of Bihar & Uttar Pradesh have been disfigured by
cruel & endemic violence because of land disputes.


The land reform measures as have been implemented have fallen short
of legitimate expectations which were initially fostered among the landless
   peasants   during the national movement.


The state of the land reforms as it existed on the eve of the sixth
Five Year Plan 1980 was described this  " Necessary determination has
been    lacking   to effectively undertake
action particulary in the matter of implementation of ceiling laws,
canalistiation of holdings & in not rigourously pursuing the concealed
tendncy & having them vested with    tenancy  
of occupancy rights as enjoined under the law"  .


The Commission for Scheduled Caste & Scheduled Tribes in its
" Fifth Report " had concluded that in many states the
necessary political will to implement land    reforms
  was singularly lacking.


This gap between promise & performance has generated considerable
volume of avoidable violence.


The issue related to land often get an infusion of caste feeling &
mindless violence erupts.


The ruthless massacre of the land owners or the tillers has been
going on in U.P. & Bihar. 

 

Reservation is another explosive issue that has tended to
aggravate caste animosities.


Violence arising out of this issue has rocked Gujarat, Andhra Pradesh
& Karnataka & now the people whole of the country.


It must be made clear that the reservation that is being resisted is
not what has been conceded to Scheduled Caste & Sheduled Tribes.


It is an expanding base of reservations among the so called back-ward
castes that threaten to produce a backlash.


The vested interests in backwardness that reservation has created
might also lead to a    re-alignment   of
communities on lines that can only perpetuate the present division. 

 

The conclusion that    follows   
in    is that   the violence
 permeates the present Indian society,  that
the changes sought in the different fields are not accompanied by appropriate
& matching institutionally mid-wifeing.


So chances are that the institutions will cease to become relevant
 ,  violence become inevitable only to the extent of the inadequacy &
ineffectiveness of the institutional infra-structure in general & the
criminal justice system in particular.  




  FREEDOM OF PRESS  

 

Democracy as a form of government depends upon certain healthy
traditions.


Till the people are conscious of their rights & duties it is not
possible for democracy to work properly.


Similarly opposition should remain alert & put a check upon the
erring government.


Apart from this the people in power should have moral integrity &
should be prepared to sacrifice their personal    interests   for the sake of the public.


The cooperation of the public & the mutual understanding between
the people & the government will ensure the proper working of democracy.


But human beings are selfish & particularly so in this competitive
society.


So they cannot expect them to be large hearted to subordinate their
personal interests to the public interest.


That is why in the democratic set up checks & counterchecks are
placed.


An independent & powerful press can keep the people in power under
check & keep the general public always informed. 

 

People in power have a tendency to become more powerful because
power like a powerful intoxicant goes to the head.


In order to achieve this they always try to encroach upon the rights
of the people.


If this process continues democracy is   
prostituted   & it changes into dictatorship of the people in power.


So the government should be properly bridled.


A common man cannot do anything about it because he had his own
limitations both psychological & financial.


It is the responsibility of the oppositon & the press to keep the
people in power under check.


By bringing out the secrets of the government & by pulling up the
ministers whenever they go against the public interest the press can play an
important role in making democracy healthy. 

 

But there is a great possibility that the press may not be able
to play this role because newspaper is itself an industry which is run on
profit & loss basis.


It is generally thought that the press being under the influence of
big businessmen can never be impartial.


It always tries to further the interest of those businessmen & so
they view the activities of the government from the point of view of the
business interests.


That is why in many cases the criticisim given by the press is
partial & one sided under such circumstances very unstable conditions are
created in the country.


Sometimes it results in frustration among the people.


So the press can play a negative role & make the working of democracy
somewhat difficult. 

 

Press can keep the people well informed.


A common man does not have access to the information regarding the
working of the governments & ministers.


The press tries to dig out that information & bring it before the
public.


Watergate Scandal in America was unearthed by the press.


These types of malpractices should be brought to the notice of the
public in order to keep them well informed.


It brings the government to the dock & the public opinion goes
against them.


Under such circumstances press can make the people in power conscious
of their commitments of the public.


It this respect also we can say that the press is  
 misused   .


Sometimes the criticism by the press proves to be nothing more than
slander.


Under such circumstances press can misguide the public & may prove
disastrous. 

 

During the elections press is supposed to play a very important
role.


The manifestoes of the different political parties can be brought
home to the people.


Similarly the speeches of the different leaders belonging to
different political parties must be properly reported.


That is why without press it may become very difficult for the voters
to make a correct choice of the leaders.


If this function is not performed the very existence of many
political parties will be meaningless. 

 

Press eastablishes a link between the people & the govt.


The grievances of the people should be brought to the notice of the
government & the  policies should be made known to the
public.


Till there is a hot line between the people and the government it is
not possible for democracy to function properly.


Till the people know about the activities of the government it is not
possible for them to make a correct assessment of the work of their
representatives & if the grievances of the public are not publicised, the
government may try to ignore them.  




  ROLE OF OPPOSITION IN DEMOCRACY.  

 

Political opposition does not mean simple  
 criticism   of the people in power.


The opposition party is expected to give a healthy, construction &
well directed criticism.


By constructive critcism we mean criticism which is not meant to pull
down the people in <del> water </del power. 


Healthy criticisim stands for a criticisim based upon moral
principles & basic values of life.


Opposition party is primarily meant for helping the public in
assessing the work of the people in power. 

 

Democratic form of Government is supposed to work for the welfare
of the people.


But generally it starts working against the people because it is
guided more by the lust for power than    their  
sincere desire to ameliorate the living conditions of the people.


As the Government becomes more powerful  ,  the rights of the
people are encroached upon  ,  consequently the institution of
democracy degenerates.


It is the opposition that pinpoints lapses as well as the    weaknesses   of the people who constitute the
Government.


Under such circumstances it is necessary for the oppsition party to
 point out to the public that the Government is not working in
larger    interests   of the country.


The image of the people in power is tarnished & they become unpopular
with the masses.


The fear of  losing support of the people makes
them to correct themselves. 

 

Opposition helps in making the people politically educated.


The party in power will always try to praise their own policies & a
comman man may live under illusions.


On the other hand opposition party will  bring political
awakening among the people.


   Moreover   when different policies
are given by different political parties there is a choice for the people to
make.


This helps them to think & organise their thoughts properley.


opposition party also takes up the momentary issues & awaken the
people to the realities of the situation.


Political culture is important for a country as the political
institution itself & opposition help in injecting the political culture. 

 

Opposition serves as an alternative to the Government.


A common man does not want to depart from the beaten track.


He would like to have the same old things because they think that
the persons & ideas which have stood the test of time will live for all times
to come.


That is why they generally become hero worshippers & start feeling
that the failure of government would mean great danger to the nation.


If there is a strong oppositon people will not depend upon the
ruling party only.


They will develop a healthy outlook & people would be able to
organize themselves politically in a better manner. 

 

In some of the contries opposition is given constitutional
recongnition.


In other countries opposition is completely wiped out.


Where there is no opposition authoritarianism becomes strong.


Whereas the countries in which opposition is recongnized democracy
can    survive   .


Political parties give proper direction to the efforts of the people
& as such they can work for the welfare of the democratic society as a whole.


 

In a country like India, opposition is all the more necessary.


The people in power    becomes   alomst
Gods upon earth.


As such they are worshiped as super-human   
beings.  


Opposition will awaken the people to realities.


Moreover the people in power exploit the ignorance of others & so
they try to become more & more powerful.


Opposition puts check    upon   them.


Opposition is necessary for the consolidation of democracy &    maintenance   of democracy.


   Sometimes   it play a negative
role & undermines the stability.


This should be checked as far as it  is  possible.

SHORT STORY


by Christine Krishnasami


  Three Sisters  

 

  THE   prestigious art gallery
was crowded, and stifling - - for me.


For I have never cared much for all this la-di-da stuff. 

 

I was always what you might call a science kid, and now a computer
analyst.


Hilda and I were school chums way back when in Siddapur, our
birthplace in Karnataka.


We pulled each  pigtails and shared school lunches (
and secrets and giggles) for many a year at St.  . 

 

On the first day,  been scared of the nuns habits and
run all the way home in tears and tantrums.


It had taken all the persuasion of two families to get me back in
that classroom. 

 

I never did get used to the nuns and their ways, though they were
generally kind and the school was okay, I guess, better than many.


It was Hilda who took to the whole scene like a duckling to water.


Well-mannered compared with me, always first in English and Art,
lagging behind in Science, zero in Math.


We had swapped our budding talents back and forth between Art and
Science. 

 

And now here I was, back from California on a visit because
Hilda was having a major exhibition at this fancy art gallery. 

 

 " Hm,"  went one critic ( you can always tell a
critic ) in front of a canvas entitled  " Harlot"  .


Harlot-ha, I thought to myself.


The thing was a lot of dots and zigzag lines resembling nothing so
much as a desert at sunset time, maybe.


A patch of volcanic Arizona.


But the colours were real pretty, all fuschia and orange.


Shadows streaking over everything. 

 

 " Harrumph!"  went another critic as I moved on.


This time, the thing was called  " Moon Mother,"  if
you please.


It seemed just like a large blank canvas to me, leastways from a
distance in flat daylight.


But when cunningly placed lights shone on it from different angles (
and Hilda had arranged it so that the lighting changes were continuous ) ,
various shapes seemed to emerge, jump at you and recede.


Sort of female shapes, some like a tree or a vase.


In a scientific way, rather clever fo her, I thhought.


I like a vase anytime, especially white, painted in the old way with
lots of colourful flowers, green leaves and stems.


I like that, period. 

 

So I pushed off to the rear of the gallery, away from all the
over-dressed, over-manicured crowd. 

 

 " What a lot of pother, Hilda!"  I went tsk-tsk.


 " I mean, the press, these darn critics, the fashionable
society, all this food and drink.


Was it really necessary?"  

 

 " Blunt as usual, Mugger.


But see here, even if I were Cezanne come back to earth, 
have to sell myself like this on opening day.


This is Bombay, remember?"  

 

Ol' Mugger.


How I had hated that nickname all through school <*> dotted line</*>


Hilda and the others had always claimed it was right for me on
account of my disposition.


The name had stuck, along with the disposition.


 a different person in California, though. 

 

 " Oh, all right.


Anything I can do to help?"  

 

 " Thanks, Mugger, but every under
control.


Go back and be nice to the press if you will."  

 

I was prevented from replying or complying by the arrival of one
of  fashionplate assistant. 

 

 "  interested in Canvas No. 24, madam,"
 she cooed.


I went back with them out of curiosity.


A white-haired gentleman in a spotless ivory   khadi kurta
  and   churidar   outfit was regarding
No. 24 with studied casualness, but his eyes gave him away.


I moved on, leaving the two to talk.


I noticed in passing that No. 24 was called  " The clay pot."
 

 

  So   the day passed somehow.


No one came near me except one ill-advised cub reporter who wanted
to know more about  background. 

 

 " Don't you know enough already from the others, young
man?"  

 

 " Yes, madam.


But they told me you are her oldest and dearest friend so I
thought - - "  

 

 " You thought nothing, kid.


And I know nothing.


Now be a good boy and yamoose before I throw this in your sweet fresh
face.


But don't hold it against Mrs. Senai.


Not her fault  her oldest and dearest friend, okay?"
 

 

I almost felt sorry when he backed away, upset a tray of snacks
and disappeared in the ensuing underplayed melee.


I hoped I hadn't spoiled a review or something.


Generally, the press ignored me and didn't hold me against Hilda.


Not that they could afford to - -  been a successful
and established artist for over a decade. 

 

So it came as no surprise that, by closing time, most of the  canvases had been sold.


Only two were left, and by  choice.


I was glad for her.


And putting up her feet while the simpering assistants and gallery
personnel went out to dinner, she settled down to a pizza with me and our
usual until-midnight-do-us-part shooting of the breeze.


And as usual, she waited for me to begin. 

 

 " That No.24,"  I said awkwardly.


 " One of the few what - - chamacallit representational
pieces.


Rather got to me."  

 

The picture shows the balcony of the ugly highrise in Bombay
where Hilda Senai then lived with her husband and teenage son.


The railing of the balcony is coincident with the horizon.


On the balcony, an eight-by-ten-inch portrait of 
mother is burning in a wide earthen pot. 

 

The young woman of the portrait has hair permed and waved in the
style of the thirties, eyes untouched by fate and lips about to smile ( Hilda
had inherited the eyes and smile ) . 

 

The address of the photographer, a studio - - now long defunct
- - on  Tottenham Court Road, is scrolled tastefully on
the bottom right-hand corner of the portrait.


High above the balcony railing hang galleons of snowy pacific Sunday
cloud ( some blues in between and some clear blue-fingered light piercing
through here and there ) with undersides of lilac shaded into violet, mystic
as all blues and purples are mystic, barely acknowledging the passage of yet
another day. 

 

Flames ring the young  face, licking at the
hair.


The bright eyes will shortly turn to smoke.


Soon the bloom on the lips will be charcoal. 

 

Framed in a mirror at a forty-five degree angle to the clay pot
is the face of Hilda around the same age, of wheaten complexion, weathered
somehow despite the seeming youth, unsmiling, eyes ringed dark. 

 

 " Yes, it got to me,"  I repeated, and waited
for Hilda to fill in the blanks.


After all, it was Art. 

 

 " That lovely photo was damaged, unfortunately,"
 she responded.


 " Like a lot of other scarred mementoes lying at the bottom
of a cracked valise.


Generation of  ` Waterloo Bridge'  ,  `
Brief Encounter'  and all those other songs and movies.


Not compatible with crude jarring disco monotonies.


Nor meant for the indignity of a local garbage bin.


So, from time to time, I let them all burn in that undated clay pot
saved from the Siddapur days.


Is there another way to dispose of them ?


Anyway, if  known you liked this canvas, Mugger, I
wouldn't have sold it."  

 

I waved a hand deprecatingly.


 " Thanks, ole gal, but  a very nice picture of
your mom.


The one I snapped just before we graduated from St.  .


Your  ma  so happy and proud, one arm around you
protectively under that tamarind tree <*> dotted line</*> "  

 

And then I changed the subject. 

 

  HOPE   Bootle had been an
unusual English girl from Kent who had had the audacity to marry an Indian
boy  met at the Universtiy of London, where she was into
Oriental Studies and he was - - as they say - - reading English ( those days,
people actually managed to get jobs after majoring in English Literature).


They had met at the British Museum,  " Hope Aunty" 
had reminisced to me once, and were married months later at St.  in Soho.


And returned to India just after 1945, having survived the blitz and
escaped the more gruesome events of the War. 

 

But they didn't quite escape the social blitz in India, from
both British and Indian lines.


Hilda got born shortly after 1947, and the three of them had managed
to stick together right up to the sixties. 

 

After we graduated from St.  , Hilda and I had
gone our separate ways.


She went to the J.J. School of Art in Bombay and thence to Paris.


I ended up at the University of California, Irvine.


But we had never lost touch. 

 

And that is how I had learned of the death of her parents in
1972 when the car they were travelling in was rammed by a speeding bus
somewhere between Siddapur and Mysore. 

 

It had, too, been Hope Swamikannu who had saved Hilda from
becoming a nun like her teachers.


Hilda had been all set to jump into that brown-and-black habit
after graduation but Hope had said, No, off you go to study Art like a good
girl. 

 

But, Mother ! 

 

But nothing, my girl, you can always become a nun later, but not
right now. 

 

We had all cheered when Hilda went off to Bombay in a spanking
new dress, all white and buttercup yellow.


I held Aunty  hand in a manner of speaking while  things were put away in storage.


And then I, too, left.


The two families supported each other through all of the social
ostracism that followed.


Those days, girls didn't go traipsing off alone for higher studies.


 

 " Shan't ask about that post-Expressionist doodad -
- or is it post-Minimalist - - but this other canvas here.


Why, you  called the shots on this one !


Everybody, but everybody was admiring it.


A hundred grand, maybe ?


And you didn't want to sell?"  

 

 " Of course not.


This canvas is for you, Mugger.


Don't pretend you can't stand it, for I caught you sneaking a look
at it whenever all those people let you.


And don't you pretend you don't know why.


Worth it, isn't it?"  

 

My throat had seized up, so I got up and poured us the last of
the wine.


 " Sure is, A toastl.  Benedicite  ! "  

 

  It   remains a very special
canvas.


Three nuns are dying in a  parlour converted into
a sick bay because outsiders wouldn't be allowed inside the cloisters. 

 

The oldest nun, past eighty, is prone on a sickbed shown
diagonally at stage right.


Skin like tallow, eyes closed.


The second nun, in her fifties, is seated by the bedside towards the
centre of the canvas and regards the viewer directly.


The starched white wimple intensifies the dark hue of her
complexion, but you can still make out the faint line of a moustache and a
wart or two on one cheek. 

 

The third and youngest nun, thirty something, is seated at an
angle away from the other two at stage left.


Elegantly straight, with hands folded behind the scapular in the
seemly way.


Behind the thick ugly frames of the spectacles, unlined
almondshaped eyes look away into some distance over your right
shoulder. 

 

The mouths of the three nuns are open slightly, almost
smilingly, in a sol-fa expression.


In intense pain, all three, but of course the eyes don't betray an
inkling.


They remain calm and contained, and yet you know 
dying - - don't ask me how.


Sort of like a poet making you understand something vast and
significant, personal and yet transcendent, and not in so many words, either.


 

A canvas over which everybody still goes gaga.


An arpeggio in black, brown, grey, white, buff and hues of mauve,
blue, violet.


Contemplative and still but with movement in stillness and music in
the silence, like a chant.


Solemnity of old Latin.


A patina.


Even I can see it, feel it. 

 

 " I went back to Siddapur for the last time in ' 72 to
sell the house and wind up,"  Hilda was saying.


 " Paid a farewell visit to St.  too, only to
find that our former principal was near extremity.


 been operated on for a strangulated hernia.


Abscess had formed, so  had to cut her open again
within three weeks.


At that age - - too much of a shock for the system.


That mind, which had had such a cutting edge, had begun to wander.


She was sleeping in exhaustion when I called.


And remember Sister Agatha,  been like a second mum
to me - - "  

 

 " And a stepmum to me - - "  


 " She taught Art, what do you expect !


Poor lady, she could speak only in a hoarse whisper.


Tuberculosis had finished off most of the neck glands.


Most nerve ends had been cut off, too.


Now the disease couldn't be halted, they said - - gone to the brain,
almost.


But she could still sing a little - - a miracle, she told me.


Same clear soprano, though an echo of that earlier, bell-like,
joyous sound.  "   

 

 " And Sister Cecilia,  never met her before,
she was after our time.


Cancer of the stomach.


 been suffering for all of seventeen years.


Secondaries had been brought under control, but the thing had
started up again.


Lining of innards almost worn out.


Chemotherapy was a form of purgatory, she told me quite serenely - -
almost with a smile."  

 

 " None of the Sisters could have really eaten for a long
time, you know.


And each moment  been agony.


But I still haven't seen such a concentration of beauty in one
room - - "  

 

 " In one canvas - - "  

 

 " Attagirl, Mugger !


You remember how Sister Agatha always used to make me sing,
choir and all.


I sang them one or two of the oldies - - you know, the  Vidi
aquam  - - "  

 

 " And  Panis angelicus  - - "  

 

 " You remembered !


And by now Mother Constance had woken up.


Looked up and smiled cheerfully at me.


Then all three Sisters began to sing the   Salve Regina
  .


In the middle, Mother Constance started coughing and had to stop,
but the other two carried on."  

 

 " I babbled the usual nonsense about how come the
Sisters get it all.


I mean, Mugger, here are all these cheap guys smoking and drinking
away to glory - - "  

 

 "  in corruption, honeying   and making love over a
nasty sty - - "  

 

 " Precisely.


And do you know, when I first entered the 
parlour, Sister Cecilia got up and gave me her chair.


Preferred to perch uncomfortably on a stool somewhere behind the
bed.


I was a guest, you see <*> dotted line</*>  "   

 

 " Something about Cecilia got me in the craw, Mugger.


That face, those hands that voice.


Didn't quite belong among all these headstones here."
 

 

 " And that snowy white collar rising above the scapular,
immaculate.


Those habits washed and worn, darned and patched up countless times.


But always, that spotless coif or collar <*> dotted line</*>  "
  

 

 " And me in my shotsilk burgundy  sari
 , amethysts at the ears, throat and on the finger.


Matching lip and eye make-up, I said to Cecilia, God chooses
suffering for His favourite ones, Sister.


 doing this for us."  

 

 " I suppose I was trying to offer them some little
comfort !


Then Cecilia came up to me and took my hands in her own exquisite
ones - - Botticelli hands, Mugger.


And she said to me, Sinner or saint, everyone is 
favourite, Sister <*> otted line</*>  "   

 

 " Pointedly called me Sister, Mugger.


Me, married with one kid and all, and so many layers of
heaven-knows-what covering over  there at the centre, the
steady white flame."  

 

 " I wondered, I really did.


How could you care so deeply about someone  just met?


Feel so much grief after a few minutes?"  

 

 "  give you something small if I may,
sister Cecilia, I said.


An old  Introit  my mother taught me and which I haven't
sung for anyone else."  

 

 " So I sang the  Gaudeamus  for the last time,
too, in that parlour.


Let us all rejoice in the Lord, keeping a festival day in honour of
the queenship of the Blessed Virgin Mary, at whose solemnity the angels
rejoice <*> dotted line</*>  "   

 

 " And I left quickly.


I was driving, had to get some lastminute things done <*> dotted
line</*> "  

 

 " Getting on for midnight now, ole gal.


My own coach is sure to turn into a pumpkin, and that chauffeur was
always a rat, anyway.


And I got a very, very special canvas to pack before catching that
plane.


Shall we?"  

 

As Hilda and I started to clear up, we fell naturally to
reciting the hymn of St. Teresa of Avila that Mother Constance Mary had
taught us - - oh, about a life-time ago : 


" I am yours and I am in this world for you.


How do you wish to dispose of me?


Give me consolation or sadness.


Give me gaiety or affliction, A soft life and an unclouded sun;
Because I have made complete surrender of myself, How do you wish to dispose
of me ? "  

 

By now, the others had begun to trickle in.


We all said our goodbyes and left. 

 

So hangs the painting in my den in Irvine, California : 
" Three Sisters."    - - in wax by breeze moulded by love of
flame melted away praying nun - -  

 

And  the closest  come to poetry, or
what folks call religion.


In a dark room with a single candle burning, when analysis and
science have been put away for the day. 

 

You don't say goodbye to a Sister, ever.


Only  Benedicite  .  <*> filled circle</*>

<$A>


Kate  " The Awakening, Sex-role  
Liberation or Sexual Liberation ",  


Over the centuries women writers have written openly or implicitly  
about the right of woman to passion, 


In fact as Ellen Moers in her " Literary Women "  
says, it was Ovid who with his, with his " Heroides "  
first gave voice to the heroine in love, 


According to Moers, Ovid started a tradition which extended well  
into the eighteenth century to become part of the infant novel in Britain,  
and which was born anew in  literature of the nineteenth  
century, 


Mary Wollstonecraft the strong-minded, feminist comes to mind in  
this respect, 


For it is in her fiction, reviews and letters that  ,  Wollstonecraft   is explicit about love  
<,,> 


" The Wrongs of Women " or " Maria  
" by Wollstonecraft is a celebration of an unhappy   
<,> adulterous love from the point of view of a woman, not only with a  
mind but a body capable of passion, 


Women writers also inherited from Rousseau the novel of adultery,  
as seen from the  point of view, 


As Moers put it I quote,  The adultery novel after  
Rousseau became the woman  vehicle of attack on the economic  
and social class realities, that make a mockery of love, as well as a  
vehicle of demonstration that woman has a capacity to think, feel and act  
for herself  unquote, 


A whole host of writers and novelists, spoke frankly about the  
positive consequences of adultery, 


George Elliot, the Bronte sisters Gaskell Browning Collette and  
Woolf, to name only the most well known ones, resolved to talk openly  
about the forbidden subject, and the right of a woman to participate  
actively, and consciously, in the affairs of love,  


The American literary scene had not witnessed the presence of a  
traditon of novel writing by women, who talk about their heroines from a  
 perspective, 


The awakening of female novel writers to a sense of their own  
identity, begins only with the publication of Kate ,  
" The Awakening " at the turn of the last century, 


One may even say that the American,  tradition  
begins in the twentieth century, 


Incidentaly " The Awakening " may be read as an  
   adultery   novel also, 


 novel sent waves of shock among the  
pre-dominantly patriarchal set up of her time, 


She became almost the first woman writer to create a woman in Edna  
<,> Pontellier who not only awakens to her sexuality, but makes bold to  
confess it, 


Linda Huf puts it succinctly I quote,  The novel,  
suggested, that the renegade heroine had not forgotten herself, but had  
in fact found herself, had awakened to her full potential as a human  
being, and all because, without consulting any one, but her own  
willful self, she had taken  ,  an unlawful  
  fancy to a younger man , unquote, 


When the novel opens the twenty-eight year old Edna Pontellier is  
holidaying at Grand Isle, with her husband Leonce Pontellier, and her  
<,> two children, Raoul and, and Etienne, 


I am sorry I don't know how to pronounce the French words so I am  
<,> I am just talking in terms of the Anglicised pronunciation, 


Pontellier a successful brokerage businessman is one of those  
husbands who prides himself, on his many possessions of which his wife is  
the most precious and attractive, 


Little wonder that he reacts typically when he reprimands Edna for  
exposing herself at midday, in such heat, while bathing in the sea, 


He is anxious that she should protect her complexion, as  
jealously if not more, as her honour, 


He scrutinizes her as he would a piece of personal property which  
has suffered some damage, 


During the six years of her married life Edna too has lived like  
any other Southern wife in her beautiful house in New Orleans,    immersed   in her home and social circle, 


She was married,  she has married Pontellier  
for the same reason as any woman of her class would, 


She chooses Leonce to become the devoted wife of a man, who she  
felt, worshiped her, 


She feels she would I quote,  Take her place with a  
certain dignity in the world of reality, closing the portals forever  
behind her, upon the realm of romance and dreams  unquote, 


The opening pages of the novel would give one the impression that  
Edna is one of those usual Southern women, who is contented looking after  
her husband and children, 


Yet, through the flashback technique, Chopin employs, we  
know that Edna had been a different person in her childhood, girlhood,  
and youth, 


As a lonely and imaginative person she has given herself to secret  
and intense, infatuations, 


First it is the dignified and sad-eyed cavalry officer, at  
another time it is I quote  the young gentleman who visits a lady on a  
neighbourhood plantation , unquote 


Yet a third time it is I quote  the figure of a great  
tragedian, that possessed her mind , 


But marriage with the tragedian which would have been the highest  
point of her happiness, was not for her in this world, 


However, if he does not come in the form of a Leonce, he

Omar khayyam was born in the latter half of the 11th century and
died in the first quarter of the 12th.


For a man of the 11th century, Khayyam is strangely modern.


He was a scientist of no ordinary worth of distinction.


His work entitled  " Algebra "  was translated into
some of the European languages.


As an astronomer he was amongst the foremost of the Middle Ages and
the Christian calendar of the present day owes much of its perfection to
his labours.


Not satisfied with being a scientist, he wanted to be a philosopher -
- the solver of  mighty riddle - - with disastrous results to
his peace of mind. 

 

  " Up from  centre through the Seventh
gate I rose and on the throne of Saturn sate and many a knot unravelled by
the Road; but not the master - knot of Human death and fate.


There was the door to which I found no key  . " 


He was too naughty a spirit to find consolation in faith and
resignation, the unfailing resources of the meek and humble.


Supremely endowed with courage and audacity, he did battle with
the orthodoxy of his days.


He sneered at the mystical  Sufis  as a loquacious
lot.


He was not given the Robe of Honour, which his genious deserved.


He laughs, saying that it could only be purchased by bartering away
his freedom of thought; certainly He is the richer by keeping the more
precious stuff for himself.


Like Mill and Morley of contemporary history, he was a sage and
sceptic rolled into one.


High office did not tempt him.


He preferred instead a pension coupled with the pleasures and
pursuits of private life. 

 

The thoughts and feelings he expresses are astonishingly and
surprisingly modern.


There is not a single writer of the Middle Ages who has caught the
fancy of the present day in such a close and mighty grip as Omar.


One may not like him - - his views may be abhorrent to you - - but if
there is any the least spark of serious intellectual purpose in your life
he seizes on your attention.


He has the glittering eye of the Ancient Mariner and fascinates
while perturbing the guest bent on attending the feast of faith.


 rendering of the  Rubaiyat
 has become a classic - - a leading classic in the literature of
revolt - - of revolt against accepted doctrines of human worth and destiny.
 

 

Khayyam can never become obsolete because the theme of his song
belongs to the eternal element in the heart.


Feeling minds and thinking heads will ask these questions.


 " What is truth? said jesting Pilate and would not stay for
an answer"  .


Probably    he   knew it was no use waiting
for an answer.


But Pilate has left plenty of successors, more patient than he, and
in consequence more miserable. 

 

I shall briefly summarise the considerations that led Omar to
deny the divine ordering of the world : 


  1. Intellectual despair  

 

In his youth he frequented doctor and saint and heard great
argument about it.


 ( It never is, on it I am afraid ) but every more came out by

nor yet from the world within.


  " And I heard, as from without, the Me within thee is
blind"   .


What then were the questions that perplexed him ?  


  " Into this Universe and why not knowing Nor whence,

not whither willy-nilly blowing."

thus arrogated to itself the function of disposing my destinies?
"  


   "  What without asking, hither hurried whence ?


And without asking, whither hurried hence !


Despair is own cousin to blind fury and rage"    

 

He adds :  


  " In many a cup of this forbidden wine


Must drown the memory of that insolence"  .  

 

  "  Shall I seek for tempral good or for eternal
happiness ? the answer is the same to both : your reward is neither here nor

It will be observed that Omar parts company with Kantian ethics
and the generally accepted theological views.


According to these ethical codes imperfection pertains only to this
world, and strangely enough, it is a fine reason for believing in the

The answer of Omar is clear though rude.


He asks  " Who made this world? " 


In his parable of the pot and the potter he makes one of the pots

  " They sneer at me for leaving all things awry 


Why did the hand then of the potter shake"  . 

 

If the hand shook in making this world, why should we suppose it

The results is he gives up asking these questions.  


  "  no more with human or divine


 tangle to the winds resign"  . 

 

This is more often attempted than achieved.


In point of fact he did worry himself with problems which were most

We have already seen that Omar khayyam was alive to the problem

Look, he says, how all is vanity !

Familiar incidents, do not usually excite our, curiosity, 


We look at them, and we take them for granted, 


We do not ask, what makes them, happen, ? 


How they are connected with the rest, of the universe, ? 


It was, one of these mundane incidents, which excited the  
curiosity, of, Issac Newton, 


He saw, an apple fall from a tree, 


It made him wonder, whether the law of nature that made the  
apple fall, would also make the moon, fall towards the earth, 


He was taking a great intellectual leap from the apple, to the  
moon, 


He was not content, with having seen this event with his physical  
eyes alone, 


He was trying, to see a hidden connection behind the phenomenon  
<,> with his, intellect, the third eye, 


What is the connection, that Newton saw, betweeen the apple  
and the moon, ? 


Let us look at the moon, 


If the earth, did not attract the moon, the moon would have  
travelled in a straight line and escaped to infinity, 


The  attraction provides the centripidal force,  
that bends the  projectory, continuously, from its  
linear projectory, 


One can therefore say, that the moon is continuously falling  
towards the  centre, 


It is exactly analogous to the case of the spacecraft, that we  
talked about in an earlier episode 


Now, if the  gravity extends, upto the orbit  
of the moon, and this force decreases, as the square of the distance  
from the  centre, 


It is easy to calculate the acceleration of the moon as it falls  
<,,> from a knowledge of the acceleration of the apple, 


Since the moon is sixty times, as far from the centre of the  
earth as the apple, its acceleration should be sixty multiplied by sixty  
that is, three thousand six hundred times smaller, than the  acceleration, 


The remarkable thing is, that this gives the right answer for  
the moon to go, once round the earth in twenty-eight days, exactly as  
observed, 


This was , famous, moon test, 


In fact in the beginning, he used a slightly wrong value for the  
distance of the moon from the centre of the earth, and therefore got, a  
slightly wrong value for the lunar month, that made him wonder for a  
while as to whether, there was something other than gravity, which  
affected the  motion, 


He therefore didn't publish his results until much later, 


The primitive concept of forces, arises from our experience of  
<,> pushes and pulls, 


Newton made a tremendous intellectual leap, from such a concept  
of contact forces, to the concept of forces, such as gravitation,  
which act over a distance through empty space, 


This is how he made, the leap, 


Consider the uniform inertial motion of a body, in a straight  
line, covering equal distances AB, BC, CD, DE and so on, in  
equal times, 


Let the points " A B C D E " etcetera, be  
joined by a straight line, to the point P, not on the line of motion  
<,,> 


Then, the successive triangles, all have equal bases, AB  
<,> BC, CD, DE, etcetera, and the same height, H, from the  
base, 


Therefore, they all have the same area, 


Since these equal areas are swept out in equal times, this is  
clear that inertial motion, traces out equal areas in equal times, 


Now Newton supposed, that the body received a succession of  
blows, at regular intervals, 


All directed towards a common point, P, 


Then the direction of motion would change at every blow, and the  
body would coast along inertially in a straight line, between these blows  
<,,> 


The linear path would thus be converted into a polygon, whose  
sides would still determine consecutive triangles of equal areas, with  
respect to the point P, 


Now says Newton, let the time between successive blows become  
smaller and smaller, then the number of blows and triangles would increase  
<,> and the width, would decrease, 


In the limit of arbitrarily small intervals of time, the  
projectory would be a continuous curve, 


This is the crucial point, 


It lies at the very heart of calculus, 


This limiting procedure enabled Newton to make a transition,  
from a succession of discrete blows, to the concept of a continually  
acting force, directed towards a common point, a central or centripidal  
force causing curvilinear motion, 


And he discovered, that bodies moving under the action of such a  
force would trace out equal areas in equal times, 


This is  second law of planetary motion, 


Notice that Newton arrived at the concept of an attractive force  
acting over a distance, as a mathematical limit of a succession of direct  
impact, 


He wrote,  what I call attraction, may be performed  
by impulse, or by some other means unknown to me, 


I use these words here to signify in general, any force, by  
which bodies, tend towards one another, whatsoever be the cause  
, 


He didn't pretend to know the cause of gravity, 


Could it be due to, a shower of ethereal particles, or was  
it is as Descartes had imagined, ? 


Newton was curious, but he couldn't decide, 


He left the question, open, 


But what is important is that he didn't stop there, 


He simply assumed the existance of gravity, and proceeded to  
work out its consequences, 


This pragmatic approach, was, essential for the progress of  
science in his time, but it was completely misunderstood, by many of  
his eminent contemporaries, 


It led to, a lot of unnecessary and bitter controversy, 


Having shown that a centripidal force acting continually would make  
a body move in a curve, that traced out equal areas in equal times, he  
also proved the converse, namely that this area law employed a motion in a  
central force speed, 


Since the area law held for planets, it became clear to Newton  
that the force acting between the sun and the planets must be a central force  
<,,> 


He had earlier deduced from  third law of  
planetary motion, that a circular orbit employed a force, that  
decreased as the square of the distance from the centre, 


Armed with the discovery of calculus he was now able to show,  
that under a central force that decreased at the square of the distance, a  
planet would describe, an elliptic orbit, 


In other words, he derived  first law of  
planetary motion, from causal principles, 


Now, this derivation of  empirical laws,  
held only for an imagined system, a hypothetical point particle, moving  
around a centre of force, in a perfect vacuum, 


The real world is of course much more complex, 


Newton therefore didn't publish his results, 


In the mean time, Robert Hook quite independently hit upon the  
idea, that the attraction between the sun and the planets, fell off at  
the square of their distances, 


However, he couldn't work out, what the orbits would be under  
such an attractive force, 


He tried to get Newton interested in the problem, and wrote to  
him in January sixteen hundred and eighty, 


But Newton didn't reply, as an earlier controversy with Hook  
about the nature of light, had offended him, 


In London, there were two other men, who were, also  
working on  problem, 


Christopher Wren, the famous architect of Saint   
Cathedral, and Edmund Halley, 


In August sixteen eighty-four, Halley, who was younger than  
Hook and more tactful, went to Cambridge on horseback, to find out if  
Newton could help, 


A contemporary account, states, without mentioning either his  
own speculations, or those of Hook or Wren, he at once indicated the  
object of his visit by asking Newton, what would be the curve described by  
the planets on the supposition, that gravity, diminished at the square  
of the distance, 


Newton immediately answered, an ellips, 


Struck with joy and amazement, Halley asked him how he knew it  
<,,> ? 


Why replied he, I have calculated it, and being asked for  
the calculation, he could not find it, but, promised to send it to  
him, 


This was the beginning, of the writing of   
Principia, 


Perhaps the greatest book on physical science, ever written, 


It took him nearly, three years of incredible labour, 


He submitted it to the Royal Society on twenty-eighth April  
sixteen eighty-six, 


One of the greatest days in the history of science, 


It was finally accepted by Samuel Peeps, the president of the  
Royal Society, and published in sixteen eithty-seven, 


It would not have seen the light of day, had it not been for the  
constant coaxing and persuasion by Halley, who even paid for its  
publication, 


It consisted of three books, written in Latin, in which,  
Newton developed a full dynamical theory, encapsulated in his three laws  
of motion, 


The third law is the most original, of his three laws, and  
appears for the first time in the Principia, 


Newton, generalised the experience of, direct collisions of  
bodies like, billiard balls acting mutually on one another, to the case  
<,> of four types of forces, including attraction, 


The third law, is not however applicable to every case, 


Nowadays we believe, that all signals or forces have a finite  
velocity of propagation, 


It is therefore not applicable to them, because, it talks  
about, forces of action and reaction being equal, as measured at the  
same time, 


We therefore don't expect it to be very good, say in the case of  
atomic category, 


It is however perfectly applicable, to the collisions of  
billiard balls, cars and so on, 


As I have said earlier,  derivation of  empirical laws, held only for an imagined system, a  
hypothetical point particle moving around the centre of force, in a  
perfect vacuum, 


A physically impressed force, must be directed towards a real  
physical body, 


So Newton next introduced a second body in place of the  
mathematical centre of force, to simulate the sun, and a single planet  
<,,> 


And he assumed, that they were both spherical in shape, and  
attracted each other with equal and opposite forces, 


After much effort lasting over a number of years, Newton  
obtained the remarkable mathematical result, that a gravitational

Taxation Policies as an  Aid to Economic
 Development   


JAL E. DASTUR  *   


 

  THE   least that can be said is
that we are today living in interesting times.


It would not be untrue, or even an exaggeration, to say that no
other period of 12 months in the whole history of our planet has seen such
incredible changes as have taken place in the last 12 months.


The Berlin Wall has been broken; the two Germanies have been united.


Communism has been disowned not only in the countries of Eastern
Europe, which were euphemistically known as the socialist bloc, but in its
very heartland,  the birth place of Lenin and Stalin,
the Soviet Union itself.


Thoughts which would hitherto have been considered blasphemous, such
as a free market economy, are now being openly, unabashedly and forcefully
expressed and elaborate programmes chalked out for their speedy
attainment. 

 

As if to show that this is not just a European phenomenon, China,
the <*> line</*> sleeping giant of Asia, hitherto a great bastion of
Communism, is not immune to the winds of change though, not progressing
towards liberalisation at as fast a pace.


Not only windows, but doors are being opened for economic
participation to people and systems which till recently were anathema to the
ruling clique. 

 

No less remarkable have been the events in South Africa.


Though it is too soon to say that Apartheid has been dismantled or
disbanded, it is certainly much less rigid than it has ever been during the
last 40 years since it was so blatantly and brazenly proclaimed as an
article of faith by the late unlamented Dr. Daniel Malan. 


  Socialism in Flight  

 

A question may be asked as to what the above exposition of
politics and recent history has got to do with this paper, which is on a
fiscal-cum-economic subject.


The answer is that, except for the developments in South Africa, all
the other apparently political developments have, in fact, an economic
main spring.


If the East Germans wanted to be united ( I shall not use the word
 " merged"  for fear of wounding the sensitive East German
ego!), with their West German counterparts, it was not political freedom
alone on the other side of the WaIl, which lured them.


More than anything else, it was the  economic
development and industrial advancement, which acted as the magnetic pull.


Similarly, if the other European socialist nations, like
Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Rumania and Poland decided to change the basic
structure of their lives, it was in order to improve their economic  lot.


Perhaps, there is a lesson in all this, which we in this part of the
world can ignore only at our peril. 

 

The historical message, therefore, is loud and clear.


Socialism is on the run.


It was given a fair chance.


In the USSR, it ran for over 70 years, more than the full length of
the biblical life span of man !


In the East European socialist countries, the innings, though
undoubtedly shorter, still covered four to five decades.


At the end of it all, the preaching and practising high priests of
socialism have realised that the system did not 
really deliver the goods.


The phrase, which has been just employed, is not metaphorical,
because  " goods"  , after all, is the name of the development
game !


Many years ago, Koestler achieved fame for himself by writing a
best-seller called  " The God that Failed"  .


The God, of course, was communism, though the allusion, to
Divinity, is more than a little ironic, since communism is essentially
atheistic!


However, be that as it may, history has borne out his prophecy. 

 

In a way, the failure of socialism, is a failure of the knowledge
of human psychology.


Man is basically acquisitive and avaricious in his outlook.


He would work best, when he can reap the fruits of his own toil.


He would work for money, he would work for honour, he would probably
work for love but he would not work for the State, beyond a certain point.


 

Probably sensing the message of the times and recognising the
universal withdrawal from socialism, a known socialist, who presented the
last budget in my country, was constrained to make the apologetic and
defensive observation that he was not a doctrinaire socialist!  

 

The reader might wonder what point I am trying to derive or drive
home from the above narrative and, therefore, it is my duty to satiate his
curiosity.


The difference between socialism and capitalism, though fundamental,
is really quite narrow.


The former lays stress on the distributive aspect and the latter
on the productive one.


The former is obsessed with distributing the existing cake
equally, while the latter is absorbed in increasing the size of that cake
so that all may get more, even if it is not necessarily equally.


As a result of the inexorable working of economic forces, the bigger
cake would also lead to more egalitarian distribution.  


  Poverty - - the No. 1 Foe  

 

Since the beginning of human life, the arch enemy of mankind has
not been any particular individual or idea or system but a condition which
goes by the name  " poverty"  .


This is not something peculiar to my country or to this part of Asia.


It is a universal phenomenon present in the industrialised and
developed world alike, though, no doubt, to a much lesser extent in the
former.


The first step in military strategy is to recognise the foe.


Having identified poverty this way, we can say that we have
negotiated this first step. 

 

Having identified the enemy, the next step is, of course,
vanquishing him.


The only way, that I know by which this can be done is by the
creation of wealth.


It is said idiomatically that one must set a thief to catch a
thief.


However, this does not hold good here.


Just as a dog does not eat another dog, one cannot vanquish poverty
with poverty.


The only thing which can vanquish poverty is its antonym, namely
wealth.


One must, therefore, create as much of it as one can. 


  Prejudice Against Wealth  

 

Time was when  " profit"  was considered a
dirty word.


Today, happily, it is looked upon more kindly.


However, nature abhors a vacuum, and, accordingly, the word  "
wealth"  to some minds, now occupies the vacated slot in the dirt
dictionary as an unworthy concept, an economic pariah.


Human perception is often warped: straight thinking, therefore, is at
a discount.


As a result, almost a comical situation develops, wherein, even after
having identified  enemy, instead of turning 
guns at him, one turns the guns at the very person who could suitably do
battle with the enemy.


We all agree that people must be raised above the poverty line.


To put it conversely, the poverty line must be lowered so that there
are more people who out-surface it.


In other words our straggle, our endeavour, must be focussed
undivertingly on the poverty line.


Despite this, it is almost comic that just a few months ago, a high
political dignitary in this part of the world talked albeit rather
casually about the affluence line, apparently hinting that a person should
not amass wealth beyond a particular point.


This, I think, is a pernicious thought.


National wealth is the sum total of individual wealth and, if our
goal is to increase national wealth, it can be achieved only by tolerating (
if not  encouraging ) the components of inlividual
wealth.


In the  view, therefore, nothing could be so
selfdefeating as the project of delineating the so-called affluence
line. 

 

To recapitulate, our proclaimed enemy is poverty, and our best
weapon against it, is the creation of wealth.


Wealth, again, can result only from economic development, both
agricultural and industrial.


To state the most sterile truism, development requires resources - -
monetary, material and human.


The resources can be acquired only by human endeavour.


No doubt, there are many natural resources and happy is the land
which possesses them in abundance.


However, ultimately, it is human beings who exploit them.


It is, therefore, the human factor which must be nurtured.


This paper has already had occasion to cite two proverbs.


A third one now comes to mind:  " Money leads the mare."



It is, accordingly, monetary incentives, which appear to be the
key.


To invoke a fourth metaphor: it is the carrot, and not the stick,
which must play the lead role. 

 

The proposition that this paper is advancing is that the maximum
money must be left in private individual  hands to
promote development.


It is the well-known experience of mankind that private initiative
is always more effective, more efficient and more enterprising than the
public one.


With a maximisation of private initiative, there would be a
minimisation of corruption.


Corruption breeds in an atmosphere of controls, and controls are,
almost by definition, inseparable from public regulation. 

 

Theoretically, it may appear that the ideal environment for
economic development would be a taxless society.


Such thought, however, apart from being impractical would also be
deceptive.


It would be impractical, because the State needs money for
defence, law-and-order; communications; diplomatic ties, etc.


It would be deceptive, because there can be no proper or, at least,
speedy economic development without the necessary infrastructure, which,
in most cases, can be best provided by the State.


For this also, therefore, taxes would be required. 

 

In fact, it must have been this realisation which prompted a
great scientist-cum-politician of the l8th century to make the depressing
profound observation that nothing in this world can be said to be certain,
except death and taxes!


Having reconciled ourselves, therefore, to the  inevitability of taxes, the problem is not only how to live with them
but also how to harness them to promote the noble cause of economic
development, the pursuit of which is beyond controversy. 


  Savings - - Removal of Disincentive  

 

The object of economic development is beyond controversy, so
also the means through which it can be achieved.


Economic development requires investment and investment requires
savings.


Almost the first object of a taxation policy, therefore, should be
to promote and encourage savings.


A person who saves must be rewarded.


Instead, we find today, that savings are subjected to a tax which
goes under the name wealth tax, because, wealth, after all is accumulated
savings.


It is a  income minus his expenditure.


These savings should qualify for a relief and not an additional
impost.


This may sound a revolutionary idea, if not utopian.


The touchstone, of all ideas, should be not their novelty or
departure from tradition but their rationality and capacity to stand the
ruthless inquisition of logic. 

 

As a matter of fact, wealth-tax  amounts to
double taxation, because wealth is made up of that part, of income which has
not been spent.


Since income itself would have been initially taxed, subjecting it
again to another tax ( albeit under a different label ) clearly amounts to a
repeat levy.


That the charging rates of wealth-tax, on the saved income are
much lower than the rates at which tax was charged on the earned income, may
mitigate the levy but does not excuse it. 

 

Again, the income which has been spent away, is obviously beyond
the reach of the wealth-tax.


This means that the squanderer of income is at a premium in
comparison with the saver.


This goes against the basic proposition that saving holds the key to
development. 

 

Wealth-tax being conceptually a tax on savings, is unjustified.


However, it is possible to make a resultoriented exception.


The case against wealth-tax rests on the assumption that the
savings, which are subjected to tax have been appropriately invested in a
development-oriented manner.


Thus, savings, which are used to acquire fixed assets that
directly contribute to production, must obviuosly be considered to be
development-oriented.


Similarly, savings in the form of shares, debentures, bonds, bank
and other deposits, which, though not directly contributing to production,
serve that purpose indirectly ( by feeding those who contribute to
production themselves, may be also considered to be development-oriented
 )  , thus qualifying for immunity from wealth-tax.


However, the position would be different for savings transformed
into, say, bullion, jewellery, vacant land, unproductive vehicles, etc.


Thus, as far as such assets are concerned, they could probably be
legitimately subjected to this levy.


No doubt as already discussed above, this would still partake
of the character of double taxation as the source of these assets would
have been income which has been subjected to income-tax.


This aberration, however, may be a necessary sacrifice to be
offered at the altar of economic development.


In any event, avoidance of this double taxation would be in the  own hands - - because he could redeploy his assets into
development channels.  

 

The above measure may not be really an incentive to savings, but
only a removal of an existing disincentive.


In other words, the tax on the savings ( which is what the
wealth-tax is ) invested in productive and development-oriented assets
should be removed.  


  Failure of Socialism is a failure of the knowledge of
human psychology.    <&> tantalizer 2 on page 713, column
three  


  Since the difficulty of saving increases with the
quantum of saving, it seems logical that greater difficulty should be matched
by greater incentive.   


  Dividend should be allowed as a deduction to the
distributing company or it should be exempt in the hands of the recipient
shareholders.   


  Since the basic postulate of income-tax is the capacity
to pay, there is no reason why it should not be levied on those who have this
capacity irrespective of whether they are in industry or farming. 



 The paper presented by the author, a member of institute
of Chartered Accountants of India, at the seminar on  " Accountants in
the 1990s"  under the auspices of South Asian Federation of
Accountants.

  Public Financial Institutions and Control   <*>
line from left to right</*> 


RAHUL CHITNIS, Advocate, Bombay.   

 

  IN   the nineteenth century,
entrepreneurs owned and managed the business of companies.


But, with the growth of modern companies, there has come about a
separation of ownership and control.


There has been a shift of power, from those who own, to those who
control and manage the modern companies.


This divergence of ownership and control has led to a divergence of
interest.


Now-a-days, a shareholder is more interested in the income and capital
appreciation of his investment, rather than the company as an enterprise.
  


These observations have been made in the English context, but are true
even in the Indian context. 

 

The growth of institutional investment is a major factor in this
process of separation.


The financial institutions are not usually skilled in the management
nor even necessarily interested in the detailed operations of the companies
in which they have invested.


This has, in turn, led to a shift of power, from those who own, to
those who control the companies.   

 

The term  ` financial institutions'  has not been
defined in the Companies Act, 1956.


Here, it may be relevant to look at the definition of financial
institutions in the United States of America.


The Uniform Probate Code, paragraph 6-101(3) defines financial
institutions as:  " any organisation authorised to do business under
state or federal laws relating to financial institutions, including, without
limitation, banks and trust companies, savings banks, building and loan
associations, savings and loan companies or associations, and credit
unions."     

 

The Companies ( Amendment ) Act, 1974 has introduced the concept
of  ` public financial institutions'  into the Companies Act,
1956, vide section 4 A.


Section 4A ( I ) names the various financial institutions that were
to be regarded as public financial institutions and section 4A ( 2 ) states
that the Central Government may notify any other institution to be a public
financial institution, but such an institution must have been established or
constituted by or under any Act of Parliament or that not less than 51 per
cent of the paid-up share capital of such an institution should be held or
controlled by the Central Government.


The Central Government has, from time to time, notified various
institutions that are public financial institutions. 


  WHAT IS CONTROL ?  

 

The control of a company is a difficult concept to define as a
matter of law, but essentially, it denotes the relationship which exists when
an individual or a group of individuals who are clearly identifiable in some
respect or respects and who may themselves be incorporated exercise powers of
direction and dominance over the affairs of a company.


It is not easy to locate control in a corporation as there is no set
rule for determining control.


An individual Corporation may be related to other corporations,
banks, financial institutions, etc.  via  complex patterns of
shareholdings, interlocking directorships, etc. and so a case-by-case
approach is necessary.     <*> line through
column</*>

 

Control is defined in the draft United States Federal Securities
Code, section 202, as follows:  " control means power, directly or
indirectly to exercise controlling influence over management or policies of a
company or the activities of a natural person, either alone or pursuant to an
arrangement or understanding with one or more other persons whether through
the ownership of voting securities, through one or more intermediary persons,
by contract or otherwise."  

 

" Berle and Means " were the first to trace the
development of the concept of control.


In their book  " The Modern Corporation " 
and  " Private Property, "  they identified
different species of control in the modern company, which were: 


  1. Control through complete ownership  

 

This was a straightforward category which resembled the position
in private companies in which a single individual or small group of
associates own all or practically all the shares in the company.


In such case, the ownership and control are in the same hands. 


  2. Majority control  

 

This is the first step in separation oF ownership and control.


It consists of ownership of majority of the  issued
shares.


This brings in virtually all the legal powers of control. 


  3. Control through legal devices  

 

This category is more common in the United States than to the
Common wealth.


It was the practice of voting trusts and shareholder agreements and
pyramiding.


Pyramiding involves the owning of stock of one company which in turn,
holds stock in another. 


  4 ( a). Minority control  

 

This category of control exists when individual small groups hold
sufficient interest to be in a position to dominate a company through share
interest.


The large the company, the easier it is to have minority control, but
everything depends on the situation in a particular company. 


  4 ( b). Management control  

 

This category is characterised by shares initially being so
widely distributed that no individual or small group has even a minority
interest to dominate the affairs of the company. 

 

Today, in India, the largest shareholders in the public limited
companies tend to be the public financial institutions.


It is then difficult to determine whether there is management control
or minority control or negative control vested in the hands of these
financial institutions. 

 

Do the public financial institutions have control?


In a sense, the rise of the investor reproduces something with which
the law has had to deal ever since the advent of the modern company: the
concentration of power in the hands of one or more shareholders.


This affords to the controlling shareholder the  power to influence the dividend policy and in many cases, the management
of the whole company.


There is also a power to influence management through threats to sell
shareholdings or to work against management can be made to tow the line of
the public financial institutions.


The financial institutions can be said to be just another example of
a power bloc within a company.    

 

In India, the public financial institutions are major
shareholders in public limited companies, but do they have  ` control'
 over these companies ?


This question can be answered by looking at two major acts, which a
public financial institution could perform, by virtue of its majority
shareholding. 


  ACTS OPPRESSIVE TO THE MINORITY  

 

In  " Nagappa Chettiar v. Madras Race Club,
"     the court ruled that the rule laid
down in  " Foss v. Harbottle "   
 , along with its exceptions, held good in India courts.


The rule is that the company is the right person to sue and that it
is not open to the individual members to assume to themselves the right of
suing in the name of the company, except where the transaction is illegal;
where the transaction requires the sanction of a special majority; where the
transaction infringes the personal rights of the shareholders; and where the
transaction amounts to a fraud on the minority.


But, the company can only act through the board of directors and they
may well be the wrong-doers.


They may, therefore, decide not to sue a decision approved by the
company in the general meeting, where the wrong-doers control the majority of
votes.


The outcome would be that the wrong doers would go unpunished and
minority shareholders would be at the mercy of the majority who could loot
the company.


In such a case, control exists because the wrong-doers have a
majority of votes and have actually approved the fraud.


Further, if in this case, the minority shareholders brought an action
and were able to show that the defendants, by any means of manipulation of
their position in the company, were able to ensure that no action was
brought, it would clearly go to show that the defendants were in control.


 

In  " Prudential Assurance Company Limited v. Newman
Industries Limited " ( No. 2)     , it
was held that while the plaintiff in an action for wrong done to the company
is normally the company itself, in exceptional circumstances a minority
shareholder may bring a derivative action on behalf of the company where the
wrong done to the company is a fraud and the wrong-doers are in majority,
thereby preventing the company from suing. 

 

Even if an exception can be successfully invoked, a number of
difficulties beset the path of the shareholder who decides to pursue an
action against the alleged wrong doers. 

 

The transactions are often of a complicated nature and so it is
difficult to establish what the transaction involves and who the
beneficiaries are.


A large amount of money is also required to pursue an action of such
a nature.    

 

The better non-statutory option open to an aggrieved shareholder
in such a case is to withdraw his investment from the company by selling his
shares.


The statutory alternatives open to an aggrieved shareholder include
petitioning the Company Law Board under section 397 or 398. 


Section 397 provides,  " any members of a company who
complains that the affairs of the company are being conducted in a manner
prejudicial to public interest or in a manner oppressive to any member or
members ( including any one or more of themselves) may apply to the Company
Law Board for an order under this section <*> dotted line</*>" 

 

Section 397 ( 2) lays down that in order grant relief under this
section, there should be facts to justify the making of a winding up order.


 

The aggrieved shareholder can also proceed under section 398.


In order to grant relief under this section, it is not necessary to
show that there are facts which justify the making of a winding up order.


It is enough if the affairs of the company are being conducted in a
manner prejudicial to the interests of the company or to public interest.


 

The  ` words in a manner prejudicial to public interest'
 were inserted in sections 397, 398 and 408 by the Companies (
Amendment ) Act, 1963.


This enables the Central Government to move the Company Law Board
under these sections,  "  suo motu  "
,  on grounds of public interest. 

 

In  " State of Bihar v. Kameshwar Singh "
    Mahajan CJ, opined:  " the expression
[ public interest] is not capable of precise definition and has not a rigid
meaning, and is elastic and takes its colours from the statute in which it
occurs, the concept varying with the time and state of society and its needs.


Thus, what is  ` public interest'  today may not be so
considered a decade later.


In any case, the expression cannot be considered in vacuo but must be
decided on the facts and circumstances."  

 

The concept of  ` public interest'  takes the
company outside the conventional sphere of being a concern in which the
shareholders alone are interested.


It emphasizes the idea that the company functions for the general
welfare of the community    . 

 

In practice, it is difficult to sustain an application on the
ground that the affairs of a company are conducted in a manner prejudicial to
public interest because, conducting the affairs in such a manner cannot be a
just an equitable ground for winding up of the company unless the affairs of
the company should be considered illegal or opposed to public policy 
  . 


  DISMISSAL OF DIRECTORS  

 

The day-to-day control of the business of a company is in the
hands of directors.


As a matter of company law, shareholders cannot intervene in the
management of the  affairs. 

 

Section 284 ( 1), however, provides that the shareholders may, by
ordinary resolution, remove a director ( not being a director appointed by
the Central Government in pursuance of section 408 ) from office.


Under section 284 ( 2), special notice has to be given of any such
resolution.


Section 284(3) provides that the company must supply a copy of the
resolution to the concerned  director, who is
entitled to be heard at the meeting.


Further section 284 ( 4) provides that he may require the company to
circulate, to shareholders, any representation he makes.


This elaborate procedure is laid down to prevent a director from
being deprived of an office of profit without having had an opportunity of
being heard. 

 

Therefore, even if the shareholders act malafide or out of spite
against a particular director, there is no basis in Indian Company Law for an
injunction restraining the company from giving effect to the resolution,
provided only, that requirements of the aforesaid section have been met. 

 

A dismissed director could petition under section 433 ( f), for
winding up of the company on just and equitable ground.


But, the Supreme Court has shown in  Hind Overseas ( P) Ltd v.
Raghunat Prasad Junjhunwala     , that it is not
in favour of such a remedy.


Here, a private company was formed, in which an employee " "
A" " , who had gained the confidence of the employer " " B"
" , was taken in as managing director.


" " A" " and his family members held about one-third
of the shares while " " B" " and his family members held
about two-thirds of the shares and the direction, control and financial
responsibility were also in  hands.


The Supreme Court held that it was not a case in which the
dissolution of partnership principle could be invoked in favour of  "
A"  ( and his group of shareholders ) on the  ` just and
equitable ground'  , as several remedies such as those under sections
397 and 398 were open to the minority shareholders under the Companies Act,
1956, and an application for winding up the company would be unreasonable.


 

Thus, a financial institution can effectively exercise control by
removing the directors of the company, in which it is a major shareholder.


The financial institution has to ensure that an ordinary resolution
is passed authorising the removal of a director, and that the relevant
provisions of the Companies Act, 1956, are complied with.


This threat of removal could be effectively used to influence the
decisions of the management.
